Text

ï»¿BASIL

By [Wilkie Collins]35-wilkie collins

LETTER OF DEDICATION .

TO [CHARLES JAMES WARD]36-charles james ward , ESQ .

IT has long been one of [my]0-i pleasantest anticipations to look forward to the time when [I]0-i might offer to [you]96-you , [[my]0-i old and dear friend]97-my old and dear friend , some such acknowledgment of the value [I]0-i place on [your]96-you affection for [me]0-i , and of [my]0-i grateful sense of the many acts of kindness by which that affection has been proved , as [I]0-i now gladly offer in this place . In dedicating the present work to [you]96-you , [I]0-i fulfil therefore a purpose which , for some time past , [I]0-i have sincerely desired to achieve ; and , more than that , [I]0-i gain for [myself]0-i the satisfaction of knowing that there is one page , at least , of [my]0-i book , on which [I]0-i shall always look with unalloyed pleasure - the page that bears [your]96-you name .

[I]0-i have founded the main event out of which this story springs , on a fact within [my]0-i own knowledge . In afterwards shaping the course of the narrative thus suggested , [I]0-i have guided it , as often as [I]0-i could , where [I]0-i knew by [my]0-i own experience , or by experience related to [me]0-i by [others]98-others , that it would touch on something real and true in its progress . [My]0-i idea was , that the more of the Actual [I]0-i could garner up as a text to speak from , the more certain [I]0-i might feel of the genuineness and value of the Ideal which was sure to spring out of it . Fancy and Imagination , Grace and Beauty , all those qualities which are to the work of Art what scent and colour are to the flower , can only grow towards heaven by taking root in earth . Is not the noblest poetry of prose fiction the poetry of every - day truth ?

Directing [[my]0-i characters]99-my characters and [my]0-i story , then , towards the light of Reality wherever [I]0-i could find it , [I]0-i have not hesitated to violate some of the conventionalities of sentimental fiction . For instance , the first love - meeting of two of [the personages]100-the personages in this book , occurs where the real love - meeting from which it is drawn , occurred in the very last place and under the very last circumstances which the artifices of sentimental writing would sanction . Will [[my]0-i lovers]101-my lovers excite ridicule instead of interest , because [I]0-i have truly represented [them]101-my lovers as seeing [each other]102-each other where hundreds of [other lovers]103-other lovers have first seen [each other]102-each other , as [hundreds of [people]106-people]105-hundreds of people will readily admit when [they]105-hundreds of people read the passage to which [I]0-i refer ? [I]0-i am sanguine enough to think not .

So again , in certain parts of this book where [I]0-i have attempted to excite the suspense or pity of [the reader]107-the reader , [I]0-i have admitted as perfectly fit accessories to the scene [the most ordinary street - sounds that could be heard]108-the most ordinary street - sounds that could be heard , and the most ordinary street - events that could occur , at the time and in the place represented - believing that by adding to truth , they were adding to tragedy - adding by all the force of fair contrast - adding as no artifices of mere writing possibly could add , let [them]101-my lovers be ever so cunningly introduced by ever so crafty a hand .

Allow [me]0-i to dwell a moment longer on the story which these pages contain .

Believing that the Novel and the Play are twin - sisters in the family of Fiction ; that [the one]109-the one is a drama narrated , as the other is a drama acted ; and that all the strong and deep emotions which [the Play - writer]110-the play - writer is privileged to excite , [the Novel - writer]111-the novel - writer is privileged to excite also , [I]0-i have not thought it either politic or necessary , while adhering to realities , to adhere to every - day realities only . In other words , [I]0-i have not stooped so low as to assure [myself]0-i of [the reader]107-the reader 's belief in the probability of [my]0-i story , by never once calling on [him]107-the reader for the exercise of [his]107-the reader faith . Those extraordinary accidents and events which happen to [few men]113-few men , seemed to [me]0-i to be as legitimate materials for fiction to work with - when there was a good object in using them - as the ordinary accidents and events which may , and do , happen to [us]114-us all . By appealing to genuine sources of interest within [the reader]107-the reader 's own experience , [I]0-i could certainly gain [his]107-the reader attention to begin with ; but it would be only by appealing to other sources as genuine in [their]116-their way beyond [his]107-the reader own experience , that [I]0-i could hope to fix [his]107-the reader interest and excite [his]107-the reader suspense , to occupy [his]107-the reader deeper feelings , or to stir [his]107-the reader nobler thoughts .

In writing thus - briefly and very generally - for [I]0-i must not delay [you]117-you too long from the story , [I]0-i can but repeat , though [I]0-i hope almost unnecessarily , that [I]0-i am now only speaking of what [I]0-i have tried to do . Between the purpose hinted at here , and the execution of that purpose contained in the succeeding pages , lies the broad line of separation which distinguishes between the will and the deed . How far [I]0-i may fall short of [another man]118-another man 's standard , remains to be discovered . How far [I]0-i have fallen short of [my]0-i own , [I]0-i know painfully well .

One word more on the manner in which the purpose of the following pages is worked out - and [I]0-i have done .

[Nobody who admits that the business of fiction]119-nobody who admits that the business of fiction is to exhibit human life , can deny that scenes of misery and crime must of necessity , while human nature remains what it is , form part of that exhibition . [Nobody]120-nobody can assert that such scenes are unproductive of useful results , when they are turned to a plainly and purely moral purpose . If [I]0-i am asked why [I]0-i have written certain scenes in this book , [my]0-i answer is to be found in the universally - accepted truth which the preceding words express . [I]0-i have a right to appeal to that truth ; for [I]0-i guided [myself]0-i by it throughout . In deriving the lesson which the following pages contain , from those examples of error and crime which would most strikingly and naturally teach it , [I]0-i determined to do justice to the honesty of [my]0-i object by speaking out . In drawing [the two characters]121-the two characters , whose actions bring about the darker scenes of [my]0-i story , [I]0-i did not forget that it was [my]0-i duty , while striving to portray them naturally , to put them to a good moral use ; and at some sacrifice , in certain places , of dramatic effect though [I]0-i trust with no sacrifice of truth to Nature , [I]0-i have shown the conduct of the vile , as always , in a greater or less degree , associated with something that is selfish , contemptible , or cruel in motive . Whether any of [[my]0-i better characters]122-my better characters may succeed in endearing [themselves]122-my better characters to [the reader]107-the reader , [I]0-i know not : but this [I]0-i do certainly know : - that [I]0-i shall in no instance cheat [him]107-the reader out of [his]107-the reader sympathies in favour of the bad .

To [those persons who dissent from the broad principles here adverted to]124-those persons who dissent from the broad principles here adverted to ; who deny that it is [the novelist]125-the novelist 's vocation to do more than merely amuse [them]124-those persons who dissent from the broad principles here adverted to ; who shrink from all honest and serious reference , in books , to subjects which [they]124-those persons who dissent from the broad principles here adverted to think of in private and talk of in public everywhere ; who see covert implications where nothing is implied , and improper allusions where nothing improper is alluded to ; whose innocence is in the word , and not in the thought ; whose morality stops at the tongue , and never gets on to the heart - to [those persons]126-those persons , [I]0-i should consider it loss of time , and worse , to offer any further explanation of [my]0-i motives , than the sufficient explanation which [I]0-i have given already . [I]0-i do not address [myself]0-i to [them]126-those persons in this book , and shall never think of addressing [myself]0-i to [them]126-those persons in any other .

PART I.

[I.]0-i

WHAT am [I]0-i now about to write ?

The history of little more than the events of one year , out of the twenty - four years of [my]0-i life .

Why do [I]0-i undertake such an employment as this ?

Perhaps , because [I]0-i think that [my]0-i narrative may do good ; because [I]0-i hope that , one day , it may be put to some warning use . [I]0-i am now about to relate the story of an error , innocent in its beginning , guilty in its progress , fatal in its results ; and [I]0-i would fain hope that [my]0-i plain and true record will show that this error was not committed altogether without excuse . When these pages are found after [my]0-i death , they will perhaps be calmly read and gently judged , as relics solemnized by the atoning shadows of the grave . Then , the hard sentence against [me]0-i may be repented of ; [the children of the next generation of [[our]128-our house]129-our house]127-the children of the next generation of our house may be taught to speak charitably of [my]0-i memory , and may often , of [their]127-the children of the next generation of our house own accord , think of [me]0-i kindly in the thoughtful watches of the night .

Prompted by these motives , and by others which [I]0-i feel , but can not analyse , [I]0-i now begin [my]0-i self - imposed occupation . Hidden amid [the far hills of [the far West of [England]1-england]131-the far west of england , surrounded only by [the few simple inhabitants of [a fishing hamlet]133-a fishing hamlet on [the Cornish coast]134-the cornish coast]132-the few simple inhabitants of a fishing hamlet on the cornish coast]130-the far hills of the far west of england , surrounded only by the few simple inhabitants of a fishing hamlet on the cornish coast , there is little fear that [my]0-i attention will be distracted from [my]0-i task ; and as little chance that any indolence on [my]0-i part will delay its speedy accomplishment . [I]0-i live under a threat of impending hostility , which may descend and overwhelm [me]0-i , [I]0-i know not how soon , or in what manner . [An enemy , determined and deadly]135-an enemy , determined and deadly , patient alike to wait days or years for [his]135-an enemy , determined and deadly opportunity , is ever lurking after [me]0-i in the dark . In entering on [my]0-i new employment , [I]0-i can not say of [my]0-i time , that it may be [mine]0-i for another hour ; of [my]0-i life , that it may last till evening .

Thus it is as no leisure work that [I]0-i begin [my]0-i narrative - and begin it , too , on [my]0-i birthday ! On this day [I]0-i complete [my]0-i twenty - fourth year ; the first new year of [my]0-i life which has not been greeted by a single kind word , or a single loving wish . But one look of welcome can still find [me]0-i in [my]0-i solitude - the lovely morning look of nature , as [I]0-i now see it from the casement of [[my]0-i room]136-my room . Brighter and brighter shines out the lusty sun from banks of purple , rainy cloud ; [fishermen]137-fishermen are spreading [their]137-fishermen nets to dry on the lower declivities of [the rocks]138-the rocks ; [children]139-children are playing round the boats drawn up on [the beach]140-the beach ; the sea - breeze blows fresh and pure towards [the shore]141-the shore - - all objects are brilliant to look on , all sounds are pleasant to hear , as [my]0-i pen traces the first lines which open the story of [my]0-i life .

II .

[I]0-i am [the second son of [an English gentleman of large fortune]143-an english gentleman of large fortune]142-the second son of an english gentleman of large fortune . [[Our]144-our family]145-our family is , [I]0-i believe , one of the most ancient in [this country]146-this country . On [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's side , it dates back beyond the Conquest ; on [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother 's , it is not so old , but the pedigree is nobler . Besides [[my]0-i elder brother]149-my elder brother , [I]0-i have [one sister]150-one sister , younger than [myself]0-i . [[My]0-i mother]148-my mother died shortly after giving birth to [[her]148-my mother last child]152-her last child .

Circumstances which will appear hereafter , have forced [me]0-i to abandon [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's name . [I]0-i have been obliged in honour to resign it ; and in honour [I]0-i abstain from mentioning it here . Accordingly , at the head of these pages , [I]0-i have only placed [my]0-i Christian name - not considering it of any importance to add the surname which [I]0-i have assumed ; and which [I]0-i may , perhaps , be obliged to change for some other , at no very distant period . It will now , [I]0-i hope , be understood from the outset , why [I]0-i never mention [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother and [sister]155-sister but by [their]156-their Christian names ; why a blank occurs wherever [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's name should appear ; why [my]0-i own is kept concealed in this narrative , as it is kept concealed in [the world]158-the world .

The story of [my]0-i boyhood and youth has little to interest - nothing that is new . [My]0-i education was the education of [hundreds of others]159-hundreds of others in [my]0-i rank of life . [I]0-i was first taught at [a public school]160-a public school , and then went to college to complete what is termed " a liberal education . "[0-i]

[My]0-i life at college has not left [me]0-i a single pleasant recollection . [I]0-i found sycophancy established [there]161-there , as a principle of action ; flaunting on [the lord]162-the lord 's gold tassel in [the street]163-the street ; enthroned on [the lord]162-the lord 's dais in [the dining - room]165-the dining - room . [The most learned student in [my]0-i college]166-the most learned student in my college - [the man whose life was most exemplary , whose acquirements were most admirable]167-the man whose life was most exemplary , whose acquirements were most admirable - was shown [me]0-i sitting , as [a commoner]168-a commoner , in the lowest place . [The heir to an Earldom , who had failed at the last examination]169-the heir to an earldom , who had failed at the last examination , was pointed out a few minutes afterwards , dining in solitary grandeur at a raised table , above [the reverend scholars who had turned [him]169-the heir to an earldom , who had failed at the last examination back as [a dunce]171-a dunce]170-the reverend scholars who had turned him back as a dunce . [I]0-i had just arrived at [the University]172-the university , and had just been congratulated on entering " [a venerable seminary of learning and religion]3039-a venerable seminary of learning and religion . "[0-i]

Trite and common - place though it be , [I]0-i mention this circumstance attending [my]0-i introduction to college , because it formed the first cause which tended to diminish [my]0-i faith in [the institution to which [I]0-i was attached]173-the institution to which i was attached . [I]0-i soon grew to regard [my]0-i university training as a sort of necessary evil , to be patiently submitted to . [I]0-i read for no honours , and joined [no particular set of men]174-no particular set of men . [I]0-i studied the literature of [France]2-france , [Italy]3-italy , and [Germany]4-germany ; just kept up [my]0-i classical knowledge sufficiently to take [my]0-i degree ; and left [college]175-college with no other reputation than a reputation for indolence and reserve .

When [I]0-i returned [home]176-home , it was thought necessary , as [I]0-i was [a younger son]177-a younger son , and could inherit none of [the landed property of [the family]179-the family]178-the landed property of the family , except in the case of [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's dying without [children]139-children , that [I]0-i should belong to a profession . [[My]0-i father]147-my father had the patronage of some valuable " livings , "[147-my father] and good interest with more than [one member of [the government]184-the government]183-one member of the government . [The church]185-the church , [the army]186-the army , [the navy]187-the navy , and , in the last instance , the bar , were offered [me]0-i to choose from . [I]0-i selected the last .

[[My]0-i father]147-my father appeared to be a little astonished at [my]0-i choice ; but [he]147-my father made no remark on it , except simply telling [me]0-i not to forget that the bar was a good stepping - stone to parliament . [My]0-i real ambition , however , was , not to make a name in parliament , but a name in literature . [I]0-i had already engaged [myself]0-i in the hard , but glorious service of the pen ; and [I]0-i was determined to persevere . The profession which offered [me]0-i the greatest facilities for pursuing [my]0-i project , was the profession which [I]0-i was ready to prefer . So [I]0-i chose the bar .

Thus , [I]0-i entered life under the fairest auspices . Though [a younger son]177-a younger son , [I]0-i knew that [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's wealth , exclusive of [his]147-my father landed property , secured [me]0-i an independent income far beyond [my]0-i wants . [I]0-i had no extravagant habits ; no tastes that [I]0-i could not gratify as soon as formed ; no cares or responsibilities of any kind . [I]0-i might practise [my]0-i profession or not , just as [I]0-i chose . [I]0-i could devote [myself]0-i wholly and unreservedly to literature , knowing that , in [my]0-i case , the struggle for fame could never be identical - terribly , though gloriously identical - with the struggle for bread . For [me]0-i , the morning sunshine of life was sunshine without a cloud !

[I]0-i might attempt , in this place , to sketch [my]0-i own character as it was at that time . But what [man]191-man can say - [I]0-i will sound the depth of [my]0-i own vices , and measure the height of [my]0-i own virtues ; and be as good as [his]191-man word ? [We]192-we can neither know nor judge [ourselves]192-we ; [others]98-others may judge , but can not know [us]192-we : [God]37-god alone judges and knows too . Let [my]0-i character appear - as far as [any human character]194-any human character can appear in its integrity , in [this world]195-this world - in [my]0-i actions , when [I]0-i describe the one eventful passage in [my]0-i life which forms the basis of this narrative . In the mean time , it is first necessary that [I]0-i should say more about [the members of [[my]0-i family]197-my family]196-the members of my family . [Two of [them]196-the members of my family]198-two of them , at least , will be found important to the progress of events in these pages . [I]0-i make no attempt to judge [their]196-the members of my family characters : [I]0-i only describe [them]196-the members of my family - whether rightly or wrongly , [I]0-i know not - as [they]196-the members of my family appeared to [me]0-i .

III .

[I]0-i always considered [[my]0-i father]147-my father - [I]0-i speak of [him]147-my father in the past tense , because [we]200-we are now separated for ever ; because [he]147-my father is henceforth as dead to [me]0-i as if the grave had closed over [him]147-my father - [I]0-i always considered [[my]0-i father]147-my father to be [the proudest man [I]0-i ever knew]202-the proudest man i ever knew ; [the proudest man [I]0-i ever heard of]203-the proudest man i ever heard of . [His]147-my father was not that conventional pride , which the popular notions are fond of characterising by a stiff , stately carriage ; by a rigid expression of features ; by a hard , severe intonation of voice ; by set speeches of contempt for poverty and rags , and rhapsodical braggadocio about rank and breeding . [[My]0-i father]147-my father 's pride had nothing of this about it . It was that quiet , negative , courteous , inbred pride , which only [the closest observation]205-the closest observation could detect ; which [no ordinary observers]206-no ordinary observers ever detected at all .

Who that observed [him]147-my father in communication with [any of [the farmers on any of [his]147-my father estates]208-the farmers on any of his estates - who that saw the manner in which [he]147-my father lifted [his]147-my father hat , when [he]147-my father accidentally met [any of [those farmers]210-those farmers ' wives]209-any of those farmers ' wives - who that noticed [his]147-my father hearty welcome to [the man of the people]211-the man of the people , when [that man]212-that man happened to be [a man of genius]213-a man of genius]207-any of the farmers on any of his estates - who that saw the manner in which he lifted his hat , when he accidentally met any of those farmers ' wives - who that noticed his hearty welcome to the man of the people , when that man happened to be a man of genius - would have thought [him]147-my father proud ? On such occasions as these , if [he]147-my father had any pride , it was impossible to detect it . But seeing [him]147-my father when , for instance , [an author]214-an author and [a new - made peer of no ancestry]215-a new - made peer of no ancestry entered [[his]147-my father house]216-his house together - observing merely the entirely different manner in which [he]147-my father shook hands with each - remarking that the polite cordiality was all for [the man of letters]217-the man of letters , who did not contest [[his]147-my father family]218-his family rank with [him]147-my father , and the polite formality all for [the man of title]219-the man of title , who did - [you]220-you discovered where and how [he]147-my father was proud in an instant . Here lay [his]147-my father fretful point . The aristocracy of rank , as separate from [the aristocracy of ancestry]221-the aristocracy of ancestry , was no aristocracy for [him]147-my father . [He]147-my father was jealous of it ; [he]147-my father hated it . Commoner though [he]147-my father was , [he]147-my father considered [himself]147-my father [the social superior of [any man]223-any man , from [a baronet]224-a baronet up to [a duke]225-a duke , whose family was less ancient than [his]147-my father own]222-the social superior of any man , from a baronet up to a duke , whose family was less ancient than his own .

Among a host of instances of this peculiar pride of [his]147-my father which [I]0-i could cite , [I]0-i remember one , characteristic enough to be taken as a sample of all the rest . It happened when [I]0-i was quite [a child]226-a child , and was told [me]0-i by [one of [[my]0-i uncles]228-my uncles now dead - who witnessed the circumstance [himself]227-one of my uncles now dead - who witnessed the circumstance himself , and always made a good story of it to the end of his life , and always made a good story of it to the end of [his]227-one of my uncles now dead - who witnessed the circumstance himself , and always made a good story of it to the end of his life life]227-one of my uncles now dead - who witnessed the circumstance himself , and always made a good story of it to the end of his life .

[A merchant of enormous wealth , who had recently been raised to the peerage]229-a merchant of enormous wealth , who had recently been raised to the peerage , was staying at [one of [[our]231-our country houses]232-our country houses]230-one of our country houses . [[His]229-a merchant of enormous wealth , who had recently been raised to the peerage daughter]233-his daughter , [[my]0-i uncle]234-my uncle , and [an Italian Abbe]235-an italian abbe were [the only guests besides]236-the only guests besides . [The merchant]237-the merchant was [a portly , purple - faced man , who bore [his]237-the merchant new honours]238-a portly , purple - faced man , who bore his new honours with a curious mixture of assumed pomposity and natural good - humour . [The Abbe]38-the abbe was dwarfish and deformed , lean , sallow , sharp - featured , with bright bird - like eyes , and a low , liquid voice . [He]235-an italian abbe was [a political refugee]239-a political refugee , dependent for the bread [he]235-an italian abbe ate , on the money [he]235-an italian abbe received for teaching languages . [He]235-an italian abbe might have been [a beggar from [the streets]241-the streets]240-a beggar from the streets ; and still [[my]0-i father]147-my father would have treated [him]235-an italian abbe as [the principal guest in [the house]244-the house]243-the principal guest in the house , for this all - sufficient reason - [he]235-an italian abbe was [a direct descendant of [one of the oldest of those famous Roman families whose names are part of the history of the Civil Wars in [Italy]3-italy]246-one of the oldest of those famous roman families whose names are part of the history of the civil wars in italy]245-a direct descendant of one of the oldest of those famous roman families whose names are part of the history of the civil wars in italy .

On the first day , [the party]247-the party assembled for dinner comprised [[the merchant]237-the merchant 's daughter]249-the merchant 's daughter , [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother , [an old lady who had once been [[her]237-the merchant governess]252-her governess , and had always lived with [her]237-the merchant since [her]237-the merchant marriage , [the new Lord]253-the new lord , [the Abbe]254-the abbe , [[my]0-i father]147-my father , and [[my]0-i uncle]234-my uncle]251-an old lady who had once been her governess , and had always lived with her since her marriage , the new lord , the abbe , my father , and my uncle . When dinner was announced , [the peer]257-the peer advanced in new - blown dignity , to offer [his]257-the peer arm as a matter of course to [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother . [[My]0-i father]147-my father 's pale face flushed crimson in a moment . [He]147-my father touched [the magnificent merchant - lord]260-the magnificent merchant - lord on the arm , and pointed significantly , with a low bow , towards [the decrepit old lady who had once been [[my]0-i mother 's governess]262-my mother 's governess]261-the decrepit old lady who had once been my mother 's governess . Then walking to the other end of [the room]263-the room , where [the penniless Abbe]264-the penniless abbe was looking over a book in a corner , [he]147-my father gravely and courteously led [the little , deformed , limping language - master]265-the little , deformed , limping language - master , clad in a long , threadbare , black coat , up to [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother whose shoulder the [Abbe]38-the abbe 's head hardly reached , held the door open for [them]267-them to pass out first , with [his]147-my father own hand ; politely invited [the new nobleman , who stood half - paralysed between confusion and astonishment]268-the new nobleman , who stood half - paralysed between confusion and astonishment , to follow with [the tottering old lady]269-the tottering old lady on [his]147-my father arm ; and then returned to lead [[the peer]257-the peer 's daughter]271-the peer 's daughter down to dinner [himself]147-my father . [He]147-my father only resumed [his]147-my father wonted expression and manner , when [he]147-my father had seen [the little Abbe]272-the little abbe - [the squalid , half - starved representative of [mighty barons of the olden time]274-mighty barons of the olden time]273-the squalid , half - starved representative of mighty barons of the olden time - seated at the highest place of the table by [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother 's side .

It was by such accidental circumstances as these that [you]276-you discovered how far [he]147-my father was proud . [He]147-my father never boasted of [[his]147-my father ancestors]277-his ancestors ; [he]147-my father never even spoke of [them]277-his ancestors , except when [he]147-my father was questioned on the subject ; but [he]147-my father never forgot [them]277-his ancestors . [They]277-his ancestors were the very breath of [his]147-my father life ; the deities of [his]147-my father social worship : the family treasures to be held precious beyond all lands and all wealth , all ambitions and all glories , by [[his]147-my father children]278-his children and [[[his]147-my father children]278-his children 's children to the end of [[their]278-his children race]281-their race]280-his children 's children to the end of their race .

In [home]176-home - life [he]147-my father performed [his]147-my father duties towards [[his]147-my father family]218-his family honourably , delicately , and kindly . [I]0-i believe in [his]147-my father own way [he]147-my father loved [us]284-we all ; but [we]284-we , [[his]147-my father descendants]285-his descendants , had to share [his]147-my father heart with [[his]147-my father ancestors]277-his ancestors - [we]284-we were [his]147-my father household property as well as [[his]147-my father children]278-his children . Every fair liberty was given to [us]284-we ; every fair indulgence was granted to [us]284-we . [He]147-my father never displayed any suspicion , or any undue severity . [We]284-we were taught by [his]147-my father direction , that to disgrace [[our]284-we family]145-our family , either by word or action , was the one fatal crime which could never be forgotten and never be pardoned . [We]284-we were formed , under [his]147-my father superintendence , in principles of religion , honour , and industry ; and the rest was left to [our]284-we own moral sense , to [our]284-we own comprehension of the duties and privileges of [our]284-we station . There was no one point in [his]147-my father conduct towards any of [us]284-we that [we]284-we could complain of ; and yet there was something always incomplete in [our]284-we domestic relations .

It may seem incomprehensible , even ridiculous , to [some persons]289-some persons , but it is nevertheless true , that [we]284-we were none of [us]284-we ever on intimate terms with [him]147-my father . [I]0-i mean by this , that [he]147-my father was [a father to [us]284-we]290-a father to us , but never [a companion]291-a companion . There was something in [his]147-my father manner , [his]147-my father quiet and unchanging manner , which kept [us]284-we almost unconsciously restrained . [I]0-i never in [my]0-i life felt less at [my]0-i ease - [I]0-i knew not why at the time - than when [I]0-i occasionally dined alone with [him]147-my father . [I]0-i never confided to [him]147-my father [my]0-i schemes for amusement as [a boy]292-a boy , or mentioned more than generally [my]0-i ambitious hopes , as [a young man]293-a young man . It was not that [he]147-my father would have received such confidences with ridicule or severity , [he]147-my father was incapable of it ; but that [he]147-my father seemed above [them]294-them , unfitted to enter into [them]294-them , too far removed by [his]147-my father own thoughts from such thoughts as [ours]284-we . Thus , all holiday councils were held with [old servants]295-old servants ; thus , [my]0-i first pages of manuscript , when [I]0-i first tried authorship , were read by [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , and never penetrated into [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's study .

Again , [his]147-my father mode of testifying displeasure towards [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother or [myself]0-i , had something terrible in its calmness , something that [we]284-we never forgot , and always dreaded as the worst calamity that could befall [us]284-we .

Whenever , as [boys]299-boys , [we]284-we committed some boyish fault , [he]147-my father never displayed outwardly any irritation - [he]147-my father simply altered [his]147-my father manner towards [us]284-we altogether . [We]284-we were not soundly lectured , or vehemently threatened , or positively punished in anyway ; but , when [we]284-we came in contact with [him]147-my father , [we]284-we were treated with a cold , contemptuous politeness especially if [our]284-we fault showed a tendency to anything mean or ungentlemanlike which cut [us]284-we to the heart . On these occasions , [we]284-we were not addressed by [our]284-we Christian names ; if [we]284-we accidentally met [him]147-my father out of doors , [he]147-my father was sure to turn aside and avoid [us]284-we ; if [we]284-we asked a question , it was answered in the briefest possible manner , as if [we]284-we had been [strangers]300-strangers . [His]147-my father whole course of conduct said , as though in so many words - [You]301-you have rendered [yourselves]301-you unfit to associate with [[your]301-you father]302-your father ; and [he]147-my father is now making [you]301-you feel that unfitness as deeply as [he]147-my father does . [We]284-we were left in this domestic purgatory for days , sometimes for weeks together . To [our]284-we boyish feelings to [mine]303-mine especially there was no ignominy like it , while it lasted .

[I]0-i know not on what terms [[my]0-i father]147-my father lived with [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother . Towards [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , [his]147-my father demeanour always exhibited something of the old - fashioned , affectionate gallantry of a former age . [He]147-my father paid [her]296-my sister the same attention that [he]147-my father would have paid to [the highest lady in [the land]308-the land]307-the highest lady in the land . [He]147-my father led [her]296-my sister into [the dining - room]165-the dining - room , when [we]284-we were alone , exactly as [he]147-my father would have led [a duchess]310-a duchess into [a banqueting - hall]311-a banqueting - hall . [He]147-my father would allow [us]284-we , as [boys]299-boys , to quit the breakfast - table before [he]147-my father had risen [himself]147-my father ; but never before [she]296-my sister had left [it]313-it . If [a servant]314-a servant failed in duty towards [him]147-my father , [the servant]315-the servant was often forgiven ; if towards [her]296-my sister , [the servant]315-the servant was sent away on the spot . [[His]147-my father daughter]233-his daughter was in [his]147-my father eyes [the representative of [[her]233-his daughter mother]319-her mother]318-the representative of her mother : [the mistress of [[his]147-my father house]216-his house]320-the mistress of his house , as well as [[his]147-my father child]322-his child . It was curious to see the mixture of high - bred courtesy and fatherly love in [his]147-my father manner , as [he]147-my father just gently touched [her]233-his daughter forehead with [his]147-my father lips , when [he]147-my father first saw [her]233-his daughter in the morning .

In person , [[my]0-i father]147-my father was of not more than middle height . [He]147-my father was very slenderly and delicately made ; [his]147-my father head small , and well set on [his]147-my father shoulders - [his]147-my father forehead more broad than lofty - [his]147-my father complexion singularly pale , except in moments of agitation , when [I]0-i have already noticed its tendency to flush all over in an instant . [His]147-my father eyes , large and gray , had something commanding in their look ; they gave a certain unchanging firmness and dignity to [his]147-my father expression , not often met with . [They]324-they betrayed [his]147-my father birth and breeding , [his]147-my father old ancestral prejudices , [his]147-my father chivalrous sense of honour , in every glance . It required , indeed , all the masculine energy of look about the upper part of [his]147-my father face , to redeem the lower part from an appearance of effeminacy , so delicately was it moulded in its fine Norman outline . [His]147-my father smile was remarkable for its sweetness - it was almost like [a woman]325-a woman 's smile . In speaking , too , [his]147-my father lips often trembled as [women]326-women 's do . If [he]147-my father ever laughed , as [a young man]293-a young man , [his]147-my father laugh must have been very clear and musical ; but since [I]0-i can recollect [him]147-my father , [I]0-i never heard it . In [his]147-my father happiest moments , in the gayest society , [I]0-i have only seen [him]147-my father smile .

There were other characteristics of [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's disposition and manner , which [I]0-i might mention ; but they will appear to greater advantage , perhaps , hereafter , connected with circumstances which especially called [them]329-them forth .

IV .

When [a family]330-a family is possessed of [large landed property]331-large landed property , [the individual of that family who shows least interest in [its]330-a family welfare]332-the individual of that family who shows least interest in its welfare ; who is least fond of [home]176-home , least connected by [his]147-my father own sympathies with [[his]147-my father relatives]334-his relatives , least ready to learn [his]147-my father duties or admit [his]147-my father responsibilities , is often [that very individual who is to succeed to the family]335-that very individual who is to succeed to the family inheritance - [the eldest son]336-the eldest son .

[[My]0-i brother]154-my brother [Ralph]39-ralph was no exception to this remark . [We]338-our were educated together . After [our]338-our education was completed , [I]0-i never saw [him]154-my brother , except for short periods . [He]154-my brother was almost always on [the continent]339-the continent , for some years after [he]154-my brother left college . And when [he]154-my brother returned definitely to [England]1-england , [he]154-my brother did not return to live under [our]338-our roof . Both in [town]340-town and [country]341-country [he]154-my brother was [[our]338-our visitor]342-our visitor , not [[our]338-our inmate]343-our inmate .

[I]0-i recollect [him]154-my brother at [school]344-school - stronger , taller , handsomer than [I]0-i was ; far beyond [me]0-i in popularity among [the little community [we]338-our lived with]345-the little community we lived with ; [the first to lead a daring exploit]346-the first to lead a daring exploit , [the last to abandon it]347-the last to abandon it ; now at the bottom of the class , now at the top - just [that sort of gay , boisterous , fine - looking , dare - devil boy , whom [old people]349-old people would instinctively turn round and smile after , as [they]349-old people passed [him]154-my brother by in a morning walk]348-that sort of gay , boisterous , fine - looking , dare - devil boy , whom old people would instinctively turn round and smile after , as they passed him by in a morning walk .

Then , at college , [he]154-my brother became illustrious among [rowers]350-rowers and [cricketers]351-cricketers , renowned as [a pistol shot , dreaded as a singlestick player]352-a pistol shot , dreaded as a singlestick player . No wine parties in [the university]172-the university were such wine parties as [his]154-my brother ; [tradesmen]354-tradesmen gave [him]154-my brother the first choice of everything that was new ; [young ladies in [the town]356-the town]355-young ladies in the town fell in love with [him]154-my brother by [dozens]357-dozens ; [young tutors with a tendency to dandyism]358-young tutors with a tendency to dandyism , copied the cut of [his]154-my brother coat and the tie of [his]154-my brother cravat ; even the awful heads of [houses]359-houses looked leniently on [his]154-my brother delinquencies . [The gay , hearty , handsome young English gentleman]360-the gay , hearty , handsome young english gentleman carried a charm about [him]154-my brother that subdued [everybody]361-everybody . Though [I]0-i was [his]154-my brother favourite butt , both at [school]344-school and college , [I]0-i never quarrelled with [him]154-my brother in [my]0-i life . [I]0-i always let [him]154-my brother ridicule [my]0-i dress , manners , and habits in [his]154-my brother own reckless , boisterous way , as if it had been a part of [his]154-my brother birthright privilege to laugh at [me]0-i as much as [he]154-my brother chose .

Thus far , [[my]0-i father]147-my father had no worse anxieties about [him]147-my father than those occasioned by [his]147-my father high spirits and [his]147-my father heavy debts . But when [he]147-my father returned [home]176-home - when the debts had been paid , and it was next thought necessary to drill the free , careless energies into something like useful discipline - then [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's trials and difficulties began in earnest .

It was impossible to make [Ralph]39-ralph comprehend and appreciate [his]147-my father position , as [he]147-my father was desired to comprehend and appreciate it . [The steward]366-the steward gave up in despair all attempts to enlighten [him]147-my father about the extent , value , and management of the estates [he]147-my father was to inherit . A vigorous effort was made to inspire [him]147-my father with ambition ; to get [him]147-my father to go into parliament . [He]147-my father laughed at the idea . A commission in [the Guards]5-the guards was next offered to [him]147-my father . [He]147-my father refused it , because [he]147-my father would never be buttoned up in a red coat ; because [he]147-my father would submit to no restraints , fashionable or military ; because in short , [he]147-my father was determined to be [[his]147-my father own master]367-his own master . [[My]0-i father]147-my father talked to [him]147-my father by the hour together , about [his]147-my father duties and [his]147-my father prospects , the cultivation of [his]147-my father mind , and the example of [[his]147-my father ancestors]277-his ancestors ; and talked in vain . [He]147-my father yawned and fidgetted over the emblazoned pages of [his]147-my father own family pedigree , whenever they were opened before [him]147-my father .

In [the country]370-the country , [he]147-my father cared for nothing but hunting and shooting - it was as difficult to make [him]147-my father go to [a grand county dinner - party]371-a grand county dinner - party , as to make [him]147-my father go to [church]372-church . In [town]340-town , [he]147-my father haunted [the theatres]374-the theatres , behind the scenes as well as before ; entertained [actors]375-actors and [actresses]376-actresses at [Richmond]6-richmond ; ascended in balloons at [Vauxhall]7-vauxhall ; went about with [detective policemen]377-detective policemen , seeing life among pickpockets and [housebreakers]378-housebreakers ; belonged to a whist club , [a supper club]379-a supper club , [a catch club]380-a catch club , [a boxing club]381-a boxing club , [a picnic club]382-a picnic club , [an amateur theatrical club]383-an amateur theatrical club ; and , in short , lived such a careless , convivial life , that [[my]0-i father]147-my father , outraged in every one of [his]147-my father family prejudices and family refinements , almost ceased to speak to [him]147-my father , and saw [him]147-my father as rarely as possible . Occasionally , [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister 's interference reconciled [them]386-them again for a short time ; [her]296-my sister influence , gentle as it was , was always powerfully felt for good , but [she]296-my sister could not change [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's nature . Persuade and entreat as anxiously as [she]296-my sister might , [he]154-my brother was always sure to forfeit the paternal favour again , a few days after [he]154-my brother had been restored to it .

At last , matters were brought to [their]386-them climax by an awkward love adventure of [Ralph]39-ralph 's with [one of [[our]389-our tenants]390-our tenants ' daughters]388-one of our tenants ' daughters . [[My]0-i father]147-my father acted with [his]147-my father usual decision on the occasion . [He]147-my father determined to apply a desperate remedy : to let [the refractory eldest son]392-the refractory eldest son run through [his]392-the refractory eldest son career in freedom , abroad , until [he]392-the refractory eldest son had well wearied [himself]392-the refractory eldest son , and could return [home]176-home [a sobered man]394-a sobered man . Accordingly , [he]147-my father procured for [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother an [attache]396-attache 's place in [a foreign embassy]397-a foreign embassy , and insisted on [his]392-the refractory eldest son leaving [England]1-england forthwith . For once in a way , [Ralph]39-ralph was docile . [He]147-my father knew and cared nothing about diplomacy ; but [he]147-my father liked the idea of living on [the continent]339-the continent , so [he]147-my father took [his]147-my father leave of [home]176-home with [his]147-my father best grace . [[My]0-i father]147-my father saw [him]147-my father depart , with ill - concealed agitation and apprehension ; although [he]147-my father affected to feel satisfied that , flighty and idle as [Ralph]39-ralph was , [he]147-my father was incapable of voluntarily dishonouring [[his]147-my father family]218-his family , even in [his]147-my father most reckless moods .

After this , [we]402-us heard little from [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother . [His]154-my brother letters were few and short , and generally ended with petitions for money . The only important news of [him]154-my brother that reached [us]402-us , reached [us]402-us through public channels .

[He]154-my brother was making quite a continental reputation - a reputation , the bare mention of which made [[my]0-i father]147-my father wince . [He]154-my brother had fought a duel ; [he]154-my brother had imported a new dance from [Hungary]8-hungary ; [he]154-my brother had contrived to get [the smallest groom that ever was seen behind [a cabriolet]406-a cabriolet]405-the smallest groom that ever was seen behind a cabriolet ; [he]154-my brother had carried off the reigning beauty among [the opera - dancers of the day]407-the opera - dancers of the day from all competitors ; [a great French cook]408-a great french cook had composed a great French dish , and christened it by [his]154-my brother name ; [he]154-my brother was understood to be [the " unknown friend]3040-the " unknown friend , "[154-my brother] to whom [a literary Polish countess]409-a literary polish countess had dedicated [her]409-a literary polish countess " Letters against the restraint of the Marriage Tie ; "[154-my brother] [a female German metaphysician , sixty years old]410-a female german metaphysician , sixty years old , had fallen Platonically in love with [him]154-my brother , and had taken to writing erotic romances in [her]410-a female german metaphysician , sixty years old old age . Such were some of the rumours that reached [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's ears on the subject of [[his]147-my father son]412-his son and [heir]413-heir !

After a long absence , [he]154-my brother came [home]176-home on a visit . How well [I]0-i remember the astonishment [he]154-my brother produced in [the whole household]415-the whole household ! [He]154-my brother had become [a foreigner]416-a foreigner in manners and appearance . [His]154-my brother mustachios were magnificent ; miniature toys in gold and jewellery hung in clusters from [his]154-my brother watch - chain ; [his]154-my brother shirt - front was a perfect filigree of lace and cambric . [He]154-my brother brought with [him]154-my brother [his]154-my brother own boxes of choice liqueurs and perfumes ; [[his]154-my brother own smart , impudent , French valet]417-his own smart , impudent , french valet ; [his]154-my brother own travelling bookcase of French novels , which [he]154-my brother opened with [his]154-my brother own golden key . [He]154-my brother drank nothing but chocolate in the morning ; [he]154-my brother had long interviews with [the cook]418-the cook , and revolutionized [our]419-our dinner table . All the French newspapers were sent to [him]154-my brother by [a London agent]420-a london agent . [He]154-my brother altered the arrangements of [[his]154-my brother bed - room]421-his bed - room ; [no servant]422-no servant but [[his]154-my brother own valet]423-his own valet was permitted to enter [it]421-his bed - room . Family portraits that hung [there]161-there , were turned to the walls , and portraits of [French actresses]425-french actresses and [Italian singers]426-italian singers were stuck to the back of the canvasses . Then [he]154-my brother displaced a beautiful little ebony cabinet which had been in [the family]179-the family three hundred years ; and set up in [its]421-his bed - room stead [a Cyprian temple of [his]154-my brother own]428-a cyprian temple of his own , in miniature , with crystal doors , behind which hung locks of hair , rings , notes written on blush - coloured paper , and other love - tokens kept as sentimental relics . [His]154-my brother influence became all - pervading among [us]419-our . [He]154-my brother seemed to communicate to [the house]244-the house the change that had taken place in [himself]154-my brother , from [the reckless , racketty young Englishman]430-the reckless , racketty young englishman to [the super - exquisite foreign dandy]431-the super - exquisite foreign dandy . It was as if the fiery , effervescent atmosphere of [the Boulevards of [Paris]9-paris]432-the boulevards of paris had insolently penetrated into [the old English mansion]433-the old english mansion , and ruffled and infected [its]433-the old english mansion quiet native air , to [the remotest corners of [the place]435-the place]434-the remotest corners of the place .

[[My]0-i father]147-my father was even more dismayed than displeased by the alteration in [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's habits and manners - [the eldest son]336-the eldest son was now farther from [his]336-the eldest son ideal of what [an eldest son]439-an eldest son should be , than ever . As for [friends]440-friends and [neighbours]441-neighbours , [Ralph]39-ralph was heartily feared and disliked by [them]442-their , before [he]154-my brother had been in [the house]244-the house a week . [He]154-my brother had an ironically patient way of listening to [their]442-their conversation ; an ironically respectful manner of demolishing [their]442-their old - fashioned opinions , and correcting [their]442-their slightest mistakes , which secretly aggravated [them]442-their beyond endurance . It was worse still , when [[my]0-i father]147-my father , in despair , tried to tempt [him]154-my brother into marriage , as the one final chance of working [his]154-my brother reform ; and invited [half the marriageable young ladies of [our]446-our acquaintance]445-half the marriageable young ladies of our acquaintance to [the house]244-the house , for [his]154-my brother especial benefit .

[Ralph]39-ralph had never shown much fondness at [home]176-home , for the refinements of [good female society]449-good female society . Abroad , [he]154-my brother had lived as exclusively as [he]154-my brother possibly could , among [women whose characters ranged downwards by infinitesimal degrees]450-women whose characters ranged downwards by infinitesimal degrees , from the mysteriously doubtful to the notoriously bad . [The highly - bred , highly - refined , highly - accomplished young English beauties]451-the highly - bred , highly - refined , highly - accomplished young english beauties had no charm for [him]154-my brother . [He]154-my brother detected at once the domestic conspiracy of which [he]154-my brother was destined to become [the victim]452-the victim . [He]154-my brother often came up - stairs , at night , into [[my]0-i bed - room]453-my bed - room ; and while [he]154-my brother was amusing [himself]154-my brother by derisively kicking about [my]0-i simple clothes and simple toilette apparatus ; while [he]154-my brother was laughing in [his]154-my brother old careless way at [my]0-i quiet habits and monotonous life , used to slip in , parenthetically , all sorts of sarcasms about [[our]454-our young lady guests]455-our young lady guests . To [him]154-my brother , [their]455-our young lady guests manners were horribly inanimate ; [their]455-our young lady guests innocence , hypocrisy of education . Pure complexions and regular features were very well , [he]154-my brother said , as far as they went ; but when [a girl]456-a girl could not walk properly , when [she]456-a girl shook hands with [you]457-you with cold fingers , when having good eyes [she]456-a girl could not make a stimulating use of them , then it was time to sentence the regular features and pure complexions to be taken back forthwith to [the nursery from which [they]455-our young lady guests came]458-the nursery from which they came . For [his]154-my brother part , [he]154-my brother missed the conversation of [[his]154-my brother witty Polish Countess]459-his witty polish countess , and longed for another pancake - supper with [his]154-my brother favourite grisettes .

The failure of [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's last experiment with [Ralph]39-ralph soon became apparent . [Watchful and experienced mothers]461-watchful and experienced mothers began to suspect that [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's method of flirtation was dangerous , and [his]154-my brother style of waltzing improper . [One or two ultra - cautious parents]463-one or two ultra - cautious parents , alarmed by the laxity of [his]154-my brother manners and opinions , removed [[their]463-one or two ultra - cautious parents daughters]464-their daughters out of harm 's way , by shortening [their]464-their daughters visits . [The rest]465-the rest were spared any such necessity . [[My]0-i father]147-my father suddenly discovered that [Ralph]39-ralph was devoting [himself]39-ralph rather too significantly to [a young married woman who was staying in [the house]244-the house]467-a young married woman who was staying in the house . The same day [he]154-my brother had a long private interview with [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother . What passed between [them]470-them , [I]0-i know not ; but it must have been something serious . [Ralph]39-ralph came out of [[[my]0-i father]147-my father 's private study]472-my father 's private study , very pale and very silent ; ordered [his]154-my brother luggage to be packed directly ; and the next morning departed , with [[his]154-my brother French valet]473-his french valet , and [his]154-my brother multifarious French goods and chattels , for [the continent]339-the continent .

Another interval passed ; and then [we]475-we had another short visit from [him]154-my brother . [He]154-my brother was still unaltered . [[My]0-i father]147-my father 's temper suffered under this second disappointment . [He]154-my brother became more fretful and silent ; more apt to take offence than had been [his]154-my brother wo nt . [I]0-i particularly mention the change thus produced in [his]154-my brother disposition , because that change was destined , at no very distant period , to act fatally upon [me]0-i .

On this last occasion , also , there was another serious disagreement between [father]477-father and [son]478-son ; and [Ralph]39-ralph left [England]1-england again in much the same way that [he]154-my brother had left [it]1-england before .

Shortly after that second departure , [we]475-we heard that [he]154-my brother had altered [his]154-my brother manner of life . [He]154-my brother had contracted , what would be termed in the continental code of morals , a reformatory attachment to [a woman older than [himself]154-my brother , who was living separated from [[her]479-a woman older than himself , who was living separated from her husband , when he met with her husband]480-her husband , when [he]154-my brother met with [her]479-a woman older than himself , who was living separated from her husband , when he met with her]479-a woman older than himself , who was living separated from her husband , when he met with her . It was [this lady]481-this lady 's lofty ambition to be [Mentor]482-mentor and [mistress]483-mistress , both together ! And [she]481-this lady soon proved [herself]481-this lady to be well qualified for [her]481-this lady courageous undertaking . To the astonishment of [everyone who knew [him]154-my brother]484-everyone who knew him , [Ralph]39-ralph suddenly turned economical ; and , soon afterwards , actually resigned [his]154-my brother post at [the embassy]485-the embassy , to be out of the way of temptation ! Since that , [he]154-my brother has returned to [England]1-england ; has devoted [himself]154-my brother to collecting snuff - boxes and learning the violin ; and is now living quietly in [the suburbs of [London]10-london]486-the suburbs of london , still under the inspection of [the resolute female missionary who first worked [his]154-my brother reform]487-the resolute female missionary who first worked his reform .

Whether [he]154-my brother will ever become [the high - minded , high - principled country gentleman]488-the high - minded , high - principled country gentleman , that [[my]0-i father]147-my father has always desired to see [him]154-my brother , it is useless for [me]0-i to guess . On the domains which [he]154-my brother is to inherit , [I]0-i shall never perhaps set foot again : in [the halls where [he]154-my brother will one day preside as [master]491-master]490-the halls where he will one day preside as master , [I]0-i shall never more be sheltered . Let [me]0-i now quit the subject of [[my]0-i elder brother]149-my elder brother , and turn to a theme which is nearer to [my]0-i heart ; dear to [me]0-i as the last remembrance left that [I]0-i can love ; precious beyond all treasures in [my]0-i solitude and [my]0-i exile from [home]176-home .

[[My]0-i sister]296-my sister ! - well may [I]0-i linger over [your]296-my sister beloved name in such a record as this . A little farther on , and the darkness of crime and grief will encompass [me]0-i ; here , [my]0-i recollections of [you]296-my sister kindle like a pure light before [my]0-i eyes - doubly pure by contrast with what lies beyond . May [your]296-my sister kind eyes , love , be the first that fall on these pages , when [the writer]495-the writer has parted from them for ever ! May [your]296-my sister tender hand be the first that touches these leaves , when mine is cold ! Backward in [my]0-i narrative , [Clara]57-clara , wherever [I]0-i have but casually mentioned [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , the pen has trembled and stood still . At this place , where all [my]0-i remembrances of [you]296-my sister throng upon [me]0-i unrestrained , the tears gather fast and thick beyond control ; and for the first time since [I]0-i began [my]0-i task , [my]0-i courage and [my]0-i calmness fail [me]0-i .

It is useless to persevere longer . [My]0-i hand trembles ; [my]0-i eyes grow dimmer and dimmer . [I]0-i must close [my]0-i labours for the day , and go forth to gather strength and resolution for to - morrow on [the hill - tops that overlook [the sea]498-the sea]497-the hill - tops that overlook the sea .

V.

[[My]0-i sister]296-my sister [Clara]57-clara is four years younger than [I]0-i am . In form of face , in complexion , and - except the eyes - in features , [she]57-clara bears a striking resemblance to [[my]0-i father]147-my father . [Her]57-clara expressions however , must be very like what [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother 's was . Whenever [I]0-i have looked at [her]57-clara in [her]57-clara silent and thoughtful moments , [she]57-clara has always appeared to freshen , and even to increase , [my]0-i vague , childish recollections of [[our]502-our lost mother]503-our lost mother . [Her]57-clara eyes have that slight tinge of melancholy in their tenderness , and that peculiar softness in their repose , which is only seen in blue eyes . [Her]57-clara complexion , pale as [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's when [she]57-clara is neither speaking nor moving , has in a far greater degree than [his]147-my father the tendency to flush , not merely in moments of agitation , but even when [she]57-clara is walking , or talking on any subject that interests [her]57-clara . Without this peculiarity [her]57-clara paleness would be a defect . With it , the absence of any colour in [her]57-clara complexion but the fugitive uncertain colour which [I]0-i have described , would to some eyes debar [her]57-clara from any claims to beauty . And a beauty perhaps [she]57-clara is not - at least , in the ordinary acceptation of the term .

The lower part of [her]57-clara face is rather too small for the upper , [her]57-clara figure is too slight , the sensitiveness of [her]57-clara nervous organization is too constantly visible in [her]57-clara actions and [her]57-clara looks . [She]57-clara would not fix attention and admiration in a box at [the opera]505-the opera ; [very few men passing [her]57-clara in [the street]163-the street]506-very few men passing her in the street would turn round to look after [her]57-clara ; [very few women]508-very few women would regard [her]57-clara with that slightingly attentive stare , that steady depreciating scrutiny , which [a dashing decided beauty]509-a dashing decided beauty so often receives and so often triumphs in receiving from [her]57-clara personal inferiors among [her]57-clara own sex . The greatest charms that [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister has on the surface , come from beneath it .

When [you]511-you really knew [her]57-clara , when [she]57-clara spoke to [you]511-you freely , as to [a friend]512-a friend - then , the attraction of [her]57-clara voice , [her]57-clara smile [her]57-clara manner , impressed [you]511-you indescribably . [Her]57-clara slightest words and [her]57-clara commonest actions interested and delighted [you]511-you , [you]511-you knew not why . There was a beauty about [her]57-clara unassuming simplicity , [her]57-clara natural - exquisitely natural - kindness of heart , and word , and manner , which preserved its own unobtrusive influence over [you]511-you , in spite of all other rival influences , be [they]513-they what [they]513-they might . [You]511-you missed and thought of [her]57-clara , when [you]511-you were fresh from the society of [the most beautiful and the most brilliant women]514-the most beautiful and the most brilliant women . [You]511-you remembered a few kind , pleasant words of [hers]57-clara when [you]511-you forgot the wit of [the wittiest ladies , the learning of the most learned]515-the wittiest ladies , the learning of the most learned . The influence thus possessed , and unconsciously possessed , by [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister over [every one with whom [she]57-clara came in contact]517-every one with whom she came in contact - over [men]518-men especially - may , [I]0-i think be very simply accounted for , in very few sentences .

[We]519-we live in an age when [too many women]520-too many women appear to be ambitious of morally unsexing [themselves]520-too many women before society , by aping the language and the manners of [men]518-men - especially in reference to that miserable modern dandyism of demeanour , which aims at repressing all betrayal of warmth of feeling ; which abstains from displaying any enthusiasm on any subject whatever ; which , in short , labours to make the fashionable imperturbability of the face the faithful reflection of the fashionable imperturbability of the mind . [Women of this exclusively modern order]522-women of this exclusively modern order , like to use slang expressions in [their]522-women of this exclusively modern order conversation ; assume a bastard - masculine abruptness in [their]522-women of this exclusively modern order manners , a bastard - masculine licence in [their]522-women of this exclusively modern order opinions ; affect to ridicule those outward developments of feeling which pass under the general appellation of ' sentiment . " Nothing impresses , agitates , amuses , or delights [them]522-women of this exclusively modern order in a hearty , natural , womanly way . Sympathy looks ironical , if [they]522-women of this exclusively modern order ever show it : love seems to be an affair of calculation , or mockery , or contemptuous sufferance , if [they]522-women of this exclusively modern order ever feel it .[523-women such as these]

To [women such as these]523-women such as these , [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister [Clara]57-clara presented as complete a contrast as could well be conceived . In this contrast lay the secret of [her]57-clara influence , of the voluntary tribute of love and admiration which followed [her]57-clara wherever [she]57-clara went .

[Few men]113-few men have not [their]113-few men secret moments of deep feeling - moments when , amid the wretched trivialities and hypocrisies of modern society , the image will present itself to [their]113-few men minds of [some woman]526-some woman , fresh , innocent , gentle , sincere ; [some woman whose emotions are still warm and impressible , whose affections and sympathies can still appear in]527-some woman whose emotions are still warm and impressible , whose affections and sympathies can still appear in [her]57-clara actions , and give the colour to [her]57-clara thoughts ; [some woman in whom [we]529-we could put as perfect faith and trust , as if [we]529-we were [children]139-children ; whom [we]529-we despair of finding near the hardening influences of [the world]158-the world]528-some woman in whom we could put as perfect faith and trust , as if we were children ; whom we despair of finding near the hardening influences of the world ; whom [we]529-we could scarcely venture to look for , except in [solitary places far away in [the country]370-the country]532-solitary places far away in the country ; in [little rural shrines]534-little rural shrines , shut up from society , among [woods and fields]535-woods and fields , and [lonesome boundary - hills]536-lonesome boundary - hills . When [any women]537-any women happen to realise , or nearly to realise , such an image as this , [they]537-any women possess that universal influence which [no rivalry]538-no rivalry can ever approach . On [them]537-any women really depends , and by then is really preserved , that claim upon the sincere respect and admiration of [men]518-men , on which the power of the whole sex is based - the power so often assumed by [the many]540-the many , so rarely possessed but by [the few]541-the few .

It was thus with [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister . Thus , wherever [she]296-my sister went , though without either the inclination , or the ambition to shine , [she]296-my sister eclipsed women who were [her]296-my sister superiors in beauty , in accomplishments , in brilliancy of manners and conversation - conquering by no other weapon than the purely feminine charm of everything [she]296-my sister said , and everything [she]296-my sister did .

But it was not amid the gaiety and grandeur of a [London]10-london season that [her]296-my sister character was displayed to the greatest advantage . It was when [she]296-my sister was living where [she]296-my sister loved to live , in [the old country - house]543-the old country - house , among [the old friends]544-the old friends and [old servants who would every one of [them]546-them]545-old servants who would every one of them have died a hundred deaths for [her]296-my sister sake , that [you]547-you could study and love [her]296-my sister best . Then , the charm there was in the mere presence of [the kind , gentle , happy young English girl]548-the kind , gentle , happy young english girl , who could enter into [everybody]361-everybody 's interests , and be grateful for [everybody]361-everybody 's love , possessed its best and brightest influence . At picnics , lawn - parties , little country gatherings of all sorts , [she]296-my sister was , in [her]296-my sister own quiet , natural manner , always the presiding spirit of general comfort and general friendship . Even the rigid laws of country punctilio relaxed before [her]296-my sister unaffected cheerfulness and irresistible good - nature . [She]296-my sister always contrived - [nobody]120-nobody ever knew how - to lure [the most formal people]552-the most formal people into forgetting [their]552-the most formal people formality , and becoming natural for the rest of the day . Even [a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire was not too much for [her]296-my sister . [She]296-my sister managed to make [him]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire feel at [his]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire ease , when [no one else]554-no one else would undertake the task ; [she]296-my sister could listen patiently to [his]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire confused speeches about dogs , horses , and the state of the crops , when other conversations were proceeding in which [she]296-my sister was really interested ; [she]296-my sister could receive any little grateful attention that [he]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire wished to pay [her]296-my sister - no matter how awkward or ill - timed - as [she]296-my sister received attentions from [any one else]555-any one else , with a manner which showed [she]296-my sister considered it as a favour granted to [her]296-my sister sex , not as a right accorded to it .

So , again , [she]296-my sister always succeeded in diminishing the long list of those pitiful affronts and offences , which play such important parts in the social drama of [country society]556-country society . [She]296-my sister was [a perfect Apostle - errant of the order of Reconciliation]557-a perfect apostle - errant of the order of reconciliation ; and wherever [she]296-my sister went , cast out [the devil Sulkiness]558-the devil sulkiness from all [[his]553-a heavy - headed , lumbering , silent country squire strongholds]559-his strongholds - [the lofty and the lowly alike]560-the lofty and the lowly alike . [[Our]561-our good rector]562-our good rector used to call [her]296-my sister [[his]562-our good rector Volunteer Curate]563-his volunteer curate ; and declare that [she]296-my sister preached by a timely word , or a persuasive look , the best practical sermons on the blessings of peace - making that were ever composed .

With all this untiring good - nature , with all this resolute industry in the task of making [every one happy whom [she]296-my sister approached]564-every one happy whom she approached , there was mingled some indescribable influence , which invariably preserved [her]296-my sister from the presumption , even of [the most presuming people]565-the most presuming people . [I]0-i never knew [anybody venturesome enough]566-anybody venturesome enough - either by word or look - to take a liberty with [her]296-my sister . There was something about [her]296-my sister which inspired respect as well as love . [[My]0-i father]147-my father , following the bent of [his]147-my father peculiar and favourite ideas , always thought it was the look of [her]296-my sister race in [her]296-my sister eyes , the ascendancy of [her]296-my sister race in [her]296-my sister manners . [I]0-i believe it to have proceeded from a simpler and a better cause . There is a goodness of heart , which carries the shield of its purity over the open hand of its kindness : and that goodness was [hers]296-my sister .

To [[my]0-i father]147-my father , [she]296-my sister was more , [I]0-i believe , than [he]147-my father [himself]147-my father ever imagined - or will ever know , unless [he]147-my father should lose [her]296-my sister . [He]147-my father was often , in [his]147-my father intercourse with [the world]158-the world , wounded severely enough in [his]147-my father peculiar prejudices and peculiar refinements - [he]147-my father was always sure to find [the first respected]570-the first respected , and the last partaken by [her]296-my sister . [He]147-my father could trust in [her]296-my sister implicitly , [he]147-my father could feel assured that [she]296-my sister was not only willing , but able , to share and relieve [his]147-my father domestic troubles and anxieties . If [he]147-my father had been less fretfully anxious about [[his]147-my father eldest son]571-his eldest son ; if [he]147-my father had wisely distrusted from the first [his]147-my father own powers of persuading and reforming , and had allowed [Clara]57-clara to exercise [her]57-clara influence over [Ralph]39-ralph more constantly and more completely than [he]147-my father really did , [I]0-i am persuaded that the long - expected epoch of [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's transformation would have really arrived by this time , or even before it .

The strong and deep feelings of [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister 's nature lay far below the surface - for [a woman]325-a woman , too far below it . Suffering was , for [her]296-my sister , silent , secret , long enduring ; often almost entirely void of outward vent or development . [I]0-i never remember seeing [her]296-my sister in tears , except on rare and very serious occasions . Unless [you]575-you looked at [her]296-my sister narrowly , [you]575-you would judge [her]296-my sister to be little sensitive to ordinary griefs and troubles . At such times , [her]296-my sister eyes only grew dimmer and less animated than usual ; the paleness of [her]296-my sister complexion became rather more marked ; [her]296-my sister lips closed and trembled involuntarily - but this was all : there was no sighing , no weeping , no speaking even . And yet [she]296-my sister suffered acutely . The very strength of [her]296-my sister emotions was in [their]576-their silence and [their]576-their secresy . [I]0-i , of all others - [I]0-i , guilty of infecting with [my]0-i anguish the pure heart that loved [me]0-i - ought to know this best !

How long [I]0-i might linger over all that [she]296-my sister has done for [me]0-i ! As [I]0-i now approach nearer and nearer to the pages which are to reveal [my]0-i fatal story , so [I]0-i am more and more tempted to delay over those better and purer remembrances of [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister which now occupy [my]0-i mind . The first little presents - innocent girlish presents - which [she]296-my sister secretly sent to [me]0-i at [school]344-school ; the first sweet days of [our]579-our uninterrupted intercourse , when the close of [my]0-i college life restored [me]0-i to [home]176-home ; [her]296-my sister first inestimable sympathies with [my]0-i first fugitive vanities of embryo authorship , are thronging back fast and fondly on [my]0-i thoughts , while [I]0-i now write .

But these memories must be calmed and disciplined . [I]0-i must be collected and impartial over [my]0-i narrative - if it be only to make that narrative show fairly and truly , without suppression or exaggeration , all that [I]0-i have owed to [her]296-my sister .

Not merely all that [I]0-i have owed to [her]296-my sister ; but all that [I]0-i owe to [her]296-my sister now . Though [I]0-i may never see [her]296-my sister again , but in [my]0-i thoughts ; still [she]296-my sister influences , comforts , cheers [me]0-i on to hope , as if [she]296-my sister were already [the guardian spirit of [the cottage where [I]0-i live]582-the cottage where i live]581-the guardian spirit of the cottage where i live . Even in [my]0-i worst moments of despair , [I]0-i can still remember that [Clara]57-clara is thinking of [me]0-i and sorrowing for [me]0-i : [I]0-i can still feel that remembrance , as an invisible hand of mercy which supports [me]0-i , sinking ; which raises [me]0-i , fallen ; which may yet lead [me]0-i safely and tenderly to [my]0-i hard journey 's end .

VI .

[I]0-i have now completed all the preliminary notices of [[my]0-i near relatives]583-my near relatives , which it is necessary to present in these pages ; and may proceed at once to the more immediate subject of [my]0-i narrative .

Imagine to [yourself]584-yourself that [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister have been living for some months at [[our]587-our [London]10-london residence]588-our london residence ; and that [I]0-i have recently joined [them]589-them , after having enjoyed a short tour on [the continent]339-the continent .

[[My]0-i father]147-my father is engaged in [his]147-my father parliamentary duties . [We]587-our see very little of [him]147-my father . [Committees]41-committees absorb [his]147-my father mornings - debates [his]147-my father evenings . When [he]147-my father has a day of leisure occasionally , [he]147-my father passes it in [[his]147-my father study]592-his study , devoted to [his]147-my father own affairs . [He]147-my father goes very little into society - a political dinner , or a scientific meeting are the only social relaxations that tempt [him]147-my father .

[[My]0-i sister]296-my sister leads a life which is not much in accordance with [her]296-my sister simple tastes . [She]296-my sister is wearied of balls , operas , flower - shows , and all other [London]10-london gaieties besides ; and heartily longs to be driving about [the green lanes]594-the green lanes again in [her]296-my sister own little poney - chaise , and distributing plum - cake prizes to [the good children at [the Rector 's Infant School]596-the rector 's infant school]595-the good children at the rector 's infant school . But [the female friend who happens to be staying with [her]296-my sister]597-the female friend who happens to be staying with her , is fond of excitement ; [[my]0-i father]147-my father expects [her]296-my sister to accept the invitations which [he]147-my father is obliged to decline ; so [she]296-my sister gives up [her]296-my sister own tastes and inclinations as usual , and goes into [hot rooms]599-hot rooms among [crowds of fine people]600-crowds of fine people , hearing the same glib compliments , and the same polite inquiries , night after night , until , patient as [she]296-my sister is , [she]296-my sister heartily wishes that [[her]296-my sister fashionable friends]601-her fashionable friends all lived in [some opposite quarter of the globe]602-some opposite quarter of the globe , the farther away the better .

[My]0-i arrival from [the continent]339-the continent is the most welcome of events to [her]296-my sister . It gives a new object and a new impulse to [her]296-my sister [London]10-london life .

[I]0-i am engaged in writing a historical romance - indeed , it is principally to examine [the localities in [the country where]605-the country where [my]0-i story is laid , that [I]0-i have been abroad]604-the localities in the country where my story is laid , that i have been abroad . [Clara]57-clara has read the first half - dozen finished chapters , in manuscript , and augurs wonderful success for [my]0-i fiction when it is published . [She]57-clara is determined to arrange [my]0-i study with [her]57-clara own hands ; to dust [my]0-i books , and sort [my]0-i papers [herself]57-clara .
