[She]57-clara knows that [I]0-i am already as fretful and precise about [my]0-i literary goods and chattels , as indignant at any interference of [housemaids]606-housemaids and [dusters]607-dusters with [my]0-i library treasures , as if [I]0-i were [a veteran author of twenty years]608-a veteran author of twenty years ' standing ; and [she]57-clara is resolved to spare [me]0-i every apprehension on this score , by taking all the arrangements of [[my]0-i study]609-my study on [herself]57-clara , and keeping the key of the door when [I]0-i am not in need of it .

[We]610-our have [[our]610-our [London]10-london amusements]611-our london amusements , too , as well as [[our]610-our [London]10-london employments]612-our london employments . But the pleasantest of [our]610-our relaxations are , after all , procured for [us]610-our by [our]610-our horses . [We]610-our ride every day - sometimes with [friends]440-friends , sometimes alone together . On these latter occasions , [we]610-our generally turn [our]610-our horses ' heads away from [the parks]614-the parks , and seek what country sights [we]610-our can get in [the neighbourhood of [London]10-london]615-the neighbourhood of london . [The northern roads]616-the northern roads are generally [our]610-our favourite ride .

Sometimes [we]610-our penetrate so far that [we]610-our can bait [our]610-our horses at [a little inn]617-a little inn which reminds [me]0-i of [the inns near [[our]610-our country home]619-our country home]618-the inns near our country home . [I]0-i see [the same sanded parlour]620-the same sanded parlour , decorated with the same old sporting prints , furnished with the same battered , deep - coloured mahogany table , and polished elm tree chairs , that [I]0-i remember in [[our]610-our own village inn]621-our own village inn . [Clara]57-clara , also , finds bits of common , out of doors , that look like [our]610-our common ; and trees that might have been transplanted expressly for [her]57-clara , from [[our]610-our park]622-our park .

These excursions [we]610-our keep a secret , [we]610-our like to enjoy them entirely by [ourselves]610-our . Besides , if [[my]0-i father]147-my father knew that [[his]147-my father daughter]233-his daughter was drinking [the landlady]625-the landlady 's fresh milk , and [[his]147-my father son]412-his son [the landlord]627-the landlord 's old ale , in [the parlour of [a suburban roadside inn]629-a suburban roadside inn]628-the parlour of a suburban roadside inn , [he]147-my father would , [I]0-i believe , be apt to suspect that both [[his]147-my father children]278-his children had fairly taken leave of [their]278-his children senses .

Evening parties [I]0-i frequent almost as rarely as [[my]0-i father]147-my father . [Clara]57-clara 's good nature is called into requisition to do duty for [me]0-i , as well as for [him]147-my father . [She]57-clara has little respite in the task . [Old lady relatives]632-old lady relatives and [friends]440-friends , always ready to take care of [her]57-clara , leave [her]57-clara no excuse for staying at [home]176-home . Sometimes [I]0-i am shamed into accompanying [her]57-clara a little more frequently than usual ; but [my]0-i old indolence in these matters soon possesses [me]0-i again . [I]0-i have contracted a bad habit of writing at night - [I]0-i read almost incessantly in the day time . It is only because [I]0-i am fond of riding , that [I]0-i am ever willing to interrupt [my]0-i studies , and ever ready to go out at all .

Such were [my]0-i domestic habits , such [my]0-i regular occupations and amusements , when a mere accident changed every purpose of [my]0-i life , and altered [me]0-i irretrievably from what [I]0-i was then , to what [I]0-i am now .

It happened thus :

VII .

[I]0-i had just received [my]0-i quarter 's allowance of pocket - money , and had gone into [the city]635-the city to cash the cheque at [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's bankers .

The money paid , [I]0-i debated for a moment how [I]0-i should return homewards . First [I]0-i thought of walking : then of taking [a cab]637-a cab . While [I]0-i was considering this frivolous point , [an omnibus]638-an omnibus passed [me]0-i , going westward . In the idle impulse of the moment , [I]0-i hailed it , and got in .

It was something more than an idle impulse though . If [I]0-i had at that time no other qualification for the literary career on which [I]0-i was entering , [I]0-i certainly had this one - an aptitude for discovering points of character in others : and its natural result , an unfailing delight in studying [characters of all kinds]639-characters of all kinds , wherever [I]0-i could meet with [them]639-characters of all kinds .

[I]0-i had often before ridden in omnibuses to amuse [myself]0-i by observing [the passengers]640-the passengers . [An omnibus]638-an omnibus has always appeared to [me]0-i , to be a perambulatory exhibition - room of the eccentricities of human nature . [I]0-i know not any other sphere in which [persons of all classes and all temperaments]642-persons of all classes and all temperaments are so oddly collected together , and so immediately contrasted and confronted with each other . To watch merely the different methods of getting into [the vehicle]643-the vehicle , and taking [their]639-characters of all kinds seats , adopted by [different people]644-different people , is to study no incomplete commentary on the infinitesimal varieties of human character - as various even as the varieties of the human face .

Thus , in addition to the idle impulse , there was the idea of amusement in [my]0-i thoughts , as [I]0-i stopped [the public vehicle]645-the public vehicle , and added one to the number of [[the conductor]646-the conductor 's passengers]647-the conductor 's passengers .

There were five persons in [the omnibus]648-the omnibus when [I]0-i entered [it]648-the omnibus . [Two middle - aged ladies]649-two middle - aged ladies , dressed with amazing splendour in silks and satins , wearing straw - coloured kid gloves , and carrying highly - scented pocket handkerchiefs , sat apart at the end of [the vehicle]643-the vehicle ; trying to look as if [they]649-two middle - aged ladies occupied [it]643-the vehicle under protest , and preserving the most stately gravity and silence . [They]649-two middle - aged ladies evidently felt that [their]649-two middle - aged ladies magnificent outward adornments were exhibited in a very unworthy locality , and among a very uncongenial company .

One side , close to the door , was occupied by [a lean , withered old man]651-a lean , withered old man , very shabbily dressed in black , who sat eternally mumbling something between [his]651-a lean , withered old man toothless jaws . Occasionally , to the evident disgust of [the genteel ladies]652-the genteel ladies , [he]651-a lean , withered old man wiped [his]651-a lean , withered old man bald head and wrinkled forehead with a ragged blue cotton handkerchief , which [he]651-a lean , withered old man kept in the crown of [his]651-a lean , withered old man hat .

Opposite to [this ancient]653-this ancient sat [a dignified gentleman]654-a dignified gentleman and [a sickly vacant - looking little girl]655-a sickly vacant - looking little girl . Every event of that day is so indelibly marked on [my]0-i memory , that [I]0-i remember , not only [this man]656-this man 's pompous look and manner , but even the words [he]656-this man addressed to [the poor squalid little creature by [his]656-this man side]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side . When [I]0-i entered [the omnibus]648-the omnibus , [he]656-this man was telling [her]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side in a loud voice how [she]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side ought to dispose of [her]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side frock and [her]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side feet when [people]106-people got into [the vehicle]643-the vehicle , and when [they]106-people got out . [He]656-this man then impressed on [her]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side the necessity in future life , when [she]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side grew up , of always having the price of [her]657-the poor squalid little creature by his side fare ready before it was wanted , to prevent unnecessary delay . Having delivered [himself]656-this man of this good advice , [he]656-this man began to hum , keeping time by drumming with [his]656-this man thick Malacca cane . [He]656-this man was still proceeding with this amusement - producing some of the most acutely unmusical sounds [I]0-i ever heard - when [the omnibus]648-the omnibus stopped to give admission to [two ladies]662-two ladies . [The first who got in]663-the first who got in was [an elderly person]664-an elderly person - pale and depressed - evidently in delicate health . [The second]665-the second was [a young girl]666-a young girl .

Among the workings of the hidden life within [us]667-we which [we]667-we may experience but can not explain , are there any more remarkable than those mysterious moral influences constantly exercised , either for attraction or repulsion , by [one human being]668-one human being over another ? In the simplest , as in the most important affairs of life , how startling , how irresistible is [their]669-their power ! How often [we]667-we feel and know , either pleasurably or painfully , that another is looking on [us]667-we , before [we]667-we have ascertained the fact with [our]667-we own eyes ! How often [we]667-we prophesy truly to [ourselves]667-we the approach of [a friend]512-a friend or [enemy]671-enemy , just before either have really appeared ! How strangely and abruptly [we]667-we become convinced , at a first introduction , that [we]667-we shall secretly love [this person]672-this person and loathe that , before experience has guided [us]667-we with a single fact in relation to [[their]669-their characters]673-their characters !

[I]0-i have said that [the two additional passengers who entered [the vehicle]643-the vehicle in which [I]0-i was riding]674-the two additional passengers who entered the vehicle in which i was riding , were , [one of [them]674-the two additional passengers who entered the vehicle in which i was riding]676-one of them , [an elderly lady]677-an elderly lady ; [the other]678-the other , [a young girl]666-a young girl . As soon as [the latter]680-the latter had seated [herself]680-the latter nearly opposite to [me]0-i , by [[her]680-the latter companion]681-her companion 's side , [I]0-i felt [her]680-the latter influence on [me]0-i directly - an influence that [I]0-i can not describe - an influence which [I]0-i had never experienced in [my]0-i life before , which [I]0-i shall never experience again .

[I]0-i had helped to hand [her]680-the latter in , as [she]680-the latter passed [me]0-i ; merely touching [her]680-the latter arm for a moment . But how the sense of that touch was prolonged ! [I]0-i felt it thrilling through [me]0-i - thrilling in every nerve , in every pulsation of [my]0-i fast - throbbing heart .

Had [I]0-i the same influence over [her]680-the latter ? Or was it [I]0-i that received , and [she]680-the latter that conferred , only ? [I]0-i was yet destined to discover ; but not then - not for a long , long time .

[Her]680-the latter veil was down when [I]0-i first saw [her]680-the latter . [Her]680-the latter features and [her]680-the latter expression were but indistinctly visible to [me]0-i . [I]0-i could just vaguely perceive that [she]680-the latter was young and beautiful ; but , beyond this , though [I]0-i might imagine much , [I]0-i could see little .

From the time when [she]680-the latter entered [the omnibus]648-the omnibus , [I]0-i have no recollection of anything more that occurred in it . [I]0-i neither remember what [passengers]683-passengers got out , or what [passengers]683-passengers got in . [My]0-i powers of observation , hitherto active enough , had now wholly deserted [me]0-i . Strange ! that the capricious rule of chance should sway the action of [our]685-our faculties that a trifle should set in motion the whole complicated machinery of [their]686-their exercise , and a trifle suspend it .

[We]685-our had been moving onward for some little time , when [[the girl]687-the girl 's companion]688-the girl 's companion addressed an observation to [her]687-the girl . [She]687-the girl heard it imperfectly , and lifted [her]687-the girl veil while it was being repeated . How painfully [my]0-i heart beat ! [I]0-i could almost hear it - as [her]687-the girl face was , for the first time , freely and fairly disclosed !

[She]687-the girl was dark . [Her]687-the girl hair , eyes , and complexion were darker than usual in [English women]689-english women . The form , the look altogether , of [her]687-the girl face , coupled with what [I]0-i could see of [her]687-the girl figure , made [me]0-i guess [her]687-the girl age to be about twenty . There was the appearance of maturity already in the shape of [her]687-the girl features ; but [their]690-their expression still remained girlish , unformed , unsettled . The fire in [her]687-the girl large dark eyes , when [she]687-the girl spoke , was latent . [Their]690-their languor , when [she]687-the girl was silent - that voluptuous languor of black eyes - was still fugitive and unsteady . The smile about [her]687-the girl full lips to other eyes , [they]690-their might have looked too full struggled to be eloquent , yet dared not . Among [women]326-women , there always seems something left incomplete - a moral creation to be superinduced on the physical - which love alone can develop , and which maternity perfects still further , when developed . [I]0-i thought , as [I]0-i looked on [her]687-the girl , how the passing colour would fix itself brilliantly on [her]687-the girl round , olive cheek ; how the expression that still hesitated to declare itself , would speak out at last , would shine forth in the full luxury of its beauty , when [she]687-the girl heard the first words , received the first kiss , from [the man [she]687-the girl loved]692-the man she loved !

While [I]0-i still looked at [her]687-the girl , as [she]687-the girl sat opposite speaking to [[her]687-the girl companion]681-her companion , [our]694-we eyes met . It was only for a moment - but the sensation of a moment often makes the thought of a life ; and that one little instant made the new life of [my]0-i heart . [She]687-the girl put down [her]687-the girl veil again immediately ; [her]687-the girl lips moved involuntarily as [she]687-the girl lowered it : [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could discern , through the lace , that the slight movement ripened to a smile .

Still there was enough left to see - enough to charm . There was the little rim of delicate white lace , encircling the lovely , dusky throat ; there was the figure visible , where the shawl had fallen open , slender , but already well developed in its slenderness , and exquisitely supple ; there was the waist , naturally low , and left to its natural place and natural size ; there were the little millinery and jewellery ornaments that [she]687-the girl wore - simple and common - place enough in themselves - yet each a beauty , each a treasure , on [her]687-the girl . There was all this to behold , all this to dwell on , in spite of the veil . The veil ! how little of [the woman]695-the woman does it hide , when [the man]696-the man really loves [her]687-the girl !

[We]694-we had nearly arrived at the last point to which [the omnibus]648-the omnibus would take [us]694-we , when [she]687-the girl and [[her]687-the girl companion]681-her companion got out . [I]0-i followed [them]699-they , cautiously and at some distance .

[She]687-the girl was tall - tall at least for [a woman]325-a woman . There were [not many people in [the road along which [we]694-we were proceeding]702-the road along which we were proceeding]701-not many people in the road along which we were proceeding ; but even if there had been , far behind as [I]0-i was walking , [I]0-i should never have lost [her]687-the girl - never have mistaken [any one else]555-any one else for [her]687-the girl . Already , strangers though [we]694-we were , [I]0-i felt that [I]0-i should know [her]687-the girl , almost at any distance , only by [her]687-the girl walk .

[They]699-they went on , until [we]694-we reached [a suburb of [new houses]705-new houses , intermingled with [wretched patches of waste land]706-wretched patches of waste land , half built over]704-a suburb of new houses , intermingled with wretched patches of waste land , half built over . [Unfinished streets]707-unfinished streets , [unfinished crescents]708-unfinished crescents , [unfinished squares]709-unfinished squares , [unfinished shops]710-unfinished shops , [unfinished gardens]711-unfinished gardens , surrounded [us]694-we . At last [they]699-they stopped at [a new square]712-a new square , and rang the bell at one of [the newest of [the new houses]714-the new houses]713-the newest of the new houses . The door was opened , and [she]687-the girl and [[her]687-the girl companion]681-her companion disappeared . [The house]244-the house was partly detached . [It]244-the house bore no number ; but was distinguished as [North Villa]11-north villa . [The square]717-the square - unfinished like everything else in [the neighbourhood]718-the neighbourhood - was called [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square .

[I]0-i noticed nothing else about [the place]435-the place at that time . [Its]435-the place newness and desolateness of appearance revolted [me]0-i , just then . [I]0-i had satisfied [myself]0-i about [the locality of [the house]244-the house]720-the locality of the house , and [I]0-i knew that it was [[her]687-the girl home]722-her home ; for [I]0-i had approached sufficiently near , when the door was opened , to hear [her]687-the girl inquire if [anybody]723-anybody had called in [her]687-the girl absence . For the present , this was enough . [My]0-i sensations wanted repose ; [my]0-i thoughts wanted collecting . [I]0-i left [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square at once , and walked into [the Regent 's Park]724-the regent 's park , the northern portion of which was close at hand .

Was [I]0-i in love ? - in love with [a girl whom [I]0-i had accidentally met in an omnibus]725-a girl whom i had accidentally met in an omnibus ? Or , was [I]0-i merely indulging a momentary caprice - merely feeling [a young man]293-a young man 's hot , hasty admiration for a beautiful face ? These were questions which [I]0-i could not then decide . [My]0-i ideas were in utter confusion , all [my]0-i thoughts ran astray . [I]0-i walked on , dreaming in full day - [I]0-i had no distinct impressions , except of [the stranger beauty whom [I]0-i had just seen]727-the stranger beauty whom i had just seen . The more [I]0-i tried to collect [myself]0-i , to resume the easy , equable feelings with which [I]0-i had set forth in the morning , the less self - possessed [I]0-i became . There are two emergencies in which [the wisest man]728-the wisest man may try to reason [himself]728-the wisest man back from impulse to principle ; and try in vain : - the one when [a woman]325-a woman has attracted [him]728-the wisest man for the first time ; the other , when , for the first time , also , [she]325-a woman has happened to offend [him]728-the wisest man .

[I]0-i know not how long [I]0-i had been walking in [the park]730-the park , thus absorbed yet not thinking , when the clock of [a neighbouring church]731-a neighbouring church struck three , and roused [me]0-i to the remembrance that [I]0-i had engaged to ride out with [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister at two o'clock . It would be nearly half - an - hour more before [I]0-i could reach [home]176-home . Never had [any former appointment of [mine]0-i with [Clara]57-clara]734-any former appointment of mine with clara been thus forgotten ! Love had not yet turned [me]0-i selfish , as it turns [all men]735-all men , and even [all women]736-all women , more or less . [I]0-i felt both sorrow and shame at the neglect of which [I]0-i had been guilty ; and hastened [homeward]737-homeward .

[The groom]738-the groom , looking unutterably weary and discontented , was still leading [my]0-i horse up and down before [the house]244-the house . [[My]0-i sister]296-my sister 's horse had been sent back to [the stables]741-the stables . [I]0-i went in ; and heard that , after waiting for [me]0-i an hour , [Clara]57-clara had gone out with [some friends]742-some friends , and would not be back before dinner .

[No one]743-no one was in [the house]244-the house but [the servants]745-the servants . [The place]435-the place looked dull , empty , inexpressibly miserable to [me]0-i ; the distant roll of carriages along [the surrounding streets]747-the surrounding streets had a heavy boding sound ; the opening and shutting of doors in [the domestic offices below]748-the domestic offices below , startled and irritated [me]0-i ; the [London]10-london air seemed denser to breathe than it had ever seemed before . [I]0-i walked up and down [one of [the rooms]750-the rooms]749-one of the rooms , fretful and irresolute . Once [I]0-i directed [my]0-i steps towards [[my]0-i study]609-my study ; but retraced them before [I]0-i had entered [it]609-my study . Reading or writing was out of the question at that moment .

[I]0-i felt the secret inclination strengthening within [me]0-i to return to [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square ; to try to see [the girl]687-the girl again , or at least to ascertain who [she]687-the girl was . [I]0-i strove - yes , [I]0-i can honestly say , strove to repress the desire . [I]0-i tried to laugh it off , as idle and ridiculous ; to think of [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , of the book [I]0-i was writing , of anything but the one subject that pressed stronger and stronger on [me]0-i , the harder [I]0-i struggled against it . The spell of the syren was over [me]0-i . [I]0-i went out , hypocritically persuading [myself]0-i , that [I]0-i was only animated by a capricious curiosity to know [the girl]687-the girl 's name , which once satisfied , would leave [me]0-i at rest on the matter , and free to laugh at [my]0-i own idleness and folly as soon as [I]0-i got [home]176-home again .

[I]0-i arrived at [the house]244-the house . The blinds were all drawn down over the front windows , to keep out the sun . The little slip of [garden]757-garden was left solitary - baking and cracking in the heat . [The square]717-the square was silent ; desolately silent , as only [a suburban square]759-a suburban square can be . [I]0-i walked up and down [the glaring pavement]760-the glaring pavement , resolved to find out [her]687-the girl name before [I]0-i quitted [the place]435-the place . While still undecided how to act , a shrill whistling - sounding doubly shrill in the silence around - made [me]0-i look up .

[[A tradesman]762-a tradesman 's boy]763-a tradesman 's boy - [one of [those town Pucks of [the highway]766-the highway]765-those town pucks of the highway]764-one of those town pucks of the highway ; one of those incarnations of precocious cunning , inveterate mischief , and impudent humour , which great cities only can produce - was approaching [me]0-i with [his]763-a tradesman 's boy empty tray under [his]763-a tradesman 's boy arm . [I]0-i called to [him]763-a tradesman 's boy to come and speak to [me]0-i . [He]763-a tradesman 's boy evidently belonged to [the neighbourhood]718-the neighbourhood , and might be made of some use .

[His]763-a tradesman 's boy first answer to [my]0-i inquiries , showed that [[his]763-a tradesman 's boy master]768-his master served [the household at [North Villa]11-north villa]769-the household at north villa . A present of a shilling secured [his]763-a tradesman 's boy attention at once to the few questions of any importance which [I]0-i desired to put to [him]763-a tradesman 's boy . [I]0-i learned from [his]763-a tradesman 's boy replies , that the name of [the master of [the house]244-the house]770-the master of the house was " [Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin : "[770-the master of the house] and that [the family]179-the family only consisted of [Mr.]773-mr. and [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin , and [the young lady]774-the young lady , [[their]775-their daughter]776-their daughter .

[My]0-i last inquiry addressed to [the boy]777-the boy was the most important of all . Did [he]777-the boy know what [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's profession or employment was ?

[His]777-the boy answer startled [me]0-i into perfect silence . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin kept [a large linen - draper 's shop]778-a large linen - draper 's shop in [one of [the great [London]10-london thoroughfares]780-the great london thoroughfares]779-one of the great london thoroughfares ! [The boy]777-the boy mentioned the number , and the side of the way on which [the house]244-the house stood - then asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i wanted to know anything more . [I]0-i could only tell [him]777-the boy by a sign that [he]777-the boy might leave [me]0-i , and that [I]0-i had heard enough .

Enough ? If [he]777-the boy had spoken the truth , [I]0-i had heard too much .

[[A linen - draper]783-a linen - draper 's shop]784-a linen - draper 's shop - [[a linen - draper]783-a linen - draper 's daughter]786-a linen - draper 's daughter ! Was [I]0-i still in love ? - [I]0-i thought of [[my]0-i father]147-my father ; [I]0-i thought of the name [I]0-i bore ; and this time , though [I]0-i might have answered the question , [I]0-i dared not .

But [the boy]777-the boy might be wrong . Perhaps , in mere mischief , [he]777-the boy had been deceiving [me]0-i throughout . [I]0-i determined to seek the address [he]777-the boy had mentioned , and ascertain the truth for [myself]0-i .

[I]0-i reached [the place]435-the place : there was [the shop]790-the shop , and there the name " [Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin "[777-the boy] over the door . One chance still remained . [This Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin and [the Sherwin of [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square]791-the sherwin of hollyoake square might not be the same .

[I]0-i went in and purchased something . While [the man]696-the man was tying up the parcel , [I]0-i asked [him]696-the man whether [[his]696-the man master]768-his master lived in [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square . Looking a little astonished at the question , [he]696-the man answered in the affirmative .

" There was [a Mr. Sherwin [I]0-i once knew]3041-a mr. sherwin i once knew , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , forging in those words the first link in the long chain of deceit which was afterwards to fetter and degrade [me]0-i - " [a Mr. Sherwin who is now , as [I]0-i have heard , living somewhere in [the Hollyoake Square neighbourhood]3042-the hollyoake square neighbourhood]42-mr. sherwin . [He]42-mr. sherwin was [a bachelor]3043-a bachelor - [I]0-i do n't know whether [[my]0-i friend]3044-my friend and [[your]696-the man master]3045-your master are the same ? "[0-i]

" Oh dear no , [Sir]3046-sir ! [[My]696-the man master]3047-my master is [a married man]3048-a married man , and has [one daughter]3049-one daughter - [Miss Margaret]44-margaret - who is reckoned [a very fine young lady]3050-a very fine young lady , [Sir]3046-sir ! "[696-the man] And [the man]696-the man grinned as [he]696-the man spoke - a grin that sickened and shocked [me]0-i .

[I]0-i was answered at last : [I]0-i had discovered all . [Margaret]44-margaret ! - [I]0-i had heard [her]44-margaret name , too . [Margaret]44-margaret ! - it had never hitherto been a favourite name with [me]0-i . Now [I]0-i felt a sort of terror as [I]0-i detected [myself]0-i repeating it , and finding a new , unimagined poetry in the sound .

Could this be love ? - pure , first love for [[a shopkeeper]795-a shopkeeper 's daughter]796-a shopkeeper 's daughter , whom [I]0-i had seen for a quarter of an hour in an omnibus , and followed [home]176-home for another quarter of an hour ? The thing was impossible . And yet , [I]0-i felt a strange unwillingness to go back to [[our]798-our house]129-our house , and see [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [sister]155-sister , just at that moment .

[I]0-i was still walking onward slowly , but not in the direction of [home]176-home , when [I]0-i met [an old college friend of [[my]0-i brother]154-my brother 's]803-an old college friend of my brother 's , and [an acquaintance of mine]805-an acquaintance of mine - [a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow . [He]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow greeted [me]0-i at once , with uproarious cordiality ; and insisted on [my]0-i accompanying [him]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow to dine at [[his]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow club]807-his club .

If the thoughts that still hung heavy on [my]0-i mind were only the morbid , fanciful thoughts of the hour , here was [a man whose society would dissipate them]808-a man whose society would dissipate them . [I]0-i resolved to try the experiment , and accepted [his]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow invitation .

At dinner , [I]0-i tried hard to rival [him]806-a reckless , good - humoured , convivial fellow in jest and joviality ; [I]0-i drank much more than [my]0-i usual quantity of wine - but it was useless . The gay words came fainting from [my]0-i heart , and fell dead on [my]0-i lips . The wine fevered , but did not exhilarate [me]0-i . Still , the image of the dark beauty of the morning was the one reigning image of [my]0-i thoughts - still , the influence of the morning , at once sinister and seductive , kept its hold on [my]0-i heart .

[I]0-i gave up the struggle . [I]0-i longed to be alone again . [[My]0-i friend]3044-my friend soon found that [my]0-i forced spirits were flagging ; [he]3044-my friend tried to rouse [me]0-i , tried to talk for two , ordered more wine , but everything failed . Yawning at last , in undisguised despair , [he]3044-my friend suggested a visit to [the theatre]810-the theatre .

[I]0-i excused [myself]0-i - professed illness - hinted that the wine had been too much for [me]0-i . [He]3044-my friend laughed , with something of contempt as well as good - nature in the laugh ; and went away to the play by [himself]3044-my friend evidently feeling that [I]0-i was still as bad a companion as [he]3044-my friend had found [me]0-i at college , years ago .

As soon as [we]811-we parted [I]0-i felt a sense of relief . [I]0-i hesitated , walked backwards and forwards a few paces in [the street]163-the street ; and then , silencing all doubts , leaving [my]0-i inclinations to guide [me]0-i as they would - [I]0-i turned [my]0-i steps for the third time in that one day to [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square .

The fair summer evening was tending towards twilight ; the sun stood fiery and low in a cloudless horizon ; the last loveliness of the last quietest daylight hour was fading on the violet sky , as [I]0-i entered [the square]717-the square .

[I]0-i approached [the house]244-the house . [She]815-she was at the window - it was thrown wide open . A bird - cage hung rather high up , against the shutter - panel . [She]815-she was standing opposite to it , making a plaything for the poor captive canary of a piece of sugar , which [she]815-she rapidly offered and drew back again , now at [one bar of the cage]816-one bar of the cage , and now at another . The bird hopped and fluttered up and down in [[his]3044-my friend prison]817-his prison after the sugar , chirping as if [he]3044-my friend enjoyed playing [his]3044-my friend part of the game with [[his]3044-my friend mistress]818-his mistress . How lovely [she]815-she looked ! [Her]815-she dark hair , drawn back over each cheek so as just to leave the lower part of the ear visible , was gathered up into a thick simple knot behind , without ornament of any sort . [She]815-she wore a plain white dress fastening round the neck , and descending over the bosom in numberless little wavy plaits . The cage hung just high enough to oblige [her]815-she to look up to it . [She]815-she was laughing with all the glee of [a child]226-a child ; darting the piece of sugar about incessantly from place to place . Every moment , [her]815-she head and neck assumed some new and lovely turn - every moment [her]815-she figure naturally fell into the position which showed its pliant symmetry best . The last - left glow of the evening atmosphere was shining on [her]815-she - the farewell pause of daylight over the kindred daylight of beauty and youth .

[I]0-i kept [myself]0-i concealed behind a pillar of the garden - gate ; [I]0-i looked , hardly daring either to move or breathe ; for [I]0-i feared that if [she]815-she saw or heard [me]0-i , [she]815-she would leave the window . After a lapse of some minutes , the canary touched the sugar with [his]3044-my friend beak .

" There , [Minnie]45-minnie ! "[815-she] [she]815-she cried laughingly , " [you]45-minnie have caught the runaway sugar , and now [you]45-minnie shall keep it ! "[815-she]

For a moment more , [she]815-she stood quietly looking at the cage ; then raising [herself]815-she on tip - toe , pouted [her]815-she lips caressingly to the bird , and disappeared in the interior of [the room]263-the room .

The sun went down ; the twilight shadows fell over [the dreary square]821-the dreary square ; the gas lamps were lighted far and near ; [people who had been out for a breath of fresh air in the fields]822-people who had been out for a breath of fresh air in the fields , came straggling past [me]0-i by ones and twos , on [their]822-people who had been out for a breath of fresh air in the fields way [home]176-home - and still [I]0-i lingered near [the house]244-the house , hoping [she]815-she might come to the window again ; but [she]815-she did not re - appear . At last , [a servant]314-a servant brought candles into [the room]263-the room , and drew down the Venetian blinds . Knowing it would be useless to stay longer , [I]0-i left [the square]717-the square .

[I]0-i walked homeward joyfully . That second sight of [her]815-she completed what the first meeting had begun . The impressions left by it made [me]0-i insensible for the time to all boding reflections , careless of exercising the smallest self - restraint . [I]0-i gave [myself]0-i up to the charm that was at work on [me]0-i . Prudence , duty , memories and prejudices of [home]176-home , were all absorbed and forgotten in love - love that [I]0-i encouraged , that [I]0-i dwelt over in the first reckless luxury of a new sensation .

[I]0-i entered [[our]829-our house]129-our house , thinking of nothing but how to see [her]815-she , how to speak to [her]815-she , on the morrow ; murmuring [her]815-she name to [myself]0-i ; even while [my]0-i hand was on the lock of [my]0-i study door . The instant [I]0-i was in [the room]263-the room , [I]0-i involuntarily shuddered and stopped speechless . [Clara]57-clara was there ! [I]0-i was not merely startled ; a cold , faint sensation came over [me]0-i . [My]0-i first look at [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister made [me]0-i feel as if [I]0-i had been detected in a crime .

[She]815-she was standing at [my]0-i writing - table , and had just finished stringing together the loose pages of [my]0-i manuscript , which had hitherto laid disconnectedly in a drawer . There was a grand ball somewhere , to which [she]815-she was going that night . The dress [she]815-she wore was of pale blue crape [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's favourite colour , on [her]815-she . One white flower was placed in [her]815-she light brown hair . [She]815-she stood within the soft steady light of [my]0-i lamp , looking up towards the door from the leaves [she]815-she had just tied together . [Her]815-she slight figure appeared slighter than usual , in the delicate material that now clothed it . [Her]815-she complexion was at its palest : [her]815-she face looked almost statue - like in its purity and repose . What a contrast to the other living picture which [I]0-i had seen at sunset !

The remembrance of the engagement that [I]0-i had broken came back on [me]0-i avengingly , as [she]815-she smiled , and held [my]0-i manuscript up before [me]0-i to look at . With that remembrance there returned , too - darker than ever - the ominous doubts which had depressed [me]0-i but a few hours since . [I]0-i tried to steady [my]0-i voice , and felt how [I]0-i failed in the effort , as [I]0-i spoke to [her]815-she :

" Will [you]815-she forgive [me]0-i , [Clara]57-clara , for having deprived [you]815-she of [your]815-she ride to - day ? [I]0-i am afraid [I]0-i have but a bad excuse - "[0-i]

" Then do n't make it , [Basil]46-basil ; or wait till [papa]3052-papa can arrange it for [you]46-basil , in a proper parliamentary way , when [he]3052-papa comes back from [the House of Commons]3053-the house of commons to - night . See how [I]834-i have been meddling with [your]46-basil papers ; but they were in such confusion [I]834-i was really afraid some of these leaves might have been lost . "[834-i]

" Neither the leaves nor [the writer]495-the writer deserve half the pains [you]46-basil have taken with them ; but [I]0-i am really sorry for breaking [our]3055-our engagement . [I]0-i met [an old college friend]3056-an old college friend - there was business too , in the morning - [we]3055-our dined together - [he]3056-an old college friend would take no denial . "[0-i]

" [Basil]46-basil , how pale [you]46-basil look ! Are [you]46-basil ill ? "[834-i]

" No ; the heat has been a little too much for [me]0-i - nothing more . "[0-i]

" Has anything happened ? [I]834-i only ask , because if [I]834-i can be of any use - if [you]46-basil want [me]834-i to stay at [home]176-home - "[834-i]

" Certainly not , love . [I]0-i wish [you]46-basil all success and pleasure at the ball . "[0-i]

For a moment [she]834-i did not speak ; but fixed [her]834-i clear , kind eyes on [me]0-i more gravely and anxiously than usual . Was [she]834-i searching [my]0-i heart , and discovering the new love rising , [an usurper]835-an usurper already , in the place where the love of [her]834-i had reigned before ?

Love ! love for [[a shopkeeper]795-a shopkeeper 's daughter]796-a shopkeeper 's daughter ! That thought came again , as [she]834-i looked at [me]0-i ! and , strangely mingled with it , a maxim [I]0-i had often heard [[my]0-i father]147-my father repeat to [Ralph]39-ralph - " Never forget that [[your]46-basil station]3058-your station is not [yours]46-basil , to do as [you]46-basil like with . It belongs to [us]3059-us , and belongs to [[your]46-basil children]3060-your children . [You]46-basil must keep it for [them]3060-your children , as [I]834-i have kept it for [you]46-basil . "[834-i]

" [I]57-clara thought , "[57-clara] resumed [Clara]57-clara , in rather lower tones than before , " that [I]57-clara would just look into [[your]46-basil room]3061-your room before [I]57-clara went to the ball , and see that everything was properly arranged for [you]46-basil , in case [you]46-basil had any idea of writing tonight ; [I]57-clara had just time to do this while [[my]57-clara aunt]3062-my aunt , who is going with [me]57-clara , was [upstairs]3063-upstairs altering [her]3062-my aunt toilette . But perhaps [you]46-basil do n't feel inclined to write ? "[57-clara]

" [I]834-i will try at least . "[834-i]

" Can [I]57-clara do anything more ? Would [you]46-basil like [my]57-clara nosegay left in [the room]263-the room ? - the flowers smell so fresh ! [I]57-clara can easily get another . Look at the roses , [my]57-clara favourite white roses , that always remind [me]57-clara of [[my]57-clara own garden]3065-my own garden at [the dear old Park]3066-the dear old park ! "[57-clara]

" Thank [you]46-basil , [Clara]57-clara ; but [I]834-i think the nosegay is fitter for [your]46-basil hand than [my]834-i table . "[834-i]

" Good night , [Basil]46-basil . "[57-clara]

" Good night . "[834-i]

[She]839-she walked to the door , then turned round , and smiled as if [she]839-she were about to speak again ; but checked [herself]839-she , and merely looked at [me]0-i for an instant . In that instant , however , the smile left [her]839-she face , and the grave , anxious expression came again . [She]839-she went out softly . A few minutes afterwards the roll of the carriage which took [her]839-she and [[her]839-she companion]681-her companion to the ball , died away heavily on [my]0-i ear . [I]0-i was left alone in [the house]244-the house - alone for the night .

VIII .

[My]0-i manuscript lay before [me]0-i , set in order by [Clara]57-clara 's careful hand . [I]0-i slowly turned over the leaves one by one ; but [my]0-i eye only fell mechanically on the writing . Yet one day since , and how much ambition , how much hope , how many of [my]0-i heart 's dearest sensations and [my]0-i mind 's highest thoughts dwelt in those poor paper leaves , in those little crabbed marks of pen and ink ! Now [I]0-i could look on them indifferently - almost as [a stranger]842-a stranger would have looked . The days of calm study , of steady toil of thought , seemed departed for ever . Stirring ideas ; store of knowledge patiently heaped up ; visions of better sights than [this world]195-this world can show , falling freshly and sunnily over the pages of [my]0-i first book ; all these were past and gone - withered up by the hot breath of the senses - doomed by a paltry fate , whose germ was the accident of an idle day !

[I]0-i hastily put the manuscript aside . [My]0-i unexpected interview with [Clara]57-clara had calmed the turbulent sensations of the evening : but the fatal influence of the dark beauty remained with [me]0-i still . How could [I]0-i write ?

[I]0-i sat down at the open window . [It]844-it was at the back of [the house]244-the house , and looked out on [a strip of garden - [London]10-london garden]846-a strip of garden - london garden - [a close - shut dungeon for nature]847-a close - shut dungeon for nature , where stunted trees and drooping flowers seemed visibly pining for the free air and sunlight of [the country]370-the country , in [their]370-the country sooty atmosphere , amid [their]370-the country prison of high brick walls . But [the place]435-the place gave room for the air to blow in it , and distanced the tumult of [the busy streets]850-the busy streets . The moon was up , shined round tenderly by a little border - work of pale yellow light . Elsewhere , the awful void of night was starless ; the dark lustre of space shone without a cloud .

A presentiment arose within [me]0-i , that in this still and solitary hour would occur [my]0-i decisive , [my]0-i final struggle with [myself]0-i . [I]0-i felt that [my]0-i heart 's life or death was set on the hazard of the night .

This new love that was in [me]0-i ; this giant sensation of a day 's growth , was first love . Hitherto , [I]0-i had been heart - whole . [I]0-i had known nothing of the passion , which is the absorbing passion of humanity . [No woman]851-no woman had ever before stood between [me]0-i and [my]0-i ambitions , [my]0-i occupations , [my]0-i amusements . [No woman]851-no woman had ever before inspired [me]0-i with the sensations which [I]0-i now felt .

In trying to realise [my]0-i position , there was this one question to consider ; was [I]0-i still strong enough to resist the temptation which accident had thrown in [my]0-i way ? [I]0-i had this one incentive to resistance : the conviction that , if [I]0-i succumbed , as far as [[my]0-i family]197-my family prospects were concerned , [I]0-i should be [a ruined man]854-a ruined man .

[I]0-i knew [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's character well : [I]0-i knew how far [his]147-my father affections and [his]147-my father sympathies might prevail over [his]147-my father prejudices - even over [his]147-my father principles - in some peculiar cases ; and this very knowledge convinced [me]0-i that the consequences of a degrading marriage contracted by [[his]147-my father son]412-his son degrading in regard to rank , would be terrible : fatal to one , perhaps to both . Every other irregularity - every other offence even - [he]147-my father might sooner or later forgive . This irregularity , this offence , never - never , though [his]147-my father heart broke in the struggle . [I]0-i was as sure of it , as [I]0-i was of [my]0-i own existence at that moment .

[I]0-i loved [her]857-her ! All that [I]0-i felt , all that [I]0-i knew , was summed up in those few words ! Deteriorating as [my]0-i passion was in its effect on the exercise of [my]0-i mental powers , and on [my]0-i candour and sense of duty in [my]0-i intercourse with [home]176-home , it was a pure feeling towards [her]857-her . This is truth . If [I]0-i lay on [my]0-i death - bed , at the present moment , and knew that , at the Judgment Day , [I]0-i should be tried by the truth or falsehood of the lines just written , [I]0-i could say with [my]0-i last breath : So be it ; let [them]859-them remain .

But what mattered [my]0-i love for [her]857-her ? However worthy of it [she]857-her might be , [I]0-i had misplaced it , because chance - the same chance which might have given [her]857-her station and [family]860-family - had placed [her]857-her in a rank of life far - too far - below [mine]0-i . As [the daughter of [a " gentleman]3068-a " gentleman]3067-the daughter of a " gentleman , "[3068-a " gentleman] [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's welcome , [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's affection , would have been bestowed on [her]857-her , when [I]0-i took [her]857-her [home]176-home as [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife . As [the daughter of [a tradesman]762-a tradesman]865-the daughter of a tradesman , [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's anger , [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's misery , [my]0-i own ruin perhaps besides , would be the fatal dower that a marriage would confer on [her]857-her . What made all this difference ? A social prejudice . Yes : but a prejudice which had been a principle - nay , more , a religion - in [[our]869-our house]129-our house , since [my]0-i birth ; and for centuries before it .

How strange that foresight of love which precipitates the future into the present ! Here was [I]0-i thinking of [her]857-her as [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife , before , perhaps , [she]857-her had a suspicion of the passion with which [she]857-her had inspired [me]0-i - vexing [my]0-i heart , wearying [my]0-i thoughts , before [I]0-i had even spoken to [her]857-her , as if the perilous discovery of [our]869-our marriage were already at hand ! [I]0-i have thought since how unnatural [I]0-i should have considered this , if [I]0-i had read it in a book .

How could [I]0-i best crush the desire to see [her]857-her , to speak to [her]857-her , on the morrow ? Should [I]0-i leave [London]10-london , leave [England]1-england , fly from the temptation , no matter where , or at what sacrifice ? Or should [I]0-i take refuge in [my]0-i books - [the calm , changeless old friends of [my]0-i earliest fireside hours]872-the calm , changeless old friends of my earliest fireside hours ? Had [I]0-i resolution enough to wear [my]0-i heart out by hard , serious , slaving study ? If [I]0-i left [London]10-london on the morrow , could [I]0-i feel secure , in [my]0-i own conscience , that [I]0-i should not return the day after !

While , throughout the hours of the night , [I]0-i was thus vainly striving to hold calm counsel with [myself]0-i ; the base thought never occurred to [me]0-i , which might have occurred to [some other men]873-some other men , in [my]0-i position : Why marry [the girl]687-the girl , because [I]0-i love [her]687-the girl ? Why , with [my]0-i money , [my]0-i station , [my]0-i opportunities , obstinately connect love and marriage as one idea ; and make a dilemma and a danger where neither need exist ? Had such a thought as this , in the faintest , the most shadowy form , crossed [my]0-i mind , [I]0-i should have shrunk from it , have shrunk from [my]0-i self ; with horror . Whatever fresh degradations may be yet in store for [me]0-i , this one consoling and sanctifying remembrance must still be [mine]0-i . [My]0-i love for [Margaret Sherwin]44-margaret was worthy to be offered to [the purest and perfectest woman that ever [God]37-god created]875-the purest and perfectest woman that ever god created .

The night advanced - the noises faintly reaching [me]0-i from [the streets]241-the streets , sank and ceased - [my]0-i lamp flickered and went out - [I]0-i heard [the carriage]877-the carriage return with [Clara]57-clara from the ball - the first cold clouds of day rose and hid the waning orb of the moon - the air was cooled with its morning freshness : [the earth]878-the earth was purified with its morning dew - and still [I]0-i sat by [my]0-i open window , striving with [my]0-i burning love - thoughts of [Margaret]44-margaret ; striving to think collectedly and usefully - abandoned to a struggle ever renewing , yet never changing ; and always hour after hour , a struggle in vain .

At last [I]0-i began to think less and less distinctly - a few moments more , and [I]0-i sank into a restless , feverish slumber . Then began another , and a more perilous ordeal for [me]0-i - the ordeal of dreams . Thoughts and sensations which had been more and more weakly restrained with each succeeding hour of wakefulness , now rioted within [me]0-i in perfect liberation from all control .

This is what [I]0-i dreamed :

[I]0-i stood on [a wide plain]879-a wide plain . On one side , [it]879-a wide plain was bounded by [thick woods]880-thick woods , whose dark secret depths looked unfathomable to the eye : on the other , by [hills , ever rising higher and higher yet]881-hills , ever rising higher and higher yet , until they were lost in bright , beautifully white clouds , gleaming in refulgent sunlight . On the side above [the woods]882-the woods , the sky was dark and vaporous . It seemed as if some thick exhalation had arisen from beneath the trees , and overspread the clear firmament throughout this portion of the scene .

As [I]0-i still stood on [the plain]883-the plain and looked around , [I]0-i saw [a woman]325-a woman coming towards [me]0-i from the wood . [Her]325-a woman stature was tall ; [her]325-a woman black hair flowed about [her]325-a woman unconfined ; [her]325-a woman robe was of the dun hue of the vapour and mist which hung above the trees , and fell to [her]325-a woman feet in dark thick folds . [She]325-a woman came on towards [me]0-i swiftly and softly , passing over the ground like cloud - shadows over the ripe corn - field or [the calm water]885-the calm water .

[I]0-i looked to the other side , towards [the hills]886-the hills ; and there was [another woman descending from their bright summits]887-another woman descending from their bright summits ; and [her]325-a woman robe was white , and pure , and glistening . [Her]325-a woman face was illumined with a light , like the light of the harvest - moon ; and [her]325-a woman footsteps , as [she]325-a woman descended [the hills]886-the hills , left a long track of brightness , that sparkled far behind [her]325-a woman , like the track of the stars when the winter night is clear and cold . [She]325-a woman came to [the place where [the hills]886-the hills and [the plain]883-the plain were joined together]889-the place where the hills and the plain were joined together . Then [she]325-a woman stopped , and [I]0-i knew that [she]325-a woman was watching [me]0-i from afar off .

Meanwhile , [the woman from the dark wood]892-the woman from the dark wood still approached ; never pausing on [her]325-a woman path , like [the woman from [the fair hills]894-the fair hills]893-the woman from the fair hills . And now [I]0-i could see [her]325-a woman face plainly . [Her]325-a woman eyes were lustrous and fascinating , as the eyes of a serpent - large , dark and soft , as the eyes of the wild doe . [Her]325-a woman lips were parted with a languid smile ; and [she]325-a woman drew back the long hair , which lay over [her]325-a woman cheeks , [her]325-a woman neck , [her]325-a woman bosom , while [I]0-i was gazing on [her]325-a woman .

Then , [I]0-i felt as if a light were shining on [me]0-i from the other side . [I]0-i turned to look , and there was [the woman from [the hills]886-the hills]895-the woman from the hills beckoning [me]0-i away to ascend with [her]325-a woman towards the bright clouds above . [Her]325-a woman arm , as [she]325-a woman held it forth , shone fair , even against [the fair hills]894-the fair hills ; and from [her]325-a woman outstretched hand came long thin rays of trembling light , which penetrated to where [I]0-i stood , cooling and calming wherever they touched [me]0-i .

But [the woman from [the woods]882-the woods]898-the woman from the woods still came nearer and nearer , until [I]0-i could feel [her]325-a woman hot breath on [my]0-i face . [Her]325-a woman eyes looked into [mine]0-i , and fascinated them , as [she]325-a woman held out [her]325-a woman arms to embrace [me]0-i . [I]0-i touched [her]325-a woman hand , and in an instant the touch ran through [me]0-i like fire , from head to foot . Then , still looking intently on [me]0-i with [her]325-a woman wild bright eyes , [she]325-a woman clasped [her]325-a woman supple arms round [my]0-i neck , and drew [me]0-i a few paces away with [her]325-a woman towards [the wood]900-the wood .

[I]0-i felt the rays of light that had touched [me]0-i from the beckoning hand , depart ; and yet once more [I]0-i looked towards [the woman from [the hills]886-the hills]895-the woman from the hills . [She]325-a woman was ascending again towards the bright clouds , and ever and anon [she]325-a woman stopped and turned round , wringing [her]325-a woman hands and letting [her]325-a woman head droop , as if in bitter grief . The last time [I]0-i saw [her]325-a woman look towards [me]0-i , [she]325-a woman was near the clouds . [She]325-a woman covered [her]325-a woman face with [her]325-a woman robe , and knelt down where [she]325-a woman stood . After this [I]0-i discerned no more of [her]325-a woman . For now [the woman from [the woods]882-the woods]898-the woman from the woods clasped [me]0-i more closely than before , pressing [her]325-a woman warm lips on [mine]0-i ; and it was as if [her]325-a woman long hair fell round [us]905-us both , spreading over [my]0-i eyes like a veil , to hide from them the fair hill - tops , and [the woman who was walking onward to the bright clouds above]906-the woman who was walking onward to the bright clouds above .

[I]0-i was drawn along in the arms of [the dark woman]907-the dark woman , with [my]0-i blood burning and [my]0-i breath failing [me]0-i , until [we]905-us entered the secret recesses that lay amid [the unfathomable depths of trees]908-the unfathomable depths of trees . There , [she]907-the dark woman encircled [me]0-i in the folds of [her]907-the dark woman dusky robe , and laid [her]907-the dark woman cheek close to [mine]0-i , and murmured a mysterious music in [my]0-i ear , amid the midnight silence and darkness of all around [us]905-us . And [I]0-i had no thought of returning to [the plain]883-the plain again ; for [I]0-i had forgotten [the woman from [the fair hills]894-the fair hills]893-the woman from the fair hills , and had given [myself]0-i up , heart , and soul , and body , to [the woman from [the dark woods]913-the dark woods]912-the woman from the dark woods .

Here the dream ended , and [I]0-i awoke .

It was broad daylight . The sun shone brilliantly , the sky was cloudless . [I]0-i looked at [my]0-i watch ; it had stopped . Shortly afterwards [I]0-i heard the hall clock strike six .

[My]0-i dream was vividly impressed on [my]0-i memory , especially the latter part of it . Was it a warning of coming events , foreshadowed in the wild visions of sleep ? But to what purpose could this dream , or indeed any dream , tend ? Why had it remained incomplete , failing to show [me]0-i the visionary consequences of [my]0-i visionary actions ? What superstition to ask ! What a waste of attention to bestow it on such a trifle as a dream !

Still , this trifle had produced one abiding result . [I]0-i knew it not then ; but [I]0-i know it now . As [I]0-i looked out on the reviving , re - assuring sunlight , it was easy enough for [me]0-i to dismiss as ridiculous from [my]0-i mind , or rather from [my]0-i conscience , the tendency to see in the two shadowy forms of [my]0-i dream , the types of [two real living beings]914-two real living beings , whose names almost trembled into utterance on [my]0-i lips ; but [I]0-i could not also dismiss from [my]0-i heart the love - images which that dream had set up there for the worship of the senses . Those results of the night still remained within [me]0-i , growing and strengthening with every minute .

If [I]0-i had been told beforehand how the mere sight of the morning would reanimate and embolden [me]0-i , [I]0-i should have scouted the prediction as too outrageous for consideration ; yet so it was . The moody and boding reflections , the fear and struggle of the hours of darkness were gone with the daylight . The love - thoughts of [Margaret]44-margaret alone remained , and now remained unquestioned and unopposed . Were [my]0-i convictions of a few hours since , like the night - mists that fade before returning sunshine ? [I]0-i knew not . But [I]0-i was young ; and each new morning is as much the new life of youth , as the new life of [Nature]47-nature .

So [I]0-i left [[my]0-i study]609-my study and went out . Consequences might come how [they]916-they would , and when [they]916-they would ; [I]0-i thought of them no more . It seemed as if [I]0-i had cast off every melancholy thought , in leaving [[my]0-i room]136-my room ; as if [my]0-i heart had sprung up more elastic than ever , after the burden that had been laid on it during the night . Enjoyment for the present , hope for the future , and chance and fortune to trust in to the very last ! This was [my]0-i creed , as [I]0-i walked into [the street]163-the street , determined to see [Margaret]44-margaret again , and to tell [her]44-margaret of [my]0-i love before the day was out . In the exhilaration of the fresh air and the gay sunshine , [I]0-i turned [my]0-i steps towards [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square , almost as light - hearted as [a boy]292-a boy let loose from [school]344-school , joyously repeating [Shakespeare]48-shakespeare 's lines as [I]0-i went :

" Hope is [a lover]3069-a lover 's staff ; walk hence with that , And manage it against despairing thoughts . "[292-a boy]

IX .

[London]10-london was rousing everywhere into morning activity , as [I]0-i passed through [the streets]241-the streets . The shutters were being removed from the windows of [public - houses]922-public - houses : [the drink - vampyres that suck the life of [London]10-london]923-the drink - vampyres that suck the life of london , were opening [their]923-the drink - vampyres that suck the life of london eyes betimes to look abroad for the new day 's prey ! [Small tobacco and provision - shops in [poor neighbourhoods]925-poor neighbourhoods]924-small tobacco and provision - shops in poor neighbourhoods ; [dirty little eating - houses]926-dirty little eating - houses , exhaling greasy - smelling steam , and displaying a leaf of yesterday 's paper , stained and fly - blown , hanging in the windows - were already plying , or making ready to ply , [their]923-the drink - vampyres that suck the life of london daily trade . Here , [a labouring man]927-a labouring man , late for [his]927-a labouring man work , hurried by ; there , [a hale old gentleman]928-a hale old gentleman started for [his]928-a hale old gentleman early walk before breakfast . Now a market - cart , already unloaded , passed [me]0-i on its way back to [the country]370-the country ; now , [a cab , laden with luggage]930-a cab , laden with luggage and carrying [pale , sleepy - looking people]931-pale , sleepy - looking people , rattled by , bound for [the morning train]932-the morning train or [the morning steamboat]933-the morning steamboat . [I]0-i saw the mighty vitality of [the great city]934-the great city renewing itself in every direction ; and [I]0-i felt an unwonted interest in the sight . It was as if all things , on all sides , were reflecting before [me]0-i the aspect of [my]0-i own heart .

But the quiet and torpor of the night still hung over [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square . [That dreary neighbourhood]935-that dreary neighbourhood seemed to vindicate [its]935-that dreary neighbourhood dreariness by being the last to awaken even to a semblance of activity and life . Nothing was stirring as yet at [North Villa]11-north villa . [I]0-i walked on , beyond [the last houses]936-the last houses , into [the sooty London fields]937-the sooty london fields ; and tried to think of the course [I]0-i ought to pursue in order to see [Margaret]44-margaret , and speak to [her]44-margaret , before [I]0-i turned homeward again . After the lapse of more than half an hour , [I]0-i returned to [the square]717-the square , without plan or project ; but resolved , nevertheless , to carry [my]0-i point .

[The garden - gate of [North Villa]11-north villa]939-the garden - gate of north villa was now open . [One of [the female servants of [the house]244-the house]941-the female servants of the house]940-one of the female servants of the house was standing at [it]939-the garden - gate of north villa , to breathe the fresh air , and look about [her]44-margaret , before the duties of the day began . [I]0-i advanced ; determined , if money and persuasion could do it , to secure [her]44-margaret services .

[She]44-margaret was young that was one chance in [my]0-i favour ! - plump , florid , and evidently not by any means careless about [her]44-margaret personal appearance that gave [me]0-i another ! As [she]44-margaret saw [me]0-i approaching [her]44-margaret , [she]44-margaret smiled ; and passed [her]44-margaret apron hurriedly over [her]44-margaret face - carefully polishing it for [my]0-i inspection , much as [a broker]943-a broker polishes a piece of furniture when [you]944-you stop to look at it .

" Are [you]687-the girl in [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's service ? "[0-i] - [I]0-i asked , as [I]0-i got to the garden gate .

" As [plain cook]3070-plain cook , [Sir]3046-sir , "[687-the girl] answered [the girl]687-the girl , administering to [her]687-the girl face a final and furious rub of the apron .

" Should [you]3046-sir be very much surprised if [I]687-the girl asked [you]3046-sir to do [me]687-the girl a great favour ? "[687-the girl]

" Well - really , [Sir]3046-sir - [you]3046-sir 're quite [a stranger to [me]687-the girl]3073-a stranger to me - [I]687-the girl 'm sure [I]687-the girl do n't know ! "[687-the girl] [She]687-the girl stopped , and transferred the apron - rubbing to [her]687-the girl arms .

" [I]687-the girl hope [we]3074-our shall not be [strangers]300-strangers long . Suppose [I]687-the girl begin [our]3074-our acquaintance , by telling [you]3046-sir that [you]3046-sir would look prettier in brighter cap - ribbons , and asking [you]3046-sir to buy some , just to see whether [I]687-the girl am not right ? "[687-the girl]

" It 's very kind of [you]3046-sir to say so , [Sir]3046-sir ; and thank [you]3046-sir . But cap and ribbons are the last things [I]687-the girl can buy while [I]687-the girl 'm in [this place]3077-this place . [[Master]491-master 's [master]491-master]3079-master 's master and [missus]3081-missus too , here ; and drives [us]3074-our half wild with the fuss [he]491-master makes about [our]3074-our caps and ribbons . [He]491-master 's such [an austerious man]3082-an austerious man , that [he]491-master will have [our]3074-our caps as [he]491-master likes ['em]3083-'em . It 's bad enough when [a missus]3084-a missus meddles with [a poor servant]3085-a poor servant 's ribbons ; but to have [master]491-master come down into [the kitchen]3087-the kitchen , and - Well , it 's no use telling [you]687-the girl of it , [Sir]3046-sir - and - and thank [you]687-the girl , [Sir]3046-sir , for what [you]687-the girl 've given [me]687-the girl , all the same ! "[687-the girl]

" [I]687-the girl hope this is not the last time [I]687-the girl shall make [you]3046-sir a present . And now [I]687-the girl must come to the favour [I]687-the girl want to ask of [you]3046-sir : can [you]3046-sir keep a secret ? "[687-the girl]

" That [I]687-the girl can , [Sir]3046-sir ! [I]687-the girl 've kep ' a many secrets since [I]687-the girl 've been out at service . "[687-the girl]

" Well : [I]687-the girl want [you]3046-sir to find [me]687-the girl an opportunity of speaking to [[your]3046-sir young lady]3091-your young lady - "[687-the girl]

" To [Miss Margaret]44-margaret , [Sir]3046-sir ? "[687-the girl]

" Yes . [I]687-the girl want an opportunity of seeing [Miss Margaret]44-margaret , and speaking to [her]44-margaret in private - and not a word must be said to [her]44-margaret about it , beforehand . "[687-the girl]

" Oh Lord , [Sir]3046-sir ! [I]687-the girl could n't dare to do it ! "[687-the girl]

" Come ! come ! Ca n't [you]3046-sir guess why [I]687-the girl want to see [[your]3046-sir young lady]3091-your young lady , and what [I]687-the girl want to say to [her]44-margaret ? "[687-the girl]

[The girl]687-the girl smiled , and shook [her]687-the girl head archly . " Perhaps [you]3046-sir 're in love with [Miss Margaret]44-margaret , [Sir]3046-sir ! - But [I]687-the girl could n't do it ! [I]687-the girl could n't dare to do it ! "[687-the girl]

" Very well ; but [you]3046-sir can tell [me]687-the girl at least , whether [Miss Margaret]44-margaret ever goes out to take a walk ? "[687-the girl]

" Oh , yes , [Sir]3046-sir ; mostly every day . "[687-the girl]

" Do [you]3046-sir ever go out with [her]44-margaret ? - just to take care of [her]44-margaret when [no one else]554-no one else can be spared ? "[687-the girl]

" Do n't ask [me]687-the girl - please , [Sir]3046-sir , do n't ! "[687-the girl] [She]687-the girl crumpled [her]687-the girl apron between [her]687-the girl fingers , with a very piteous and perplexed air . " [I]687-the girl do n't know [you]3046-sir ; and [Miss Margaret]44-margaret do n't know [you]3046-sir , [I]687-the girl 'm sure - [I]687-the girl could n't , [Sir]3046-sir , [I]687-the girl really could n't ! "[687-the girl]

" Take a good look at [me]687-the girl ! Do [you]3046-sir think [I]687-the girl am likely to do [you]3046-sir or [[your]3046-sir young lady]3091-your young lady any harm ? Am [I]687-the girl too dangerous [a man]3101-a man to be trusted ? Would [you]3046-sir believe [me]687-the girl on [my]687-the girl promise ? "[687-the girl]

" Yes , [Sir]3046-sir , [I]687-the girl 'm sure [I]687-the girl would ! - being so kind and so civil to [me]687-the girl , too ! "[687-the girl] a fresh arrangement of the cap followed this speech .

" Then suppose [I]687-the girl promised , in the first place , not to tell [Miss Margaret]44-margaret that [I]687-the girl had spoken to [you]3046-sir about [her]44-margaret at all . And suppose [I]687-the girl promised , in the second place , that , if [you]3046-sir told [me]687-the girl when [you]3046-sir and [Miss Margaret]44-margaret go out together , [I]687-the girl would only speak to [her]44-margaret while [she]44-margaret was in [your]3046-sir sight , and would leave [her]44-margaret the moment [you]3046-sir wished [me]687-the girl to go away . Do n't [you]3046-sir think [you]3046-sir could venture to help [me]687-the girl , if [I]687-the girl promised all that ? "[687-the girl]

" Well , [Sir]3046-sir , that would make a difference , to be sure . But then , it 's [master]491-master [I]687-the girl 'm so afraid of - could n't [you]3046-sir speak to [master]491-master first , [Sir]3046-sir ? "[687-the girl]

" Suppose [you]3046-sir were in [[Miss Margaret]44-margaret 's place]3107-miss margaret 's place , would [you]3046-sir like to be made love to , by [[your]3046-sir father]302-your father 's authority , without [your]3046-sir own wishes being consulted first ? would [you]3046-sir like an offer of marriage , delivered like a message , by means of [[your]3046-sir father]302-your father ? Come , tell [me]687-the girl honestly , would [you]3046-sir ? "[687-the girl]

[She]947-she laughed , and shook [her]947-she head very expressively . [I]0-i knew the strength of [my]0-i last argument , and repeated it : " Suppose [you]947-she were in [[Miss Margaret]44-margaret 's place]3107-miss margaret 's place ? "[0-i]

" Hush ! do n't speak so loud , "[687-the girl] resumed [the girl]687-the girl in a confidential whisper . " [I]687-the girl 'm sure [you]3046-sir 're [a gentleman]3111-a gentleman . [I]687-the girl should like to help [you]3046-sir - if [I]687-the girl could only dare to do it , [I]687-the girl should indeed ! "[687-the girl]

" That 's [a good girl]3112-a good girl , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " Now tell [me]0-i , when does [Miss Margaret]44-margaret go out to - day ; and who goes with [her]44-margaret ? "[0-i]

" [Dear]3113-dear ! dear ! - it 's very wrong to say it ; but [I]687-the girl must . [She]44-margaret 'll go out with [me]687-the girl to market , this morning , at eleven o'clock . [She]44-margaret 's done it for the last week . [Master]491-master do n't like it ; but [Missus]3115-missus begged and prayed [she]44-margaret might ; for [Missus]3116-missus says [she]44-margaret wo n't be fit to be married , if [she]44-margaret knows nothing about housekeeping , and prices , and what 's good meat , and what is n't , and all that , [you]3046-sir know . "[687-the girl]

" Thank [you]3046-sir a thousand times ! [you]3046-sir have given [me]0-i all the help [I]0-i want . [I]0-i 'll be here before eleven , waiting for [you]3046-sir to come out . "[0-i]

" Oh , please do n't , [Sir]3046-sir - [I]687-the girl wish [I]687-the girl had n't told [you]3046-sir - [I]687-the girl ought n't , indeed [I]687-the girl ought n't ! "[687-the girl]

" No fear - [you]3046-sir shall not lose by what [you]3046-sir have told [me]0-i - [I]0-i promise all [I]0-i said [I]0-i would promise - good bye . And mind , not a word to [Miss Margaret]44-margaret till [I]0-i see [her]687-the girl ! "[0-i]

As [I]0-i hurried away , [I]0-i heard [the girl]687-the girl run a few paces after [me]0-i - then stop - then return , and close the garden gate , softly . [She]687-the girl had evidently put [herself]687-the girl once more in [[Miss Margaret]44-margaret 's place]3107-miss margaret 's place ; and had given up all idea of further resistance as [she]687-the girl did so .

How should [I]0-i occupy the hours until eleven o'clock ? [Deceit]49-deceit whispered : - Go [home]176-home ; avoid even the chance of exciting suspicion , by breakfasting with [[your]952-your family]953-your family as usual . And as deceit counselled , so [I]0-i acted .

[I]0-i never remember [Clara]57-clara more kind , more ready with all those trifling little cares and attentions which have so exquisite a grace , when offered by [a woman]325-a woman to [a man]3101-a man , and especially by [a sister]956-a sister to [a brother]957-a brother , as when [she]57-clara and [I]0-i and [[my]0-i father]147-my father assembled together at the breakfast - table . [I]0-i now recollect with shame how little [I]0-i thought about [her]57-clara , or spoke to [her]57-clara on that morning ; with how little hesitation or self - reproach [I]0-i excused [myself]0-i from accepting an engagement which [she]57-clara wished to make with [me]0-i for that day . [[My]0-i father]147-my father was absorbed in some matter of business ; to [him]147-my father [she]57-clara could not speak . It was to [me]0-i that [she]57-clara addressed all [her]57-clara wonted questions and remarks of the morning . [I]0-i hardly listened to them ; [I]0-i answered them carelessly and briefly . The moment breakfast was over , without a word of explanation [I]0-i hastily left [the house]244-the house again .

As [I]0-i descended the steps , [I]0-i glanced by accident at the dining - room window . [Clara]57-clara was looking after [me]0-i from it . There was the same anxious expression on [her]57-clara face which it had worn when [she]57-clara left [me]0-i the evening before . [She]57-clara smiled as [our]961-our eyes met - a sad , faint smile that made [her]57-clara look unlike [herself]57-clara . But it produced no impression on [me]0-i then : [I]0-i had no attention for anything but [my]0-i approaching interview with [Margaret]44-margaret . [My]0-i life throbbed and burned within [me]0-i , in that direction : it was all coldness , torpor , insensibility , in every other .

[I]0-i reached [Hollyoake Square]12-hollyoake square nearly an hour before the appointed time . In the suspense and impatience of that long interval , it was impossible to be a moment in repose . [I]0-i walked incessantly up and down [the square]717-the square , and round and round [the neighbourhood]718-the neighbourhood , hearing each quarter chimed from a church clock near , and mechanically quickening [my]0-i pace the nearer the time came for the hour to strike . At last , [I]0-i heard the first peal of the eventful eleven . Before the clock was silent , [I]0-i had taken up [my]0-i position within view of the gate of [North Villa]11-north villa .

Five minutes passed - ten - and [no one]743-no one appeared . In [my]0-i impatience , [I]0-i could almost have rung the bell and entered [the house]244-the house , no matter who might be [there]161-there , or what might be the result . The first quarter struck ; and at that very moment [I]0-i heard the door open , and saw [Margaret]44-margaret , and [the servant with whom [I]0-i had spoken , descending the steps]967-the servant with whom i had spoken , descending the steps .

[They]968-they passed out slowly through the garden gate , and walked down [the square]717-the square , away from where [I]0-i was standing . [The servant]315-the servant noticed [me]0-i by one significant look , as [they]968-they went on . [[Her]44-margaret young mistress]971-her young mistress did not appear to see [me]0-i . At first , [my]0-i agitation was so violent that [I]0-i was perfectly incapable of following [them]968-they a single step . In a few moments [I]0-i recovered [myself]0-i ; and hastened to overtake [them]968-they , before [they]968-they arrived at [a more frequented part of [the neighbourhood]718-the neighbourhood]972-a more frequented part of the neighbourhood .

As [I]0-i approached [her]44-margaret side , [Margaret]44-margaret turned suddenly and looked at [me]0-i , with an expression of anger and astonishment in [her]44-margaret eyes . The next instant , [her]44-margaret lovely face became tinged all over with a deep , burning blush ; [her]44-margaret head drooped a little ; [she]44-margaret hesitated for a moment ; and then abruptly quickened [her]44-margaret pace . Did [she]44-margaret remember [me]0-i ? The mere chance that [she]44-margaret did , gave [me]0-i confidence : [I]0-i -

- No ! [I]0-i can not write down the words that [I]0-i said to [her]44-margaret . Recollecting the end to which [our]974-our fatal interview led , [I]0-i recoil at the very thought of exposing to [others]98-others , or of preserving in any permanent form , the words in which [I]0-i first confessed [my]0-i love . It may be pride - miserable , useless pride - which animates [me]0-i with this feeling : but [I]0-i can not overcome it . Remembering what [I]0-i do , [I]0-i am ashamed to write , ashamed to recall , what [I]0-i said at [my]0-i first interview with [Margaret]44-margaret [Sherwin]44-margaret . [I]0-i can give no good reason for the sensations which now influence [me]0-i ; [I]0-i can not analyse them ; and [I]0-i would not if [I]0-i could .

Let it be enough to say that [I]0-i risked everything , and spoke to [her]44-margaret . [My]0-i words , confused as they were , came hotly , eagerly , and eloquently from [my]0-i heart . In the space of a few minutes , [I]0-i confessed to [her]44-margaret all , and more than all , that [I]0-i have here painfully related in many pages . [I]0-i made use of [my]0-i name and [my]0-i rank in life - even now , [my]0-i cheeks burn while [I]0-i think of it - to dazzle [[her]44-margaret girl]976-her girl 's pride , to make [her]44-margaret listen to [me]0-i for the sake of [my]0-i station , if [she]44-margaret would not for the sake of [my]0-i suit , however honourably urged . Never before had [I]0-i committed the meanness of trusting to [my]0-i social advantages , what [I]0-i feared to trust to [myself]0-i . It is true that love soars higher than the other passions ; but it can stoop lower as well .

[Her]44-margaret answers to all that [I]0-i urged were confused , commonplace , and chilling enough . [I]0-i had surprised [her]44-margaret - frightened [her]44-margaret - it was impossible [she]44-margaret could listen to such addresses from [a total stranger]977-a total stranger - it was very wrong of [me]0-i to speak , and of [her]44-margaret to stop and hear [me]0-i - [I]0-i should remember what became [me]0-i as [a gentleman]3111-a gentleman , and should not make such advances to [her]44-margaret again - [I]0-i knew nothing of [her]44-margaret - it was impossible [I]0-i could really care about [her]44-margaret in so short a time - [she]44-margaret must beg that [I]0-i would allow [her]44-margaret to proceed unhindered .

Thus [she]44-margaret spoke ; sometimes standing still , sometimes moving hurriedly a few steps forward . [She]44-margaret might have expressed [herself]44-margaret severely , even angrily ; but nothing [she]44-margaret could have said would have counteracted the fascination that [her]44-margaret presence exercised over [me]0-i . [I]0-i saw [her]44-margaret face , lovelier than ever in its confusion , in its rapid changes of expression ; [I]0-i saw [her]44-margaret eloquent eyes once or twice raised to mine , then instantly withdrawn again - and so long as [I]0-i could look at [her]44-margaret , [I]0-i cared not what [I]0-i listened to . [She]44-margaret was only speaking what [she]44-margaret had been educated to speak ; it was not in [her]44-margaret words that [I]0-i sought the clue to [her]44-margaret thoughts and sensations ; but in the tone of [her]44-margaret voice , in the language of [her]44-margaret eyes , in the whole expression of [her]44-margaret face . All these contained indications which reassured [me]0-i . [I]0-i tried everything that respect , that the persuasion of love could urge , to win [her]44-margaret consent to [our]979-our meeting again ; but [she]44-margaret only answered with repetitions of what [she]44-margaret had said before , walking onward rapidly while [she]44-margaret spoke . [The servant , who had hitherto lingered a few paces behind]980-the servant , who had hitherto lingered a few paces behind , now advanced to [[her]980-the servant , who had hitherto lingered a few paces behind young mistress]971-her young mistress 's side , with a significant look , as if to remind [me]0-i of [my]0-i promise . Saying a few parting words , [I]0-i let [them]982-them proceed : at this first interview , to have delayed [them]982-them longer would have been risking too much .
