Remain here as long as [you]0-i like : [we]3324-we shall be happy to see [you]0-i in [the country]370-the country , when [you]0-i are able to leave [town]340-town . "[147-my father]

[He]1156-he turned to [Clara]57-clara . " [I]1156-he suppose , [[my]1156-he love]3327-my love , [you]57-clara want [me]1156-he no longer . While [I]1156-he settle [my]1156-he own matters of business , [you]57-clara can arrange about the bookcases with [[your]57-clara brother]3328-your brother . Whatever [you]57-clara wish , [I]1156-he shall be glad to do . "[1156-he] And [he]1156-he left [the room]263-the room without speaking to [me]0-i , or looking at [me]0-i again . [I]0-i sank into a chair , feeling disgraced in [my]0-i own estimation by the last words [he]1156-he had spoken to [me]0-i . [His]1156-he trust in [my]0-i honour was [his]1156-he only guarantee against [my]0-i deceiving [him]1156-he . As [I]0-i thought over that declaration , every syllable of it seemed to sear [my]0-i conscience ; to brand Hypocrite on [my]0-i heart .

[I]0-i turned towards [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister . [She]296-my sister was standing at a little distance from [me]0-i , silent and pale , mechanically twisting the measuring - string , which [she]296-my sister still held between [her]296-my sister trembling fingers ; and fixing [her]296-my sister eyes upon [me]0-i so lovingly , so mournfully , that [my]0-i fortitude gave way when [I]0-i looked at [her]296-my sister . At that instant , [I]0-i seemed to forget everything that had passed since the day when [I]0-i first met [Margaret]44-margaret , and to be restored once more to [my]0-i old way of life and [my]0-i old home - sympathies . [My]0-i head drooped on [my]0-i breast , and [I]0-i felt the hot tears forcing themselves into [my]0-i eyes .

[Clara]57-clara stepped quietly to [my]0-i side ; and sitting down by [me]0-i in silence , put [her]57-clara arm round [my]0-i neck .

When [I]0-i was calmer , [she]57-clara said gently :

" [I]57-clara have been very anxious about [you]0-i , [Basil]46-basil ; and perhaps [I]57-clara have allowed that anxiety to appear more than [I]57-clara ought . Perhaps [I]57-clara have been accustomed to exact too much from [you]0-i - [you]0-i have been too ready to please [me]57-clara . But [I]57-clara have been used to it so long ; and [I]57-clara have nobody else that [I]57-clara can speak to as [I]57-clara can to [you]0-i . [Papa]58-papa is very kind ; but [he]58-papa ca n't be what [you]0-i are to [me]57-clara exactly ; and [Ralph]39-ralph does not live with [us]3329-us now , and cared little about [me]57-clara , [I]57-clara am afraid , when [he]58-papa did . [I]57-clara have [friends]440-friends , but [friends]440-friends are not - "[57-clara]

[She]1159-i stopped again ; [her]1159-i voice was failing [her]1159-i . For a moment , [she]1159-i struggled to keep [her]1159-i self - possession - struggled as only [women]326-women can - and succeeded in the effort . [She]1159-i pressed [her]1159-i arm closer round [my]0-i neck ; but [her]1159-i tones were steadier and clearer when [she]1159-i resumed :

" It will not be very easy for [me]1159-i to give up [our]3329-us country rides and walks together , and the evening talk that [we]3329-us always had at dusk in [the old library at [the park]730-the park]3332-the old library at the park . But [I]1159-i think [I]1159-i can resign all this , and go away alone with [papa]3052-papa , for the first time , without making [you]0-i melancholy by anything [I]1159-i say or do at parting , if [you]0-i will only promise that when [you]0-i are in any difficulty [you]0-i will let [me]1159-i be of some use . [I]1159-i think [I]1159-i could always be of use , because [I]1159-i should always feel an interest in anything that concerned [you]0-i . [I]1159-i do n't want to intrude on [your]0-i secret ; but if that secret should ever bring [you]0-i trouble or distress which [I]1159-i hope and pray it may not , [I]1159-i want [you]0-i to have confidence in [my]1159-i being able to help [you]0-i , in some way , through any mischances . Let [me]1159-i go into [the country]370-the country , [Basil]46-basil , knowing that [you]0-i can still put trust in [me]1159-i , even though a time should come when [you]0-i can put trust in [no one else]554-no one else - let [me]1159-i know this : do let [me]1159-i ! "[1159-i]

[I]0-i gave [her]1161-her the assurance [she]1161-her desired - gave it with [my]0-i whole heart . [She]1161-her seemed to have recovered all [her]1161-her old influence over [me]0-i by the few simple words [she]1161-her had spoken . The thought crossed [my]0-i mind , whether [I]0-i ought not in common gratitude to confide [my]0-i secret to [her]1161-her at once , knowing as [I]0-i did , that it would be safe in [her]1161-her keeping , however the disclosure might startle or pain [her]1161-her , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i should have told [her]1161-her all , in another minute , but for a mere accident - the trifling interruption caused by a knock at the door .

It came from [one of [the servants]745-the servants]1162-one of the servants . [[My]0-i father]147-my father desired to see [Clara]57-clara on some matter connected with [their]1165-their impending departure for [the country]370-the country . [She]57-clara was unfit enough to obey such a summons at such a time ; but with [her]57-clara usual courage in disciplining [her]57-clara own feelings into subserviency to the wishes of [any one whom [she]57-clara loved]1167-any one whom she loved , [she]57-clara determined to obey immediately the message which had been delivered to [her]57-clara . A few moments of silence ; a slight trembling soon repressed ; a parting kiss for [me]0-i ; these few farewell words of encouragement at the door ; " Do n't grieve about what [papa]3052-papa has said ; [you]0-i have made [me]57-clara feel happy about [you]0-i , [Basil]46-basil ; [I]57-clara will make [him]3052-papa feel happy too , "[57-clara] and [Clara]57-clara was gone .

With those few minutes of interruption , the time for the disclosure of [my]0-i secret had passed by . As soon as [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister was out of [the room]263-the room , [my]0-i former reluctance to trust it to [home]176-home - keeping returned , and remained unchanged throughout the whole of the long year 's probation which [I]0-i had engaged to pass . But this mattered little . As events turned out , if [I]0-i had told [Clara]57-clara all , the end would have come in the same way , the fatality would have been accomplished by the same means .

[I]0-i went out shortly after [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister had left [me]0-i . [I]0-i could give [myself]0-i to no occupation at [home]176-home , for the rest of that night ; and [I]0-i knew that it would be useless to attempt to sleep just then . As [I]0-i walked through [the streets]241-the streets , bitter thoughts against [[my]0-i father]147-my father rose in [my]0-i mind - bitter thoughts against [his]147-my father inexorable family pride , which imposed on [me]0-i the concealment and secrecy , under the oppression of which [I]0-i had already suffered so much - bitter thoughts against those social tyrannies , which take no account of human sympathy and human love , and which [[my]0-i father]147-my father now impersonated , as it were , to [my]0-i ideas . Gradually these reflections merged in others that were better . [I]0-i thought of [Clara]57-clara again ; consoling [myself]0-i with the belief , that , however [[my]0-i father]147-my father might receive the news of [my]0-i marriage , [I]0-i might count upon [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister as certain to love [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife and be kind to [her]296-my sister , for [my]0-i sake . This thought led [my]0-i heart back to [Margaret]44-margaret - led it gently and happily . [I]0-i went [home]176-home , calmed and reassured again - at least for the rest of the night .

The events of that week , so fraught with importance for the future of [my]0-i life , passed with ominous rapidity .

The marriage license was procured ; all remaining preliminaries with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin were adjusted ; [I]0-i saw [Margaret]44-margaret every day , and gave [myself]0-i up more and more unreservedly to the charm that [she]44-margaret exercised over [me]0-i , at each succeeding interview . At [home]176-home , the bustle of approaching departure ; the farewell visitings ; the multitudinous minor arrangements preceding a journey to [the country]370-the country , seemed to hurry the hours on faster and faster , as the parting day for [Clara]57-clara , and the marriage day for [me]0-i , drew near . Incessant interruptions prevented any more lengthened or private conversations with [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister ; and [[my]0-i father]147-my father was hardly ever accessible for more than five minutes together , even to [those who specially wished to speak with [him]147-my father]1184-those who specially wished to speak with him . Nothing arose to embarrass or alarm [me]0-i now , out of [my]0-i intercourse with [home]176-home .

The day came . [I]0-i had not slept during the night that preceded it ; so [I]0-i rose early to look out on the morning .

It is strange how frequently that instinctive belief in omens and predestinations , which [we]1186-we flippantly term Superstition , asserts its natural prerogative even over minds trained to repel it , at the moment of some great event in [our]1186-we lives . [I]0-i believe this has happened to [many more men]1187-many more men than ever confessed it ; and it happened to [me]0-i . At any former period of [my]0-i life , [I]0-i should have laughed at the bare imputation of a ' superstitious " feeling ever having risen in [my]0-i mind . But now , as [I]0-i looked on the sky , and saw the black clouds that overspread the whole firmament , and the heavy rain that poured down from them , an irrepressible sinking of the heart came over [me]0-i . For the last ten days the sun had shone almost uninterruptedly - with [my]0-i marriage - day came the cloud , the mist and the rain . [I]0-i tried to laugh [myself]0-i out of the forebodings which this suggested , and tried in vain .[0-i]

The departure for [the country]370-the country was to take place at an early hour . [We]1186-we all breakfasted together ; the meal was hurried over comfortlessly and silently . [[My]0-i father]147-my father was either writing notes , or examining [the steward]366-the steward 's accounts , almost the whole time ; and [Clara]57-clara was evidently incapable of uttering a single word , without risking the loss of [her]57-clara self - possession . The silence was so complete , while [we]1186-we sat together at the table , that the fall of the rain outside which had grown softer and thicker as the morning advanced , and the quick , quiet tread of [the servants]745-the servants , as [they]745-the servants moved about [the room]263-the room , were audible with a painful distinctness . The oppression of [our]1186-we last family breakfast in [London]10-london , for that year , had an influence of wretchedness which [I]0-i can not describe - which [I]0-i can never forget .

At last the hour of starting came . [Clara]57-clara seemed afraid to trust [herself]57-clara even to look at [me]0-i now . [She]57-clara hurriedly drew down [her]57-clara veil the moment [the carriage]877-the carriage was announced . [[My]0-i father]147-my father shook hands with [me]0-i rather coldly . [I]0-i had hoped [he]147-my father would have said something at parting ; but [he]147-my father only bade [me]0-i farewell in the simplest and shortest manner . [I]0-i had rather [he]147-my father would have spoken to [me]0-i in anger than restrained [himself]147-my father as [he]147-my father did , to what the commonest forms of courtesy required . There was but one more slight , after this , that [he]147-my father could cast on [me]0-i ; and [he]147-my father did not spare it . While [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister was taking leave of [me]0-i , [he]147-my father waited at the door of [the room]263-the room to lead [her]296-my sister down [stairs]1197-stairs , as if [he]147-my father knew by intuition that this was the last little parting attention which [I]0-i had hoped to show [her]296-my sister [myself]0-i .

[Clara]57-clara whispered in such low , trembling tones that [I]0-i could hardly hear [her]57-clara :

" Think of what [you]0-i promised in [[your]0-i study]3338-your study , [Basil]46-basil , whenever [you]0-i think of [me]57-clara : [I]57-clara will write often . "[57-clara]

As [she]57-clara raised [her]57-clara veil for a moment , and kissed [me]0-i , [I]0-i felt on [my]0-i own cheek the tears that were falling fast over [hers]57-clara . [I]0-i followed [her]57-clara and [[my]0-i father]147-my father down [stairs]1197-stairs . When [they]1200-they reached [the street]163-the street , [she]57-clara gave [me]0-i [her]57-clara hand - it was cold and powerless . [I]0-i knew that the fortitude [she]57-clara had promised to show , was giving way , in spite of all [her]57-clara efforts to preserve it ; so [I]0-i let [her]57-clara hurry into [the carriage]877-the carriage without detaining [her]57-clara by any last words . The next instant [she]57-clara and [[my]0-i father]147-my father were driven rapidly from the door .

When [I]0-i re - entered [the house]244-the house , [my]0-i watch showed [me]0-i that [I]0-i had still an hour to wait , before it was time to go to [North Villa]11-north villa .

Between the different emotions produced by [my]0-i impressions of the scene [I]0-i had just passed through , and [my]0-i anticipations of the scene that was yet to come , [I]0-i suffered in that one hour as much mental conflict as [most men]1205-most men suffer in a life . It seemed as if [I]0-i were living out all [my]0-i feelings in this short interval of delay , and must die at heart when it was over . [My]0-i restlessness was a torture to [me]0-i ; and yet [I]0-i could not overcome it . [I]0-i wandered through [the house]244-the house from [room]1207-room to [room]1207-room , stopping nowhere . [I]0-i took down book after book from [the library]1061-the library , opened them to read , and put them back on the shelves the next instant . Over and over again [I]0-i walked to the window to occupy [myself]0-i with what was passing in [the street]163-the street ; and each time [I]0-i could not stay there for one minute together . [I]0-i went into [the picture - gallery]1211-the picture - gallery , looked along the walls , and yet knew not what [I]0-i was looking at . At last [I]0-i wandered into [[[my]0-i father]147-my father 's study]1213-my father 's study - [the only room [I]0-i had not yet visited]1214-the only room i had not yet visited .

A portrait of [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother hung over the fireplace : [my]0-i eyes turned towards it , and for the first time [I]0-i came to a long pause . The picture had an influence that quieted [me]0-i ; but what influence [I]0-i hardly knew . Perhaps it led [my]0-i spirit up to the spirit that had gone from [us]1216-us - perhaps those secret voices from [the unknown world]1217-the unknown world , which only the soul can listen to , were loosed at that moment , and spoke within [me]0-i . While [I]0-i sat looking up at the portrait , [I]0-i grew strangely and suddenly calm before it . [My]0-i memory flew back to a long illness that [I]0-i had suffered from , as [a child]226-a child , when [my]0-i little cradle - couch was placed by [[my]0-i mother]148-my mother 's bedside , and [she]148-my mother used to sit by [me]0-i in the dull evenings and hush [me]0-i to sleep . The remembrance of this brought with it a dread imagining that [she]148-my mother might now be hushing [my]0-i spirit , from [her]148-my mother place among [the angels of [God]37-god]1220-the angels of god . A stillness and awe crept over [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i hid [my]0-i face in [my]0-i hands .

The striking of the hour from a clock in [the room]263-the room , startled [me]0-i back to [the outer world]1222-the outer world . [I]0-i left [the house]244-the house and went at once to [North Villa]11-north villa .

[Margaret]44-margaret and [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father and [mother]1225-mother were in [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room when [I]0-i entered [it]1022-the drawing - room . [I]0-i saw immediately that [neither of [the two latter]1228-the two latter]1227-neither of the two latter had passed the morning calmly . The impending event of the day had exercised its agitating influence over [them]1228-the two latter , as well as over [me]0-i . [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin 's face was pale to [her]43-mrs. sherwin very lips : not a word escaped [her]43-mrs. sherwin . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin endeavoured to assume the self - possession which [he]42-mr. sherwin was evidently far from feeling , by walking briskly up and down [the room]263-the room , and talking incessantly - asking the most common - place questions , and making the most common - place jokes . [Margaret]44-margaret , to [my]0-i surprise , showed fewer symptoms of agitation than [either of [[her]44-margaret parents]1231-her parents]1230-either of her parents . Except when the colour came and went occasionally on [her]44-margaret cheek , [I]0-i could detect no outward evidences of emotion in [her]44-margaret at all .

[The church]185-the church was near at hand . As [we]1233-we proceeded to it , the rain fell heavily , and the mist of the morning was thickening to a fog . [We]1233-we had to wait in [the vestry]1234-the vestry for [the officiating clergyman]1235-the officiating clergyman . All the gloom and dampness of the day seemed to be collected in [this room]1236-this room - [a dark , cold , melancholy place]1237-a dark , cold , melancholy place , with one window which opened on [a burial - ground]1238-a burial - ground steaming in the wet . The rain pattered monotonously on [the pavement outside]1239-the pavement outside . While [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin exchanged remarks on the weather with [the clerk]1240-the clerk , [a tall , lean man]1241-a tall , lean man , arrayed in a black gown , [I]0-i sat silent , near [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin and [Margaret]44-margaret , looking with mechanical attention at the white surplices which hung before [me]0-i in a half - opened cupboard - at the bottle of water and tumbler , and the long - shaped books , bound in brown leather , which were on the table . [I]0-i was incapable of speaking - incapable even of thinking - during that interval of expectation .

At length [the clergyman]1242-the clergyman arrived , and [we]1233-we went into [the church]185-the church - [the church]185-the church , with [its]185-the church desolate array of empty pews , and [its]185-the church chill , heavy , week - day atmosphere . As [we]1233-we ranged [ourselves]1233-we round the altar , a confusion overspread all [my]0-i faculties . [My]0-i sense of the place [I]0-i was in , and even of the ceremony in which [I]0-i took part , grew more and more vague and doubtful every minute . [My]0-i attention wandered throughout the whole service . [I]0-i stammered and made mistakes in uttering the responses . Once or twice [I]0-i detected [myself]0-i in feeling impatient at the slow progress of the ceremony - it seemed to be doubly , trebly longer than its usual length . Mixed up with this impression was another , wild and monstrous as if it had been produced by a dream - an impression that [[my]0-i father]147-my father had discovered [my]0-i secret , and was watching [me]0-i from some hidden place in [the church]185-the church ; watching through the service , to denounce and abandon [me]0-i publicly at the end . This morbid fancy grew and grew on [me]0-i until the termination of the ceremony , until [we]1233-we had left [the church]185-the church and returned to [the vestry]1234-the vestry once more .

The fees were paid ; [we]1233-we wrote [our]1233-we names in the books and on the certificate ; [the clergyman]1242-the clergyman quietly wished [me]0-i happiness ; [the clerk]1240-the clerk solemnly imitated [him]1242-the clergyman ; the pew - opener smiled and curtseyed ; [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin made congratulatory speeches , kissed [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter , shook hands with [me]0-i , frowned a private rebuke at [[his]42-mr. sherwin wife]997-his wife for shedding tears , and , finally , led the way with [Margaret]44-margaret out of [the vestry]1234-the vestry . The rain was still falling , as [they]1254-they got into [the carriage]877-the carriage . The fog was still thickening , as [I]0-i stood alone under [the portico of [the church]185-the church]1256-the portico of the church , and tried to realise to [myself]0-i that [I]0-i was married .

Married ! [The son of [the proudest man in [England]1-england]1259-the proudest man in england , [the inheritor of a name written on the roll of Battle Abbey]1260-the inheritor of a name written on the roll of battle abbey , wedded to [[a linen - draper]783-a linen - draper 's daughter]786-a linen - draper 's daughter]1258-the son of the proudest man in england , the inheritor of a name written on the roll of battle abbey , wedded to a linen - draper 's daughter ! And what a marriage ! What a condition weighed on it ! What a probation was now to follow it ! Why had [I]0-i consented so easily to [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's proposals ? Would [he]42-mr. sherwin not have given way , if [I]0-i had only been resolute enough to insist on [my]0-i own conditions ?

How useless to inquire ! [I]0-i had made the engagement and must abide by it - abide by it cheerfully until the year was over , and [she]786-a linen - draper 's daughter was mine for ever . This must be [my]0-i all - sufficing thought for the future . No more reflections on consequences , no more forebodings about the effect of the disclosure of [my]0-i secret on [[my]0-i family]197-my family - the leap into a new life had been taken , and , lead where it might , it was a leap that could never be retraced !

[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin had insisted , with the immovable obstinacy which characterises [all feeble - minded people in the management of [their]1264-all feeble - minded people in the management of their important affairs important affairs]1264-all feeble - minded people in the management of their important affairs , that the first clause in [our]1265-our agreement the leaving [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife at [the church]185-the church - door should be performed to the letter . As a due compensation for this , [I]0-i was to dine at [North Villa]11-north villa that day . How should [I]0-i employ the interval that was to elapse before the dinner - hour ?

[I]0-i went [home]176-home , and had [my]0-i horse saddled . [I]0-i was in no mood for remaining in [an empty house]1269-an empty house , in no mood for calling on [any of [[my]0-i friends]1271-my friends]1270-any of my friends - [I]0-i was fit for nothing but a gallop through the rain . All [my]0-i wearing and depressing emotions of the morning , had now merged into a wild excitement of body and mind . When the horse was brought round , [I]0-i saw with delight that [the groom]738-the groom could hardly hold [him]1273-him . " Keep [him]1273-him well in hand , [Sir]3046-sir , "[696-the man] said [the man]696-the man , " [he]1273-him 's not been out for three days . "[696-the man] [I]0-i was just in the humour for such a ride as the caution promised [me]0-i .

And what a ride it was , when [I]0-i fairly got out of [London]10-london ; and the afternoon brightening of the foggy atmosphere , showed [the smooth , empty high road before [me]0-i]1275-the smooth , empty high road before me ! The dashing through the rain that still fell ; the feel of the long , powerful , regular stride of the horse under [me]0-i ; the thrill of that physical sympathy which establishes itself between [the man]696-the man and [the steed]1277-the steed ; the whirling past carts and waggons , saluted by the frantic barking of dogs inside [them]1278-them ; the flying by [roadside alehouses]1279-roadside alehouses , with the cheering of [boys]299-boys and [half - drunken men]1281-half - drunken men sounding for an instant behind [me]0-i , then lost in the distance - this was indeed to occupy , to hurry on , to annihilate the tardy hours of solitude on [my]0-i wedding day , exactly as [my]0-i heart desired !

[I]0-i got [home]176-home wet through ; but with [my]0-i body in a glow from the exercise , with [my]0-i spirits boiling up at fever heat . When [I]0-i arrived at [North Villa]11-north villa , the change in [my]0-i manner astonished [every one]1283-every one . At dinner , [I]0-i required no pressing now to partake of the sherry which [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin was so fond of extolling , nor of the port which [he]42-mr. sherwin brought out afterwards , with a preliminary account of the vintage - date of the wine , and the price of each bottle . [My]0-i spirits , factitious as they were , never flagged . Every time [I]0-i looked at [Margaret]44-margaret , the sight of [her]44-margaret stimulated [them]1284-them afresh . [She]44-margaret seemed pre - occupied , and was unusually silent during dinner ; but [her]44-margaret beauty was just that voluptuous beauty which is loveliest in repose . [I]0-i had never felt its influence so powerful over [me]0-i as [I]0-i felt it then .

In [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room , [Margaret]44-margaret 's manner grew more familiar , more confident towards [me]0-i than it had ever been before . [She]44-margaret spoke to [me]0-i in warmer tones , looked at [me]0-i with warmer looks . A hundred little incidents marked [our]1286-our wedding - evening - trifles that love treasures up - which still remain in [my]0-i memory . One among them , at least , will never depart from it : [I]0-i first kissed [her]44-margaret on that evening .

[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin had gone out of [the room]263-the room ; [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin was at the other end of it , watering some plants at the window ; [Margaret]44-margaret , by [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father 's desire , was showing [me]0-i some rare prints . [She]44-margaret handed [me]0-i a magnifying glass , through which [I]0-i was to look at a particular part of one of the engravings , that was considered a master - piece of delicate workmanship . Instead of applying the magnifying test to the print , for which [I]0-i cared nothing , [I]0-i laughingly applied it to [Margaret]44-margaret 's face . [Her]44-margaret lovely lustrous black eye seemed to flash into [mine]0-i through the glass ; [her]44-margaret warm , quick breathing played on [my]0-i cheek - it was but for an instant , and in that instant [I]0-i kissed [her]44-margaret for the first time . What sensations the kiss gave [me]0-i then ! - what remembrances it has left [me]0-i now !

It was one more proof how tenderly , how purely [I]0-i loved [her]44-margaret , that , before this time , [I]0-i had feared to take the first love - privilege which [I]0-i had longed to assert , and might well have asserted , before . [Men]518-men may not understand this ; [women]326-women , [I]0-i believe , will .

The hour of departure arrived ; the inexorable hour which was to separate [me]0-i from [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife on [my]0-i wedding evening . Shall [I]0-i confess what [I]0-i felt , on the first performance of [my]0-i ill - considered promise to [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin ? No : [I]0-i kept this a secret from [Margaret]44-margaret ; [I]0-i will keep it a secret here .

[I]0-i took leave of [her]44-margaret as hurriedly and abruptly as possible - [I]0-i could not trust [myself]0-i to quit [her]44-margaret in any other way . [She]44-margaret had contrived to slip aside into the darkest part of [the room]263-the room , so that [I]0-i only saw [her]44-margaret face dimly at parting .

[I]0-i went [home]176-home at once . When [I]0-i lay down to sleep - then the ordeal which [I]0-i had been unconsciously preparing for [myself]0-i throughout the day , began to try [me]0-i . Every nerve in [my]0-i body , strung up to the extremest point of tension since the morning , now at last gave way . [I]0-i felt [my]0-i limbs quivering , till the bed shook under [me]0-i . [I]0-i was possessed by a gloom and horror , caused by no thought , and producing no thought : the thinking faculty seemed paralysed within [me]0-i , altogether . The physical and mental reaction , after the fever and agitation of the day , was so sudden and severe , that the faintest noise from [the street]163-the street now terrified - yes , literally terrified [me]0-i . The whistling of the wind - which had risen since sunset - made [me]0-i start up in bed , with [my]0-i heart throbbing , and [my]0-i blood all chill . When no sounds were audible , then [I]0-i listened for [them]1295-them to come - listened breathlessly , without daring to move . At last , the agony of nervous prostration grew more than [I]0-i could bear - grew worse even than [the child]1296-the child 's horror of walking in the darkness , and sleeping alone on the bed - room floor , which had overcome [me]0-i , almost from the first moment when [I]0-i laid down . [I]0-i groped [my]0-i way to the table and lit the candle again ; then wrapped [my]0-i dressing - gown round [me]0-i , and sat shuddering near the light , to watch the weary hours out till morning .

And this was [my]0-i wedding - night ! This was how the day ended which had begun by [my]0-i marriage with [Margaret Sherwin]44-margaret !

PART II .

[I.]0-i

AN epoch in [my]0-i narrative has now arrived . Up to the time of [my]0-i marriage , [I]0-i have appeared as an active agent in the different events [I]0-i have described . After that period , and - with one or two exceptional cases - throughout the whole year of [my]0-i probation , [my]0-i position changed with the change in [my]0-i life , and became a passive one .

During this interval year , certain events happened , some of which , at the time , excited [my]0-i curiosity , but none [my]0-i apprehension - some affected [me]0-i with a temporary disappointment , but none with even a momentary suspicion . [I]0-i can now look back on them , as so many timely warnings which [I]0-i treated with fatal neglect . It is in these events that the history of the long year through which [I]0-i waited to claim [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife as [my]0-i own , is really comprised . They marked the lapse of time broadly and significantly ; and to [them]1298-them [I]0-i must now confine [myself]0-i , as exclusively as may be , in the present portion of [my]0-i narrative .

It will be first necessary , however , that [I]0-i should describe what was the nature of [my]0-i intercourse with [Margaret]44-margaret , during the probationary period which followed [our]1299-our marriage .

[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's anxiety was to make [my]0-i visits to [North]16-north Villa as few as possible : [he]42-mr. sherwin evidently feared the consequences of [my]0-i seeing [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter too often . But on this point , [I]0-i was resolute enough in asserting [my]0-i own interests , to overpower any resistance on [his]42-mr. sherwin part . [I]0-i required [him]42-mr. sherwin to concede to [me]0-i the right of seeing [Margaret]44-margaret every day - leaving all arrangements of time to depend on [his]42-mr. sherwin own convenience . After the due number of objections , [he]42-mr. sherwin reluctantly acquiesced in [my]0-i demand . [I]0-i was bound by no engagement whatever , limiting the number of [my]0-i visits to [Margaret]44-margaret ; and [I]0-i let [him]42-mr. sherwin see at the outset , that [I]0-i was now ready in [my]0-i turn , to impose conditions on [him]42-mr. sherwin , as [he]42-mr. sherwin had already imposed them on [me]0-i .

Accordingly , it was settled that [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i were to meet every day . [I]0-i usually saw [her]44-margaret in the evening . When any alteration in the hour of [my]0-i visit took place , that alteration was produced by the necessity which [we]1301-we all recognised alike of avoiding a meeting with [any of [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's friends]1303-mr. sherwin 's friends]1302-any of mr. sherwin 's friends .

Those portions of the day or the evening which [I]0-i spent with [Margaret]44-margaret , were seldom passed altogether in the Elysian idleness of love . Not content with only enumerating [[[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter 's school]1305-his daughter 's school - accomplishments to [me]0-i at [our]1301-we first interview , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin boastfully referred to them again and again , on many subsequent occasions ; and even obliged [Margaret]44-margaret to display before [me]0-i , some of [her]44-margaret knowledge of languages - which [he]42-mr. sherwin never forgot to remind [us]1301-we had been lavishly paid for out of [his]42-mr. sherwin own pocket . It was at one of these exhibitions that the idea occurred to [me]0-i of making a new pleasure for [myself]0-i out of [[Margaret]44-margaret 's society]1306-margaret 's society , by teaching [her]44-margaret really to appreciate and enjoy the literature which [she]44-margaret had evidently hitherto only studied as a task . [My]0-i fancy revelled by anticipation in all the delights of such an employment as this . It would be like acting the story of [Abelard]59-abelard and [Heloise]60-heloise over again - reviving all the poetry and romance in which those immortal love - studies of old had begun , with none of the guilt and none of the misery that had darkened their end .

[I]0-i had a definite purpose , besides , in wishing to assume the direction of [Margaret]44-margaret 's studies . Whenever the secret of [my]0-i marriage was revealed , [my]0-i pride was concerned in being able to show [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife to [every one]1283-every one , as the all - sufficient excuse for any imprudence [I]0-i might have committed for [her]864-my wife sake . [I]0-i was determined that [[my]0-i father]147-my father , especially , should have no other argument against [her]864-my wife than the one ungracious argument of [her]864-my wife birth - that [he]147-my father should see [her]864-my wife , fitted by the beauty of [her]864-my wife mind , as well as by all [her]864-my wife other beauties , for the highest station that society could offer . The thought of this gave [me]0-i fresh ardour in [my]0-i project ; [I]0-i assumed [my]0-i new duties without delay , and continued them with a happiness which never once suffered even a momentary decrease .

Of all the pleasures which [a man]3101-a man finds in the society of [a woman whom [he]3101-a man loves]1311-a woman whom he loves , are there any superior , are there many equal , to the pleasure of reading out of the same book with [her]864-my wife ? On what other occasion do the sweet familiarities of the sweetest of all companionships last so long without cloying , and pass and re - pass so naturally , so delicately , so inexhaustibly between [you]1312-your and [her]864-my wife ? When is [your]1312-your face so constantly close to [hers]864-my wife as it is then ? - when can [your]1312-your hair mingle with [hers]864-my wife , [your]1312-your cheek touch [hers]864-my wife , [your]1312-your eyes meet [hers]864-my wife , so often as they can then ? That is , of all times , the only time when [you]1312-your can breathe with [her]864-my wife breath for hours together ; feel every little warming of the colour on [her]864-my wife cheek marking its own changes on the temperature of [yours]1312-your ; follow every slight fluttering of [her]864-my wife bosom , every faint gradation of [her]864-my wife sighs , as if [her]864-my wife heart was beating , [her]864-my wife life glowing , within [yours]1312-your . Surely it is then - if ever - that [we]1313-we realize , almost revive , in [ourselves]1313-we , the love of [the first two of [our]1313-we race]1314-the first two of our race , when [angels]1315-angels walked with [them]1314-the first two of our race on [the same garden paths]1316-the same garden paths , and [their]1314-the first two of our race hearts were pure from the pollution of the fatal tree !

Evening after evening passed away - one more happily than another - in what [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i called [our]1313-we lessons . Never were lessons of literature so like lessons of love [We]1313-we read oftenest [the lighter Italian poets]1317-the lighter italian poets - [we]1313-we studied the poetry of love , written in the language of love . But , as for the steady , utilitarian purpose [I]0-i had proposed to [myself]0-i of practically improving [Margaret]44-margaret 's intellect , that was a purpose which insensibly and deceitfully abandoned [me]0-i as completely as if it had never existed . The little serious teaching [I]0-i tried with [her]44-margaret at first , led to very poor results . Perhaps , [the lover]1318-the lover interfered too much with [the tutor]1319-the tutor ; perhaps , [I]0-i had over - estimated the fertility of the faculties [I]0-i designed to cultivate - but [I]0-i cared not , and thought not to inquire where the fault lay , then . [I]0-i gave [myself]0-i up unreservedly to the exquisite sensations which the mere act of looking on the same page with [Margaret]44-margaret procured for [me]0-i ; and neither detected , nor wished to detect , that it was [I]0-i who read the difficult passages , and left only a few even of the very easiest to be attempted by [her]44-margaret .

Happily for [my]0-i patience under the trial imposed on [me]0-i by the terms on which [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's restrictions , and [my]0-i promise to obey [them]1320-them , obliged [me]0-i to live with [Margaret]44-margaret , it was [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin who was generally selected to remain in [the room]263-the room with [us]1322-us . By [no one]743-no one could such ungrateful duties of supervision as those imposed on [her]44-margaret , have been more delicately and more considerately performed .

[She]44-margaret always kept far enough away to be out of hearing when [we]1322-us whispered to [each other]102-each other . [We]1322-us rarely detected [her]44-margaret even in looking at [us]1322-us . [She]44-margaret had a way of sitting for hours together in the same part of [the room]263-the room , without ever changing [her]44-margaret position , without occupation of any kind , without uttering a word , or breathing a sigh . [I]0-i soon discovered that [she]44-margaret was not lost in thought , at these periods as [I]0-i had at first supposed : but lost in a strange lethargy of body and mind ; a comfortless , waking trance , into which [she]44-margaret fell from sheer physical weakness - it was like the vacancy and feebleness of a first convalescence , after a long illness . [She]44-margaret never changed : never looked better , never worse . [I]0-i often spoke to [her]44-margaret : [I]0-i tried hard to show [my]0-i sympathy , and win [her]44-margaret confidence and friendship . [The poor lady]1326-the poor lady was always thankful , always spoke to [me]0-i gratefully and kindly , but very briefly . [She]44-margaret never told [me]0-i what were [her]44-margaret sufferings or [her]44-margaret sorrows . The story of that lonely , lingering life was an impenetrable mystery for [[her]44-margaret own family]1327-her own family - for [[her]44-margaret husband]480-her husband and [[her]44-margaret daughter]1101-her daughter , as well as for [me]0-i . It was a secret between [her]44-margaret and [God]37-god .

With [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin as [the guardian]1330-the guardian to watch over [Margaret]44-margaret , it may easily be imagined that [I]0-i felt none of the heavier oppressions of restraint . [Her]44-margaret presence , as [the third person]1331-the third person appointed to remain with [us]1332-us , was not enough to repress the little endearments to which each evening 's lesson gave rise ; but was just sufficiently perceptible to invest them with the character of stolen endearments , and to make them all the more precious on that very account . [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin never knew , [I]0-i never thoroughly knew [myself]0-i till later , how much of the secret of [my]0-i patience under [my]0-i year 's probation lay in [her]44-margaret conduct , while [she]44-margaret was sitting in [the room]263-the room with [Margaret]44-margaret and [me]0-i .

In this solitude where [I]0-i now write - in the change of life and of all life 's hopes and enjoyments which has come over [me]0-i - when [I]0-i look back to those evenings at [North Villa]11-north villa , [I]0-i shudder as [I]0-i look . At this moment , [I]0-i see [the room]263-the room again - as in a dream - with the little round table , the reading lamp , and the open books . [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i are sitting together : [her]44-margaret hand is in [mine]0-i ; [my]0-i heart is with [hers]44-margaret . Love , and Youth , and Beauty - the mortal Trinity of [this world]195-this world 's worship - are there , in [that quiet softly - lit room]1336-that quiet softly - lit room ; but not alone . Away in the dim light behind , is [a solitary figure , ever mournful and ever still]1337-a solitary figure , ever mournful and ever still . It is [a woman]325-a woman 's form ; but how wasted and how weak ! - [a woman]325-a woman 's face ; but how ghastly and changeless , with those eyes that are vacant , those lips that are motionless , those cheeks that the blood never tinges , that the freshness of health and happiness shall never visit again ! Woeful , [warning figure of dumb sorrow and patient pain , to fill the background of a picture of Love , and Beauty , and Youth]1340-warning figure of dumb sorrow and patient pain , to fill the background of a picture of love , and beauty , and youth !

[I]0-i am straying from [my]0-i task . Let [me]0-i return to [my]0-i narrative : its course begins to darken before [me]0-i apace , while [I]0-i now write .

The partial restraint and embarrassment , caused at first by the strange terms on which [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife and [I]0-i were living together , gradually vanished before the frequency of [my]0-i visits to [North Villa]11-north villa . [We]1342-we soon began to speak with all the ease , all the unpremeditated frankness of a long intimacy . [Margaret]44-margaret 's powers of conversation were generally only employed to lead [me]0-i to exert [mine]0-i . [She]44-margaret was never tired of inducing [me]0-i to speak of [[my]0-i family]197-my family . [She]44-margaret listened with every appearance of interest , while [I]0-i talked of [[my]0-i father]147-my father , [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , or [[my]0-i elder brother]149-my elder brother ; but whenever [she]44-margaret questioned [me]0-i directly about any of [them]1347-their , [her]44-margaret inquiries invariably led away from [their]1347-their characters and dispositions , to [their]1347-their personal appearance , [their]1347-their every - day habits , [their]1347-their dress , [their]1347-their intercourse with [the gay world]1348-the gay world , the things [they]1347-their spent [their]1347-their money on , and other topics of a similar nature .

For instance ; [she]44-margaret always listened , and listened attentively , to what [I]0-i told [her]44-margaret of [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's character , and of the principles which regulated [his]147-my father life . [She]44-margaret showed every disposition to profit by the instructions [I]0-i gave [her]44-margaret beforehand , about how [she]44-margaret should treat [his]147-my father peculiarities when [she]44-margaret was introduced to [him]147-my father . But , on all these occasions , what really interested [her]44-margaret most , was to hear how many [servants]1350-servants waited on [him]147-my father ; how often [he]147-my father went to [Court]1351-court ; how many [lords]1352-lords and [ladies]1353-ladies [he]147-my father knew ; what [he]147-my father said or did to [[his]147-my father servants]1354-his servants , when [they]1354-his servants committed mistakes ; whether [he]147-my father was ever angry with [[his]147-my father children]278-his children for asking [him]147-my father for money ; and whether [he]147-my father limited [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister to any given number of dresses in the course of the year ?

Again ; whenever [our]1357-our conversation turned on [Clara]57-clara , if [I]0-i began by describing [her]57-clara kindness , [her]57-clara gentleness and goodness , [her]57-clara simple winning manners - [I]0-i was sure to be led insensibly into a digression about [her]57-clara height , figure , complexion , and style of dress . The latter subject especially interested [Margaret]44-margaret ; [she]44-margaret could question [me]0-i on it , over and over again . What was [Clara]57-clara 's usual morning dress ? How did [she]57-clara wear [her]57-clara hair ? What was [her]57-clara evening dress ? Did [she]57-clara make a difference between a dinner party and a ball ? What colours did [she]57-clara prefer ? What [dressmaker]1358-dressmaker did [she]57-clara employ ? Did [she]57-clara wear much jewellery ? Which did [she]57-clara like best in [her]57-clara hair , and which were most fashionable , flowers or pearls ? How many new dresses did [she]57-clara have in a year ; and was there more than [one maid]1359-one maid especially to attend on [her]57-clara ?

Then , again : Had [she]57-clara [a carriage of [her]57-clara own]1360-a carriage of her own ? What [ladies]1353-ladies took care of [her]57-clara when [she]57-clara went out ? Did [she]57-clara like dancing ? What were the fashionable dances at [[noblemen]1362-noblemen 's houses]1363-noblemen 's houses ? Did [young ladies in [the great world]1365-the great world]1364-young ladies in the great world practise the pianoforte much ? How many offers had [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister had ? Did [she]296-my sister go to [Court]1351-court , as well as [[my]0-i father]147-my father ? What did [she]57-clara talk about to [gentlemen]3323-gentlemen , and what did [gentlemen]3323-gentlemen talk about to [her]57-clara ? If [she]57-clara were speaking to [a duke]225-a duke , how often would [she]57-clara say " [your]225-a duke Grace "[57-clara] to [him]225-a duke ? and would [a duke]225-a duke get [her]57-clara a chair , or an ice , and wait on [her]57-clara just as [gentlemen without titles]1373-gentlemen without titles waited on [ladies]1353-ladies , when [they]1373-gentlemen without titles met [them]1353-ladies in [society]1375-society ?

[My]0-i replies to these and hundreds of other questions like them , were received by [Margaret]44-margaret with the most eager attention . On the favourite subject of [Clara]57-clara 's dresses , [my]0-i answers were an unending source of amusement and pleasure to [her]57-clara . [She]57-clara especially enjoyed overcoming the difficulties of interpreting aright [my]0-i clumsy , circumlocutory phrases in attempting to describe shawls , gowns , and bonnets ; and taught [me]0-i the exact millinery language which [I]0-i ought to have made use of with an arch expression of triumph and a burlesque earnestness of manner , that always enchanted [me]0-i . At that time , every word [she]57-clara uttered , no matter how frivolous , was the sweetest of all music to [my]0-i ears . It was only by the stern test of after - events that [I]0-i learnt to analyse [her]57-clara conversation . Sometimes , when [I]0-i was away from [her]57-clara , [I]0-i might think of leading [her]57-clara girlish curiosity to higher things ; but when [we]1376-we met again , the thought vanished ; and it became delight enough for [me]0-i simply to hear [her]57-clara speak , without once caring or considering what [she]57-clara spoke of .

Those were the days when [I]0-i lived happy and unreflecting in the broad sunshine of joy which love showered round [me]0-i - [my]0-i eyes were dazzled ; [my]0-i mind lay asleep under it . Once or twice , a cloud came threatening , with chill and shadowy influence ; but it passed away , and then the sunshine returned to [me]0-i , the same sunshine that it was before .

II .

The first change that passed over the calm uniformity of the life at [North Villa]11-north villa , came in this manner :

One evening , on entering [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room , [I]0-i missed [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin ; and found to [my]0-i great disappointment that [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband was apparently settled [there]161-there for the evening . [He]480-her husband looked a little flurried , and was more restless than usual . [His]480-her husband first words , as [we]1376-we met , informed [me]0-i of an event in which [he]480-her husband appeared to take the deepest interest .

" News , [[my]480-her husband dear sir]3140-my dear sir ! "[480-her husband] [he]480-her husband said . " [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion has come back - at least two days before [I]480-her husband expected [him]51-mr. mannion ! "[480-her husband]

At first , [I]0-i felt inclined to ask who [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion was , and what consequence it could possibly be to [me]0-i that [he]51-mr. mannion had come back . But immediately afterwards , [I]0-i remembered that [this Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's name had been mentioned during [my]0-i first conversation with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin ; and then [I]0-i recalled to mind the description [I]0-i had heard of [him]480-her husband , as " [confidential clerk]3341-confidential clerk ; "[0-i] as forty years of age ; and as [an educated man]1380-an educated man , who had made [his]480-her husband information of some use to [Margaret]44-margaret in keeping up the knowledge [she]44-margaret had acquired at [school]344-school . [I]0-i knew no more than this about [him]480-her husband , and [I]0-i felt no curiosity to discover more from [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin .

[Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i sat down as usual with [our]1382-our books about [us]1382-our .

There had been something a little hurried and abrupt in [her]44-margaret manner of receiving [me]0-i , when [I]0-i came in . When [we]1382-our began to read , [her]44-margaret attention wandered incessantly ; [she]44-margaret looked round several times towards the door . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin walked about [the room]263-the room without intermission , except when [he]42-mr. sherwin once paused on [his]42-mr. sherwin restless course , to tell [me]0-i that [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion was coming that evening ; and that [he]42-mr. sherwin hoped [I]0-i should have no objection to be introduced to [a person who was " quite like [one of [the family]179-the family]3343-one of the family , and well enough read to be sure to please [a great reader like [me]42-mr. sherwin]3345-a great reader like me]3342-a person who was " quite like one of the family , and well enough read to be sure to please a great reader like me . "[42-mr. sherwin] [I]0-i asked [myself]0-i rather impatiently , who was this [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , that [his]51-mr. mannion arrival at [[[his]51-mr. mannion employer]1384-his employer 's house]1385-his employer 's house should make a sensation ? When [I]0-i whispered something of this to [Margaret]44-margaret , [she]44-margaret smiled rather uneasily , and said nothing .

At last the bell was rung . [Margaret]44-margaret started a little at the sound . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin sat down ; composing [himself]42-mr. sherwin into rather an elaborate attitude - the door opened , and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion came in .

[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin received [[his]42-mr. sherwin clerk]1386-his clerk with the assumed superiority of [the master]1387-the master in [his]42-mr. sherwin words ; but [his]42-mr. sherwin tones and manner flatly contradicted them . [Margaret]44-margaret rose hastily , and then as hastily sat down again , while [the visitor]1388-the visitor very respectfully took [her]44-margaret hand , and made the usual inquiries . After this , [he]1388-the visitor was introduced to [me]0-i ; and then [Margaret]44-margaret was sent away to summon [[her]44-margaret mother]319-her mother down [stairs]1197-stairs . While [she]44-margaret was out of [the room]263-the room , there was nothing to distract [my]0-i attention from [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion . [I]0-i looked at [him]51-mr. mannion with a curiosity and interest , Which [I]0-i could hardly account for at first .

If extraordinary regularity of feature were alone sufficient to make [a handsome man]1392-a handsome man , then [this confidential clerk of [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's]1393-this confidential clerk of mr. sherwin 's was assuredly [one of [the handsomest men [I]0-i ever beheld]1395-the handsomest men i ever beheld]1394-one of the handsomest men i ever beheld . Viewed separately from the head which was rather large , both in front and behind [his]51-mr. mannion face exhibited , throughout , an almost perfect symmetry of proportion . [His]51-mr. mannion bald forehead was smooth and massive as marble ; [his]51-mr. mannion high brow and thin eyelids had the firmness and immobility of marble , and seemed as cold ; [his]51-mr. mannion delicately - formed lips , when [he]51-mr. mannion was not speaking , closed habitually , as changelessly still as if no breath of life ever passed them . There was not a wrinkle or line anywhere on [his]51-mr. mannion face . But for the baldness in front , and the greyness of the hair at the back and sides of [his]51-mr. mannion head , it would have been impossible from [his]51-mr. mannion appearance to have guessed [his]51-mr. mannion age , even within ten years of what it really was .

Such was [his]51-mr. mannion countenance in point of form ; but in that which is the outward assertion of [our]1396-our immortality - in expression - it was , as [I]0-i now beheld it , an utter void . Never had [I]0-i before seen any human face which baffled all inquiry like [his]51-mr. mannion . No mask could have been made expressionless enough to resemble it ; and yet it looked like a mask . It told [you]1397-you nothing of [his]51-mr. mannion thoughts , when [he]51-mr. mannion spoke : nothing of [his]51-mr. mannion disposition , when [he]51-mr. mannion was silent . [His]51-mr. mannion cold grey eyes gave [you]1397-you no help in trying to study [him]51-mr. mannion . They never varied from the steady , straightforward look , which was exactly the same for [Margaret]44-margaret as it was for [me]0-i ; for [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin as for [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin - exactly the same whether [he]51-mr. mannion spoke or whether [he]51-mr. mannion listened ; whether [he]51-mr. mannion talked of indifferent , or of important matters . Who was [he]51-mr. mannion ? What was [he]51-mr. mannion ? [His]51-mr. mannion name and calling were poor replies to those questions . Was [he]51-mr. mannion naturally cold and unimpressible at heart ? or had some fierce passion , some terrible sorrow , ravaged the life within [him]51-mr. mannion , and left it dead for ever after ? Impossible to conjecture ! There was the impenetrable face before [you]1397-you , wholly inexpressive - so inexpressive that it did not even look vacant - a mystery for [your]1397-you eyes and [your]1397-you mind to dwell on - hiding something ; but whether vice or virtue [you]1397-you could not tell .

[He]51-mr. mannion was dressed as unobtrusively as possible , entirely in black ; and was rather above the middle height . [His]51-mr. mannion manner was the only part of [him]51-mr. mannion that betrayed anything to the observation of [others]98-others . Viewed in connection with [his]51-mr. mannion station , [his]51-mr. mannion demeanour unobtrusive though it was proclaimed itself as above [his]51-mr. mannion position in [the world]158-the world . [He]51-mr. mannion had all the quietness and self - possession of [a gentleman]3111-a gentleman . [He]51-mr. mannion maintained [his]51-mr. mannion respectful bearing , without the slightest appearance of cringing ; and displayed a decision , both in word and action , that could never be mistaken for obstinacy or over - confidence . Before [I]0-i had been in [his]51-mr. mannion company five minutes , [his]51-mr. mannion manner assured [me]0-i that [he]51-mr. mannion must have descended to the position [he]51-mr. mannion now occupied .

On [his]51-mr. mannion introduction to [me]0-i , [he]51-mr. mannion bowed without saying anything . When [he]51-mr. mannion spoke to [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , [his]51-mr. mannion voice was as void of expression as [his]51-mr. mannion face : it was rather low in tone , but singularly distinct in utterance . [He]51-mr. mannion spoke deliberately , but with no emphasis on particular words , and without hesitation in choosing [his]51-mr. mannion terms .

When [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin came down , [I]0-i watched [her]43-mrs. sherwin conduct towards [him]51-mr. mannion . [She]43-mrs. sherwin could not repress a slight nervous shrinking , when [he]51-mr. mannion approached and placed a chair for [her]43-mrs. sherwin . In answering [his]51-mr. mannion inquiries after [her]43-mrs. sherwin health , [she]43-mrs. sherwin never once looked at [him]51-mr. mannion ; but fixed [her]43-mrs. sherwin eyes all the time on [Margaret]44-margaret and [me]0-i , with a sad , anxious expression , wholly indescribable , which often recurred to [my]0-i memory after that day . [She]43-mrs. sherwin always looked more or less frightened , poor thing , in [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband 's presence ; but [she]43-mrs. sherwin seemed positively awe - struck before [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion .

In truth , [my]0-i first observation of [this so - called clerk]1402-this so - called clerk , at [North Villa]11-north villa , was enough to convince [me]0-i that [he]51-mr. mannion was [master there]1403-master there - master in [his]51-mr. mannion own quiet , unobtrusive way . [That man]212-that man 's character , of whatever elements it might be composed , was a character that ruled . [I]0-i could not see this in [his]51-mr. mannion face , or detect it in [his]51-mr. mannion words ; but [I]0-i could discover it in the looks and manners of [[his]51-mr. mannion employer]1384-his employer and [[[his]51-mr. mannion employer]1384-his employer 's family]1407-his employer 's family , as [he]51-mr. mannion now sat at the same table with [them]1408-them . [Margaret]44-margaret 's eyes avoided [his]51-mr. mannion countenance much less frequently than the eyes of [[her]44-margaret parents]1231-her parents ; but then [he]51-mr. mannion rarely looked at [her]44-margaret in return - rarely looked at [her]44-margaret at all , except when common courtesy obliged [him]51-mr. mannion to do so .

If [any one]1410-any one had told [me]0-i beforehand , that [I]0-i should suspend [my]0-i ordinary evening 's occupation with [[my]0-i young wife]1411-my young wife , for the sake of observing [the very man who had interrupted it]1412-the very man who had interrupted it , and [that man]212-that man only [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's clerk]1414-mr. sherwin 's clerk , [I]0-i should have laughed at the idea . Yet so it was . [Our]1415-our books lay neglected on the table - neglected by [me]0-i , perhaps by [Margaret]44-margaret too , for [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion .

[His]51-mr. mannion conversation , on this occasion at least , baffled all curiosity as completely as [his]51-mr. mannion face . [I]0-i tried to lead [him]51-mr. mannion to talk . [He]51-mr. mannion just answered [me]0-i , and that was all ; speaking with great respect of manner and phrase , very intelligibly , but very briefly . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin - after referring to the business expedition on which [he]51-mr. mannion had been absent , for the purchase of silks at [Lyons]13-lyons - asked [him]51-mr. mannion some questions about [France]2-france and [the French]1416-the french , which evidently proceeded from the most ludicrous ignorance both of [the country]370-the country and [the people]1418-the people . [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion just set [him]51-mr. mannion right ; and did no more . There was not the smallest inflection of sarcasm in [his]51-mr. mannion voice , not the slightest look of sarcasm in [his]51-mr. mannion eye , while [he]51-mr. mannion spoke . When [we]1419-we talked among [ourselves]1419-we , [he]51-mr. mannion did not join in the conversation ; but sat quietly waiting until [he]51-mr. mannion might be pointedly and personally addressed again . At these times a suspicion crossed [my]0-i mind that [he]51-mr. mannion might really be studying [my]0-i character , as [I]0-i was vainly trying to study [his]51-mr. mannion ; and [I]0-i often turned suddenly round on [him]51-mr. mannion , to see whether [he]51-mr. mannion was looking at [me]0-i . This was never the case . [His]51-mr. mannion hard , chill grey eyes were not on [me]0-i , and not on [Margaret]44-margaret : they rested most frequently on [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin , who always shrank before [them]1420-them .

After staying little more than half an hour , [he]51-mr. mannion rose to go away . While [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin was vainly pressing [him]51-mr. mannion to remain longer , [I]0-i walked to the round table at the other end of [the room]263-the room , on which the book was placed that [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i had intended to read during the evening . [I]0-i was standing by the table when [he]51-mr. mannion came to take leave of [me]0-i . [He]51-mr. mannion just glanced at the volume under [my]0-i hand , and said in tones too low to be heard at the other end of [the room]263-the room :

" [I]51-mr. mannion hope [my]51-mr. mannion arrival has not interrupted any occupation to - night , [Sir]3046-sir . [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , aware of the interest [I]51-mr. mannion must feel in whatever concerns [the family of [an employer whom [I]51-mr. mannion have served for years]3348-an employer whom i have served for years , has informed [me]51-mr. mannion in confidence - a confidence which [I]51-mr. mannion know how to respect and preserve - of [your]3046-sir marriage with [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter , and of the peculiar circumstances under which the marriage has been contracted]3347-the family of an employer whom i have served for years , has informed me in confidence - a confidence which i know how to respect and preserve - of your marriage with his daughter , and of the peculiar circumstances under which the marriage has been contracted . [I]51-mr. mannion may at least venture to congratulate [the young lady]774-the young lady on a change of life which must procure [her]774-the young lady happiness , having begun already by procuring the increase of [her]774-the young lady mental resources and pleasures . "[51-mr. mannion] [He]51-mr. mannion bowed , and pointed to the book on the table .

" [I]0-i believe , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " that [you]51-mr. mannion have been of great assistance in laying a foundation for the studies to which [I]0-i presume [you]51-mr. mannion refer . "[0-i]

" [I]51-mr. mannion endeavoured to make [myself]51-mr. mannion useful in that way , [Sir]3046-sir , as in all others , when [[my]51-mr. mannion employer]3352-my employer desired it . "[51-mr. mannion] [He]51-mr. mannion bowed again , as [he]51-mr. mannion said this ; and then went out , followed by [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , who held a short colloquy with [him]51-mr. mannion in [the hall]1423-the hall .

What had [he]51-mr. mannion said to [me]0-i ? Only a few civil words , spoken in a very respectful manner . There had been nothing in [his]51-mr. mannion tones , nothing in [his]51-mr. mannion looks , to give any peculiar significance to what [he]51-mr. mannion uttered . Still , the moment [his]51-mr. mannion back was turned , [I]0-i found [myself]0-i speculating whether [his]51-mr. mannion words contained any hidden meaning ; trying to recall something in [his]51-mr. mannion voice or manner which might guide [me]0-i in discovering the real sense [he]51-mr. mannion attached to what [he]51-mr. mannion said . It seemed as if the most powerful whet to [my]0-i curiosity , were supplied by [my]0-i own experience of the impossibility of penetrating beneath the unassailable surface which [this man]656-this man presented to [me]0-i .

[I]0-i questioned [Margaret]44-margaret about [him]51-mr. mannion . [She]44-margaret could not tell [me]0-i more than [I]0-i knew already . [He]51-mr. mannion had always been very kind and useful ; [he]51-mr. mannion was [a clever man]1425-a clever man , and could talk a great deal sometimes , when [he]51-mr. mannion chose ; and [he]51-mr. mannion had taught [her]44-margaret more of foreign languages and foreign literature in a month , than [she]44-margaret had learned at school in a year . While [she]44-margaret was telling [me]0-i this , [I]0-i hardly noticed that [she]44-margaret spoke in a very hurried manner , and busied [herself]44-margaret in arranging the books and work that lay on the table . [My]0-i attention was more closely directed to [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin . To [my]0-i surprise , [I]0-i saw [her]43-mrs. sherwin eagerly lean forward while [Margaret]44-margaret was speaking , and fix [her]43-mrs. sherwin eyes on [[her]43-mrs. sherwin daughter]1101-her daughter with a look of penetrating scrutiny , of which [I]0-i could never have supposed [a person]1427-a person usually so feeble and unenergetic to be capable . [I]0-i thought of transferring to [her]43-mrs. sherwin [my]0-i questionings on the subject of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion ; but at that moment [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband entered [the room]263-the room , and [I]0-i addressed [myself]0-i for further enlightenment to [him]480-her husband .

" Aha ! "[42-mr. sherwin] - cried [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , rubbing [his]42-mr. sherwin hands triumphantly - " [I]42-mr. sherwin knew [Mannion]51-mr. mannion would please [you]0-i . [Curious looking person]3355-curious looking person - is n't [he]51-mr. mannion ? "[42-mr. sherwin]

" So curious , that [I]42-mr. sherwin may safely say [I]42-mr. sherwin never saw a face in the slightest degree resembling [his]51-mr. mannion in [my]42-mr. sherwin life . [[Your]0-i clerk]3356-your clerk , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , is a complete walking mystery that [I]42-mr. sherwin want to solve . [Margaret]44-margaret can not give [me]42-mr. sherwin much help , [I]42-mr. sherwin am afraid . " Do n't do any such thing ! [You]0-i 'll be quite in the wrong box [there]161-there . " What can [you]42-mr. sherwin tell [me]42-mr. sherwin about [him]51-mr. mannion [yourself]42-mr. sherwin , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin ? "[42-mr. sherwin]

" [I]42-mr. sherwin can tell [you]0-i there 's not [a house of business in [London]10-london]3358-a house of business in london has such [a managing man]3359-a managing man as [he]51-mr. mannion is : [he]51-mr. mannion 's [[my]42-mr. sherwin factotum]3360-my factotum - [my]42-mr. sherwin right hand , in short ; and [my]42-mr. sherwin left too , for the matter of that . [He]51-mr. mannion understands [my]42-mr. sherwin ways of doing business ; and , in fact , carries things out in first - rate style . [Poor devils]3363-poor devils ! [He]51-mr. mannion 's [a quiet , steady - going , regular dragon]3365-a quiet , steady - going , regular dragon at [his]51-mr. mannion work - [he]51-mr. mannion is ! That 's what [I]42-mr. sherwin call having a treasure ! And yet , though [he]51-mr. mannion 's been with [us]3375-us for years , [Mrs.]3376-mrs. " Do [you]42-mr. sherwin know how [he]51-mr. mannion was employed before [he]51-mr. mannion came to [you]42-mr. sherwin ? "[42-mr. sherwin]

" Ah ! now [you]42-mr. sherwin 've hit it - that 's where [you]42-mr. sherwin 're right in saying [he]51-mr. mannion 's a mystery . What [he]51-mr. mannion did before [I]42-mr. sherwin knew [him]51-mr. mannion , is more than [I]42-mr. sherwin can tell - a good deal more . [He]51-mr. mannion came to [me]42-mr. sherwin with a capital recommendation and security , from [a gentleman whom [I]42-mr. sherwin knew to be of the highest respectability]3378-a gentleman whom i knew to be of the highest respectability . [I]42-mr. sherwin had a vacancy in [the back office]3379-the back office , and tried [him]51-mr. mannion , and found out what [he]51-mr. mannion was worth , in no time - [I]42-mr. sherwin flatter [myself]42-mr. sherwin [I]42-mr. sherwin 've a knack at that with [everybody]361-everybody . Well : before [I]42-mr. sherwin got used to [his]51-mr. mannion curious - looking face , and [his]51-mr. mannion quiet ways , [I]42-mr. sherwin wanted badly enough to know something about [him]51-mr. mannion , and who [his]51-mr. mannion connections were . First , [I]42-mr. sherwin asked [[his]51-mr. mannion friend who had recommended [him]51-mr. mannion]3381-his friend who had recommended him - [the friend]3382-the friend was n't at liberty to answer for anything but [his]51-mr. mannion perfect trustworthiness . Then [I]42-mr. sherwin asked [Mannion]51-mr. mannion [himself]51-mr. mannion point - blank about it , one day . [He]51-mr. mannion just told [me]42-mr. sherwin that [he]51-mr. mannion had reasons for keeping [his]51-mr. mannion family affairs to [himself]51-mr. mannion - nothing more - but [you]3383-you know the way [he]51-mr. mannion has with [him]51-mr. mannion ; and , damn it , [he]51-mr. mannion put the stopper on [me]42-mr. sherwin , from that time to this . [I]42-mr. sherwin was n't going to risk losing [the best clerk that [ever man]3385-ever man]3384-the best clerk that ever man had , by worrying [him]51-mr. mannion about [his]51-mr. mannion secrets . [They]3386-they did n't interfere with business , and did n't interfere with [me]42-mr. sherwin ; so [I]42-mr. sherwin put [my]42-mr. sherwin curiosity in [my]42-mr. sherwin pocket . [I]42-mr. sherwin know nothing about [him]51-mr. mannion , but that [he]51-mr. mannion 's [[my]42-mr. sherwin right - hand man]3387-my right - hand man , and [the honestest fellow that ever stood in shoes]3388-the honestest fellow that ever stood in shoes . [He]51-mr. mannion may be [the Great Mogul]3389-the great mogul [himself]51-mr. mannion , in disguise , for anything [I]42-mr. sherwin care ! In short , [you]42-mr. sherwin may be able to find out all about [him]51-mr. mannion , [[my]42-mr. sherwin dear Sir]3140-my dear sir ; but [I]42-mr. sherwin ca n't . "[42-mr. sherwin]

" There does not seem much chance for [me]42-mr. sherwin , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , after what [you]42-mr. sherwin have said . "[42-mr. sherwin]

" Well : [I]42-mr. sherwin 'm not so sure of that - plenty of chances here , [you]42-mr. sherwin know . [You]42-mr. sherwin 'll see [him]51-mr. mannion often enough : [he]51-mr. mannion lives near , and drops in constantly of evenings . [We]3391-we settle business matters that wo n't come into business hours , in [[my]42-mr. sherwin private snuggery up [stairs]1197-stairs]3392-my private snuggery up stairs . Ah ! [Mrs. S.]53-mrs. s. , [you]42-mr. sherwin may stare , [Ma'am]61-ma'am ; but [I]42-mr. sherwin say again , [he]51-mr. mannion 's [one of [the family]179-the family]3343-one of the family ; may be , [he]51-mr. mannion 'll be [[my]42-mr. sherwin partner]3398-my partner some of these days - [you]42-mr. sherwin 'll have to get used to [him]51-mr. mannion then , whether [you]42-mr. sherwin like it or not . "[42-mr. sherwin]

" One more question : is [he]51-mr. mannion married or single ? "[42-mr. sherwin]

" Single , to be sure - [a regular old bachelor]3399-a regular old bachelor , if ever there was one yet . "[42-mr. sherwin]

During the whole time [we]1430-us had been speaking , [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin had looked at [us]1430-us with far more earnestness and attention than [I]0-i had ever seen [her]43-mrs. sherwin display before . Even [her]43-mrs. sherwin languid faculties seemed susceptible of active curiosity on the subject of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion - the more so , perhaps , from [her]43-mrs. sherwin very dislike of [him]51-mr. mannion . [Margaret]44-margaret had moved [her]44-margaret chair into the background , while [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father was talking ; and was apparently little interested in the topic under discussion . In the first interval of silence , [she]43-mrs. sherwin complained of headache , and asked leave to retire to [[her]43-mrs. sherwin room]1432-her room .

After [she]43-mrs. sherwin left [us]1430-us , [I]0-i took [my]0-i departure : for [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin evidently had nothing more to tell [me]0-i about [[his]42-mr. sherwin clerk]1386-his clerk that was worth hearing . On [my]0-i way [home]176-home , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion occupied no small share of [my]0-i thoughts . The idea of trying to penetrate the mystery connected with [him]51-mr. mannion was an idea that pleased [me]0-i ; there was a promise of future excitement in it of no ordinary kind . [I]0-i determined to have a little private conversation with [Margaret]44-margaret about [him]51-mr. mannion ; and to make [her]44-margaret an ally in [my]0-i new project . If there really had been some romance connected with [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's early life - if that strange and striking face of [his]51-mr. mannion was indeed a sealed book which contained a secret story , what a triumph and a pleasure , if [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i should succeed in discovering it together !

When [I]0-i woke the next morning , [I]0-i could hardly believe that [[this tradesman]1435-this tradesman 's clerk]1436-this tradesman 's clerk had so interested [my]0-i curiosity that [he]1436-this tradesman 's clerk had actually shared [my]0-i thoughts with [[my]0-i young wife]1411-my young wife , during the evening before . And yet , when [I]0-i next saw [him]51-mr. mannion , [he]51-mr. mannion produced exactly the same impression on [me]0-i again .

III .

Some weeks passed away ; [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i resumed [our]1438-our usual employments and amusements ; the life at [North Villa]11-north villa ran on as smoothly and obscurely as usual - and still [I]0-i remained ignorant of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's history and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's character . [He]51-mr. mannion came frequently to [the house]244-the house , in the evening ; but was generally closeted with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , and seldom accepted [[his]51-mr. mannion employer]1384-his employer 's constant invitation to [him]51-mr. mannion to join the party in [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room . At those rare intervals when [we]1438-our did see [him]51-mr. mannion , [his]51-mr. mannion appearance and behaviour were exactly the same as on the night when [I]0-i had met [him]51-mr. mannion for the first time ; [he]51-mr. mannion spoke just as seldom , and resisted just as resolutely and respectfully the many attempts made on [my]0-i part to lead [him]51-mr. mannion into conversation and familiarity . If [he]51-mr. mannion had really been trying to excite [my]0-i interest , [he]51-mr. mannion could not have succeeded more effectually . [I]0-i felt towards [him]51-mr. mannion much as [a man]3101-a man feels in a labyrinth , when every fresh failure in gaining the centre , only produces fresh obstinacy in renewing the effort to arrive at it .

From [Margaret]44-margaret [I]0-i gained no sympathy for [my]0-i newly - aroused curiosity . [She]44-margaret appeared , much to [my]0-i surprise , to care little about [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion ; and always changed the conversation , if it related to [him]51-mr. mannion , whenever it depended upon [her]44-margaret to continue the topic or not .

[Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin 's conduct was far from resembling [[her]43-mrs. sherwin daughter]1101-her daughter 's , when [I]0-i spoke to [her]44-margaret on the same subject . [She]44-margaret always listened intently to what [I]0-i said ; but [her]44-margaret answers were invariably brief , confused , and sometimes absolutely incomprehensible . It was only after great difficulty that [I]0-i induced [her]44-margaret to confess [her]44-margaret dislike of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion . Whence it proceeded [she]44-margaret could never tell . Did [she]44-margaret suspect anything ? In answering this question , [she]44-margaret always stammered , trembled , and looked away from [me]0-i . " How could [she]44-margaret suspect anything ? If [she]44-margaret did suspect , it would be very wrong without good reason : but [she]44-margaret ought not to suspect , and did not , of course . "[44-margaret]

[I]0-i never obtained any replies from [her]44-margaret more intelligible than these . Attributing [their]1444-their confusion to the nervous agitation which more or less affected [her]44-margaret when [she]44-margaret spoke on any subject , [I]0-i soon ceased making any efforts to induce [her]44-margaret to explain [herself]44-margaret ; and determined to search for the clue to [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's character , without seeking assistance from [any one]1410-any one .

[Accident]62-accident at length gave [me]0-i an opportunity of knowing something of [his]51-mr. mannion habits and opinions ; and so far , therefore , of knowing something about [the man]696-the man [himself]51-mr. mannion .

One night , [I]0-i met [him]51-mr. mannion in [the hall at [North Villa]11-north villa]1447-the hall at north villa , about to leave [the house]244-the house at the same time that [I]0-i was , after a business - consultation in private with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin . [We]1449-we went out together . The sky was unusually black ; the night atmosphere unusually oppressive and still . The roll of distant thunder sounded faint and dreary all about [us]1449-we . The sheet lightning , flashing quick and low in the horizon , made the dark firmament look like a thick veil , rising and falling incessantly , over a heaven of dazzling light behind it . [Such few foot - passengers]1450-such few foot - passengers as passed [us]1449-we , passed running - for heavy , warning drops were falling already from the sky . [We]1449-we quickened [our]1449-we pace ; but before [we]1449-we had walked more than two hundred yards , the rain came down , furious and drenching ; and the thunder began to peal fearfully , right over [our]1449-we heads .

" [[My]1451-my companion house]3400-my house is close by , "[1451-my companion] said [[my]0-i companion]1451-my companion , just as quietly and deliberately as usual - " pray step in , [Sir]3046-sir , until the storm is over . "[1451-my companion]

[I]0-i followed [him]51-mr. mannion down [a bye street]1452-a bye street ; [he]51-mr. mannion opened a door with [his]51-mr. mannion own key ; and the next instant [I]0-i was sheltered under [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's roof .

[He]51-mr. mannion led [me]0-i at once into [a room on [the ground floor]1454-the ground floor]1453-a room on the ground floor . The fire was blazing in the grate ; an arm - chair , with a reading easel attached , was placed by it ; the lamp was ready lit ; the tea - things were placed on the table ; the dark , thick curtains were drawn close over the window ; and , as if to complete the picture of comfort before [me]0-i , a large black cat lay on the rug , basking luxuriously in the heat of the fire . While [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion went out to give some directions , as [he]51-mr. mannion said , to [[his]51-mr. mannion servant]1455-his servant , [I]0-i had an opportunity of examining [the apartment]1456-the apartment more in detail .
