To study the appearance of [[a man]3101-a man 's [dwelling - room]1459-dwelling - room]1458-a man 's dwelling - room , is very often nearly equivalent to studying [his]3101-a man own character .

The personal contrast between [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin and [[his]51-mr. mannion clerk]1386-his clerk was remarkable enough , but the contrast between the dimensions and furnishing of [the rooms]750-the rooms [they]1462-they lived in , was to the full as extraordinary . [The apartment [I]0-i now surveyed]1463-the apartment i now surveyed was less than half the size of [the sitting - room at [North Villa]11-north villa]1464-the sitting - room at north villa . The paper on the walls was of a dark red ; the curtains were of the same colour ; the carpet was brown , and if it bore any pattern , that pattern was too quiet and unpretending to be visible by candlelight . One wall was entirely occupied by rows of dark mahogany shelves , completely filled with books , most of them cheap editions of the classical works of ancient and modern literature . The opposite wall was thickly hung with engravings in maple - wood frames from the works of [modern painters]1465-modern painters , English and French . All the minor articles of furniture were of the plainest and neatest order - even the white china tea - pot and tea - cup on the table , had neither pattern nor colouring of any kind . What a contrast was [this room]1236-this room to [the drawing - room at [North Villa]11-north villa]1467-the drawing - room at north villa !

On [his]51-mr. mannion return , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion found [me]0-i looking at [his]51-mr. mannion tea - equipage . " [I]51-mr. mannion am afraid , [Sir]3046-sir , [I]51-mr. mannion must confess [myself]51-mr. mannion an epicure and a prodigal in two things , "[51-mr. mannion] [he]51-mr. mannion said ; " an epicure in tea , and a prodigal at least for [a person in [my]51-mr. mannion situation in books]3403-a person in my situation in books . However , [I]51-mr. mannion receive a liberal salary , and can satisfy [my]51-mr. mannion tastes , such as they are , and save money too . What can [I]51-mr. mannion offer [you]3046-sir , [Sir]3046-sir ? "[51-mr. mannion]

Seeing the preparations on the table , [I]0-i asked for tea . While [he]51-mr. mannion was speaking to [me]0-i , there was one peculiarity about [him]51-mr. mannion that [I]0-i observed . [Almost all men]1468-almost all men , when [they]1468-almost all men stand on [[their]1468-almost all men own hearths]1469-their own hearths , in [[their]1468-almost all men own homes]1470-their own homes , instinctively alter more or less from [their]1468-almost all men out - of - door manner : [the stiffest people]1471-the stiffest people expand , the coldest thaw a little , by [their]1468-almost all men own firesides . It was not so with [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion . [He]51-mr. mannion was exactly [the same man at [[his]51-mr. mannion own house]1473-his own house that [he]51-mr. mannion was at [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's]1474-mr. sherwin 's]1472-the same man at his own house that he was at mr. sherwin 's .

There was no need for [him]51-mr. mannion to have told [me]0-i that [he]51-mr. mannion was [an epicure in tea]1475-an epicure in tea ; the manner in which [he]51-mr. mannion made it would have betrayed that to [anybody]723-anybody . [He]51-mr. mannion put in nearly treble the quantity which would generally be considered sufficient for [two persons]1477-two persons ; and almost immediately after [he]51-mr. mannion had filled the tea - pot with boiling water , began to pour from it into the cups - thus preserving all the aroma and delicacy of flavour in the herb , without the alloy of any of the coarser part of its strength . When [we]1478-our had finished [our]1478-our first cups , there was no pouring of dregs into a basin , or of fresh water on the leaves . [A middle - aged female servant , neat and quiet]1479-a middle - aged female servant , neat and quiet , came up and took away the tray , bringing it to [us]1478-our again with the tea - pot and tea - cups clean and empty , to receive a fresh infusion from fresh leaves . These were trifles to notice ; but [I]0-i thought of [[other tradesmen]1480-other tradesmen 's clerks who were drinking [their]1481-other tradesmen 's clerks who were drinking their gin - and - water jovially , at home or at a tavern gin - and - water jovially , at [home]176-home or at [a tavern]1483-a tavern]1481-other tradesmen 's clerks who were drinking their gin - and - water jovially , at home or at a tavern , and found [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion a more exasperating mystery to [me]0-i than ever .

The conversation between [us]1478-our turned at first on trivial subjects , and was but ill sustained on [my]0-i part - there were peculiarities in [my]0-i present position which made [me]0-i thoughtful . Once , [our]1478-our talk ceased altogether ; and , just at that moment , the storm began to rise to its height . Hail mingled with the rain , and rattled heavily against the window . The thunder , bursting louder and louder with each successive peal , seemed to shake [the house]244-the house to its foundations . As [I]0-i listened to the fearful crashing and roaring that seemed to fill the whole measureless void of upper air , and then looked round on the calm , dead - calm face of [the man beside [me]0-i]1485-the man beside me - without one human emotion of any kind even faintly pictured on it - [I]0-i felt strange , unutterable sensations creeping over [me]0-i ; [our]1478-our silence grew oppressive and sinister ; [I]0-i began to wish , [I]0-i hardly knew why , for [some third person in the room]1486-some third person in the room - for [somebody else]1487-somebody else to look at and to speak to .

[He]51-mr. mannion was [the first to resume the conversation]1488-the first to resume the conversation . [I]0-i should have imagined it impossible for [any man]223-any man , in the midst of such thunder as now raged above [our]1478-our heads , to think or talk of anything but the storm . And yet , when [he]51-mr. mannion spoke , it was merely on a subject connected with [his]51-mr. mannion introduction to [me]0-i at [North Villa]11-north villa . [His]51-mr. mannion attention seemed as far from being attracted or impressed by the mighty elemental tumult without , as if the tranquillity of the night were uninvaded by the slightest murmur of sound .

" May [I]51-mr. mannion inquire , [Sir]3046-sir , "[51-mr. mannion] [he]51-mr. mannion began , " whether [I]51-mr. mannion am right in apprehending that [my]51-mr. mannion conduct towards [you]3046-sir , since [we]1478-our first met at [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's house]3406-mr. sherwin 's house , may have appeared strange , and even discourteous , in [your]3046-sir eyes ? "[51-mr. mannion]

" In what respect , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , a little startled by the abruptness of the question .

" [I]51-mr. mannion am perfectly sensible , [Sir]3046-sir , that [you]3046-sir have kindly set [me]51-mr. mannion the example , on many occasions , in trying to better [our]1478-our acquaintance . When such advances are made by one in [[your]3046-sir station]3058-your station to one in [mine]51-mr. mannion , [they]3409-they ought to be immediately and gratefully responded to . "[51-mr. mannion]

Why did [he]51-mr. mannion pause ? Was [he]51-mr. mannion about to tell [me]0-i [he]51-mr. mannion had discovered that [my]0-i advances sprang from curiosity to know more about [him]51-mr. mannion than [he]51-mr. mannion was willing to reveal ? [I]0-i waited for [him]51-mr. mannion to proceed .

" [I]51-mr. mannion have only failed , "[51-mr. mannion] [he]51-mr. mannion continued , " in the courtesy and gratitude [you]0-i had a right to expect from [me]51-mr. mannion , because , knowing how [you]0-i were situated with [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's daughter]3410-mr. sherwin 's daughter , [I]51-mr. mannion thought any intrusion on [my]51-mr. mannion part , while [you]0-i were with [the young lady]774-the young lady , might not be so acceptable as [you]0-i , [Sir]3046-sir , in [your]0-i kindness , were willing to lead [me]51-mr. mannion to believe . "[51-mr. mannion]

" Let [me]0-i assure [you]51-mr. mannion , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered ; relieved to find [myself]0-i unsuspected , and really impressed by [his]51-mr. mannion delicacy - " let [me]0-i assure [you]51-mr. mannion that [I]0-i fully appreciate the consideration [you]51-mr. mannion have shown - "[0-i]

Just as the last words passed [my]0-i lips , the thunder pealed awfully over [the house]244-the house . [I]0-i said no more : the sound silenced [me]0-i .

" As [my]51-mr. mannion explanation has satisfied [you]0-i , [Sir]3046-sir , "[51-mr. mannion] [he]51-mr. mannion went on ; [his]51-mr. mannion clear and deliberate utterance rising discordantly audible above the long , retiring roll of the last burst of thunder - " may [I]51-mr. mannion feel justified in speaking on the subject of [your]0-i present position in [[[my]51-mr. mannion employer]3352-my employer 's house]3415-my employer 's house , with some freedom ? [I]51-mr. mannion mean , if [I]51-mr. mannion may say so without offence , with the freedom of [a friend]512-a friend . "[51-mr. mannion]

[I]0-i begged [he]51-mr. mannion would use all the freedom [he]51-mr. mannion wished ; feeling really desirous that [he]51-mr. mannion should do so , apart from any purpose of leading [him]51-mr. mannion to talk unreservedly on the chance of hearing [him]51-mr. mannion talk of [himself]51-mr. mannion . The profound respect of manner and phrase which [he]51-mr. mannion had hitherto testified - observed by [a man of [his]51-mr. mannion age]1491-a man of his age , to [a man of mine]1492-a man of mine - made [me]0-i feel ill at ease . [He]51-mr. mannion was most probably [[my]0-i equal]1493-my equal in acquirements : [he]51-mr. mannion had the manners and tastes of [a gentleman]3111-a gentleman , and might have the birth too , for aught [I]0-i knew to the contrary . The difference between [us]1495-us was only in [our]1495-us worldly positions . [I]0-i had not enough of [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's pride of caste to think that this difference alone , made it right that [a man whose years nearly doubled [mine]0-i , whose knowledge perhaps surpassed [mine]0-i]1497-a man whose years nearly doubled mine , whose knowledge perhaps surpassed mine , should speak to [me]0-i as [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion had spoken up to this time .

" [I]51-mr. mannion may tell [you]0-i then , "[51-mr. mannion] [he]51-mr. mannion resumed , " that while [I]51-mr. mannion am anxious to commit no untimely intrusion on [your]0-i hours at [North Villa]11-north villa , [I]51-mr. mannion am at the same time desirous of being something more than merely inoffensive towards [you]0-i . [I]51-mr. mannion should wish to be positively useful , as far as [I]51-mr. mannion can . In [my]51-mr. mannion opinion [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin has held [you]0-i to rather a hard engagement - [he]51-mr. mannion is trying [your]0-i discretion a little too severely [I]51-mr. mannion think , at [your]0-i years and in [your]0-i situation . Feeling thus , it is [my]51-mr. mannion sincere wish to render what connection and influence [I]51-mr. mannion have with [the family]179-the family , useful in making the probation [you]0-i have still to pass through , as easy as possible . [I]51-mr. mannion have more means of doing this , [Sir]3046-sir , than [you]0-i might at first imagine . "[51-mr. mannion]

[His]1498-i offer took [me]0-i a little by surprise . [I]0-i felt with a sort of shame , that candour and warmth of feeling were what [I]0-i had not expected from [him]1498-i . [My]0-i attention insensibly wandered away from the storm , to attach itself more and more closely to [him]1498-i , as [he]1498-i went on :

" [I]1498-i am perfectly sensible , "[1498-i] [he]1498-i resumed , " that such a proposition as [I]1498-i now make to [you]0-i , proceeding from one little better than [a stranger]842-a stranger , may cause surprise and even suspicion , at first . [I]1498-i can only explain it , by asking [you]0-i to remember that [I]1498-i have known [the young lady]774-the young lady since childhood ; and that , having assisted in forming [her]774-the young lady mind and developing [her]774-the young lady character , [I]1498-i feel towards [her]774-the young lady almost as [a second father]3421-a second father , and am therefore naturally interested in [the gentleman who has chosen [her]774-the young lady for [a wife]3423-a wife]3422-the gentleman who has chosen her for a wife . "[1498-i]

Was there a tremor at last in that changeless voice , as [he]1498-i spoke ? [I]0-i thought so ; and looked anxiously to catch the answering gleam of expression , which might now , for the first time , be softening [his]1498-i iron features , animating the blank stillness of [his]1498-i countenance . If any such expression had been visible , [I]0-i was too late to detect it . Just as [I]0-i looked at [him]1498-i [he]1498-i stooped down to poke the fire . When [he]1498-i turned towards [me]0-i again , [his]1498-i face was the same impenetrable face , [his]1498-i eye the same hard , steady , inexpressive eye as before .

" Besides , "[1498-i] [he]1498-i continued , " [a man]3101-a man must have some object in life for [his]3101-a man sympathies to be employed on . [I]1498-i have neither [wife]3425-wife nor [child]3426-child ; and no near relations to think of - [I]1498-i have nothing but [my]1498-i routine of business in the day , and [my]1498-i books here by [my]1498-i lonely fireside , at night . [Our]3427-our life is not much ; but it was made for a little more than this . [[My]1498-i former pupil at [North Villa]11-north villa]3428-my former pupil at north villa is [[my]1498-i pupil]3429-my pupil no longer . [I]1498-i ca n't help feeling that it would be an object in existence for [me]1498-i to occupy [myself]1498-i with [her]3428-my former pupil at north villa happiness and [yours]3430-you ; to have [two young people , in the heyday of youth]3431-two young people , in the heyday of youth and first love , looking towards [me]1498-i occasionally for the promotion of some of [their]3431-two young people , in the heyday of youth pleasures - no matter how trifling . All this will seem odd and incomprehensible to [you]3430-you . If [you]3430-you were of [my]1498-i age , [Sir]3046-sir , and in [my]1498-i position , [you]3430-you would understand it . "[1498-i]

Was it possible that [he]1499-i could speak thus , without [his]1499-i voice faltering , or [his]1499-i eye softening in the slightest degree ? Yes : [I]0-i looked at [him]1499-i and listened to [him]1499-i intently ; but here was not the faintest change in [his]1499-i face or [his]1499-i tones - there was nothing to show outwardly whether [he]1499-i felt what [he]1499-i said , or whether [he]1499-i did not . [His]1499-i words had painted such a picture of forlornness on [my]0-i mind , that [I]0-i had mechanically half raised [my]0-i hand to take [his]1499-i , while [he]1499-i was addressing [me]0-i ; but the sight of [him]1499-i when [he]1499-i ceased , checked the impulse almost as soon as it was formed . [He]1499-i did not appear to have noticed either [my]0-i involuntary gesture , or its immediate repression ; and went on speaking .

" [I]1499-i have said perhaps more than [I]1499-i ought , "[1499-i] [he]1499-i resumed . " If [I]1499-i have not succeeded in making [you]0-i understand [my]1499-i explanation as [I]1499-i could wish , [we]3433-we will change the subject , and not return to it again , until [you]0-i have known [me]1499-i for a much longer time . "[1499-i]

" On no account change the subject , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , "[0-i] [I]0-i said ; unwilling to let it be implied that [I]0-i would not put trust in [him]1499-i . " [I]0-i am deeply sensible of the kindness of [your]1499-i offer , and the interest [you]1499-i take in [Margaret]44-margaret and [me]0-i . [We]3433-we shall both , [I]0-i am sure , accept [your]1499-i good offices - "[0-i]

[I]0-i stopped . The storm had decreased a little in violence : but [my]0-i attention was now struck by the wind , which had risen as the thunder and rain had partially lulled . How drearily it was moaning down [the street]163-the street ! It seemed , at that moment , to be wailing over [me]0-i ; to be wailing over [him]1499-i ; to be wailing over all mortal things ! The strange sensations [I]0-i then felt , moved [me]0-i to listen in silence ; but [I]0-i checked them , and spoke again .

" If [I]0-i have not answered [you]1499-i as [I]0-i should , "[0-i] [I]0-i continued , " [you]1499-i must attribute it partly to the storm , which [I]0-i confess rather discomposes [my]0-i ideas ; and partly to a little surprise - a very foolish surprise , [I]0-i own - that [you]1499-i should still be able to feel so strong a sympathy with interests which are generally only considered of importance to [the young]3434-the young . "[0-i]

" It is only in [their]3434-the young sympathies , that [men of]3435-men of [my]1499-i years can , and do , live [their]3435-men of youth over again , "[1499-i] [he]1499-i said . " [You]1499-i may be surprised to hear [a tradesman 's clerk]3436-a tradesman 's clerk talk in this manner ; but [I]1499-i was not always what [I]1499-i am now . [I]1499-i have gathered knowledge , and suffered in the gathering . [I]1499-i have grown old before [my]1499-i time - [my]1499-i forty years are like the fifty of [other men]3437-other men - "[1499-i]

[My]0-i heart beat quicker - was [he]1499-i , unasked , about to disclose the mystery which evidently hung over [his]1499-i early life ? No : [he]1499-i dropped the subject at once , when [he]1499-i continued . [I]0-i longed to ask [him]1499-i to resume it , but could not . [I]0-i feared the same repulse which [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin had received : and remained silent .

" What [I]1499-i was , "[1499-i] [he]1499-i proceeded , " matters little ; the question is what can [I]1499-i do for [you]0-i ? Any aid [I]1499-i can give , may be poor enough ; but it may be of some use notwithstanding . For instance , the other day , if [I]1499-i mistake not , [you]0-i were a little hurt at [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's taking [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter to a party to which [the family]179-the family had been invited . This was very natural . [You]0-i could not be there to watch over [her]233-his daughter in [your]0-i real character , without disclosing a secret which must be kept safe ; and [you]0-i could not know what young men [she]233-his daughter might meet , who would imagine [her]233-his daughter to be [Miss Sherwin]44-margaret still , and would regulate [their]179-the family conduct accordingly . Now , [I]1499-i think [I]1499-i might be of use [here]3265-here . [I]1499-i have some influence - perhaps in strict truth [I]1499-i ought to say great influence - with [[my]1499-i employer]3352-my employer ; and , if [you]0-i wished it , [I]1499-i would use that influence to back [yours]0-i , in inducing [him]3352-my employer to forego , for the future , any intention of taking [[his]3352-my employer daughter]233-his daughter into society , except when [you]0-i desire it . Again : [I]1499-i think [I]1499-i am not wrong in assuming that [you]0-i infinitely prefer the company of [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin to that of [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , during [your]0-i interviews with [the young lady]774-the young lady ? "[1499-i]

How [he]1501-i had found that out ? At any rate , [he]1501-i was right ; and [I]0-i told [him]1501-i so candidly .

" The preference is on many accounts a very natural one , "[1501-i] [he]1501-i said ; " but if [you]0-i suffered it to appear to [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , it might , for obvious reasons , produce a most unfavourable effect . [I]1501-i might interfere in the matter , however , without suspicion ; [I]1501-i should have many opportunities of keeping [him]42-mr. sherwin away from [the room]263-the room , in the evening , which [I]1501-i could use if [you]0-i wished it . And more than that , if [you]0-i wanted longer and more frequent communication with [North Villa]11-north villa than [you]0-i now enjoy , [I]1501-i might be able to effect this also . [I]1501-i do not mention what [I]1501-i could do in these , and in other matters , in any disparagement , [Sir]3046-sir , of the influence which [you]0-i have with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , in [your]0-i own right ; but because [I]1501-i know that in what concerns [your]0-i intercourse with [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter , [[my]1501-i employer]3352-my employer has asked , and will ask [my]1501-i advice , from the habit of doing so in other things . [I]1501-i have hitherto declined giving [him]42-mr. sherwin this advice in [your]0-i affairs ; but [I]1501-i will give it , and in [your]0-i favour and [the young lady]774-the young lady 's , if [you]0-i and [she]774-the young lady choose . "[1501-i]

[I]0-i thanked [him]1502-his - but not in such warm terms as [I]0-i should have employed , if [I]0-i had seen even the faintest smile on [his]1502-his face , or had heard any change in [his]1502-his steady , deliberate tones , as [he]1502-his spoke . While [his]1502-his words attracted , [his]1502-his immovable looks repelled [me]0-i , in spite of [myself]0-i .

" [I]1502-his must again beg [you]0-i "[1502-his] - [he]1502-his proceeded - " to remember what [I]1502-his have already said , in [your]0-i estimate of the motives of [my]1502-his offer . If [I]1502-his still appear to be interfering officiously in [your]0-i affairs , [you]0-i have only to think that [I]1502-his have presumed impertinently on the freedom [you]0-i have allowed [me]1502-his , and to treat [me]1502-his no longer on the terms of to - night . [I]1502-his shall not complain of [your]0-i conduct , and shall try hard not to consider [you]0-i unjust to [me]1502-his , if [you]0-i do . "[1502-his]

Such an appeal as this was not to be resisted : [I]0-i answered [him]1502-his at once and unreservedly . What right had [I]0-i to draw bad inferences from [a man]3101-a man 's face , voice , and manner , merely because they impressed [me]0-i , as out of the common ? Did [I]0-i know how much share the influence of natural infirmity , or the outward traces of unknown sorrow and suffering , might have had in producing the external peculiarities which had struck [me]0-i ? [He]1502-his would have every right to upbraid [me]0-i as unjust - and that in the strongest terms - unless [I]0-i spoke out fairly in reply .

" [I]0-i am quite incapable , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " of viewing [your]1502-his offer with any other than grateful feelings . [You]1502-his will find [I]0-i shall prove this by employing [your]1502-his good offices for [Margaret]44-margaret and [myself]0-i in perfect faith , and sooner perhaps than [you]1502-his may imagine . "[0-i]

[He]1502-his bowed and said a few cordial words , which [I]0-i heard but imperfectly - for , as [I]0-i addressed [him]1502-his , a blast of wind fiercer than usual , rushed down [the street]163-the street , shaking the window shutter violently as it passed , and dying away in a low , melancholy , dirging swell , like a spirit - cry of lamentation and despair .

When [he]1502-his spoke again , after a momentary silence , it was to make some change in the conversation . [He]1502-his talked of [Margaret]44-margaret - dwelling in terms of high praise rather on [her]44-margaret moral than on [her]44-margaret personal qualities . [He]1502-his spoke of [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , referring to solid and attractive points in [his]1502-his character which [I]0-i had not detected . What [he]1502-his said of [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin appeared to be equally dictated by compassion and respect - [he]1502-his even hinted at [her]43-mrs. sherwin coolness towards [himself]1502-his , considerately attributing it to the involuntary caprice of settled nervousness and ill - health . [His]1502-his language , in touching on these subjects , was just as unaffected , just as devoid of any peculiarities , as [I]0-i had hitherto found it when occupied by other topics .

It was growing late . The thunder still rumbled at long intervals , with a dull , distant sound ; and the wind showed no symptoms of subsiding . But the pattering of the rain against the window ceased to be audible . There was little excuse for staying longer ; and [I]0-i wished to find none . [I]0-i had acquired quite knowledge enough of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion to assure [me]0-i , that any attempt on [my]0-i part at extracting from [him]1502-his , in spite of [his]1502-his reserve , the secrets which might be connected with [his]1502-his early life , would prove perfectly fruitless . If [I]0-i must judge [him]1502-his at all , [I]0-i must judge [him]1502-his by the experience of the present , and not by the history of the past . [I]0-i had heard good , and good only , of [him]1502-his from [the shrewd master who knew [him]1502-his best , and had tried [him]1502-his longest]1505-the shrewd master who knew him best , and had tried him longest . [He]1502-his had shown the greatest delicacy towards [my]0-i feelings , and the strongest desire to do [me]0-i service - it would be a mean return for those acts of courtesy , to let curiosity tempt [me]0-i to pry into [his]1502-his private affairs .

[I]0-i rose to go . [He]1502-his made no effort to detain [me]0-i ; but , after unbarring the shutter and looking out of the window , simply remarked that the rain had almost entirely ceased , and that [my]0-i umbrella would be quite sufficient protection against all that remained . [He]1502-his followed [me]0-i into [the passage]1048-the passage to light [me]0-i out . As [I]0-i turned round upon [his]1502-his door - step to thank [him]1502-his for [his]1502-his hospitality , and to bid [him]1502-his good night , the thought came across [me]0-i , that [my]0-i manner must have appeared cold and repelling to [him]1502-his - especially when [he]1502-his was offering [his]1502-his services to [my]0-i acceptance . If [I]0-i had really produced this impression , [he]1502-his was [[my]0-i inferior in station]1507-my inferior in station , and it would be cruel to leave it . [I]0-i tried to set [myself]0-i right at parting .

" Let [me]0-i assure [you]1502-his again , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " that it will not be [my]0-i fault if [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i do not thankfully employ [[your]1502-his good offices]3449-your good offices , as the good offices of [a well - wisher]3450-a well - wisher and [a friend]512-a friend . "[0-i]

The lightning was still in the sky , though it only appeared at long intervals . Strangely enough , at the moment when [I]0-i addressed [him]1502-his , a flash came , and seemed to pass right over [his]1502-his face . It gave such a hideously livid hue , such a spectral look of ghastliness and distortion to [his]1502-his features , that [he]1502-his absolutely seemed to be glaring and grinning on [me]0-i like [a fiend]1508-a fiend , in the one instant of its duration . For the moment , it required all [my]0-i knowledge of the settled calmness of [his]1502-his countenance , to convince [me]0-i that [my]0-i eyes must have been only dazzled by an optical illusion produced by the lightning .

When the darkness had come again , [I]0-i bade [him]1502-his good night - first mechanically repeating what [I]0-i had just said , almost in the same words .

[I]0-i walked [home]176-home thoughtful . That night had given [me]0-i much matter to think of .

IV .

About the time of [my]0-i introduction to [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion - or , to speak more correctly , both before and after that period - certain peculiarities in [Margaret]44-margaret 's character and conduct , which came to [my]0-i knowledge by pure accident , gave [me]0-i a little uneasiness and even a little displeasure . Neither of these feelings lasted very long , it is true ; for the incidents which gave rise to them were of a trifling nature in themselves . While [I]0-i now write , however , these domestic occurrences are all vividly present to [my]0-i recollection . [I]0-i will mention two of them as instances . Subsequent events , yet to be related , will show that they are not out of place at this part of [my]0-i narrative .

One lovely autumn morning , [I]0-i called rather before the appointed time at [North Villa]11-north villa . As [the servant]315-the servant opened the front garden - gate , the idea occurred to [me]0-i of giving [Margaret]44-margaret a surprise , by entering [the drawing room]1511-the drawing room unexpectedly , with a nosegay gathered for [her]44-margaret from [her]44-margaret own flower - bed . Telling [the servant]315-the servant not to announce [me]0-i , [I]0-i went round to [the back garden]1513-the back garden , by a gate which opened into [it]1513-the back garden at the side of [the house]244-the house . The progress of [my]0-i flower - gathering led [me]0-i on to the lawn under one of [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room windows , which was left a little open . The voices of [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife and [[her]864-my wife mother]319-her mother reached [me]0-i from [the room]263-the room . It was this part of [their]1519-i conversation which [I]0-i unintentionally overheard : -

" [I]1519-i tell [you]44-margaret , [mamma]3452-mamma , [I]1519-i must and will have the dress , whether [papa]58-papa chooses or not . "[1519-i]

This was spoken loudly and resolutely ; in such tones as [I]0-i had never heard from [Margaret]44-margaret before .

" Pray - pray , [[my]43-mrs. sherwin dear]3163-my dear , do n't talk so , "[43-mrs. sherwin] answered the weak , faltering voice of [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin ; " [you]0-i know [you]0-i have had more than [your]0-i year 's allowance of dresses already . "[43-mrs. sherwin]

" [I]319-her mother wo n't be allowanced . [[His]58-papa sister]3454-his sister is n't allowanced : why should [I]319-her mother be ? "[319-her mother]

" [[My]43-mrs. sherwin dear love]3455-my dear love , surely there is some difference - "[43-mrs. sherwin]

" [I]319-her mother 'm sure there is n't , now [I]319-her mother am [[his]58-papa wife]997-his wife . [I]319-her mother shall ride some day in [[my]319-her mother carriage]3457-my carriage , just as [[his]58-papa sister]3454-his sister does . [He]58-papa gives [me]319-her mother [my]319-her mother way in everything ; and so ought [you]3455-my dear love . "[319-her mother]

" It is n't [me]43-mrs. sherwin , [Margaret]44-margaret : if [I]43-mrs. sherwin could do anything , [I]43-mrs. sherwin 'm sure [I]43-mrs. sherwin would ; but [I]43-mrs. sherwin really could n't ask [[your]44-margaret papa]3459-your papa for another new dress , after [his]58-papa having given [you]44-margaret so many this year , already . "[43-mrs. sherwin]

" That 's the way it always is with [you]44-margaret , [mamma]3452-mamma - [you]44-margaret ca n't do this , and [you]44-margaret ca n't do that - [you]44-margaret are so excessively tiresome ! But [I]319-her mother will have the dress , [I]319-her mother 'm determined . [He]58-papa says [[his]58-papa sister]3454-his sister wears light blue crape of an evening ; and [I]319-her mother 'll have light blue crape , too - see if [I]319-her mother do n't ! [I]319-her mother 'll get it somehow from [the shop]790-the shop , [myself]319-her mother . [Papa]58-papa never takes any notice , [I]319-her mother 'm sure , what [I]319-her mother have on ; and [he]58-papa need n't find out anything about what 's gone out of [the shop]790-the shop , until [they]3464-they ' take stock , ' or whatever it is [he]58-papa calls it . And then , if [he]58-papa flies into one of [his]58-papa passions - "[319-her mother]

" [[My]43-mrs. sherwin dear]3163-my dear ! [[my]43-mrs. sherwin dear]3163-my dear ! [you]3163-my dear really ought not to talk so of [[your]3163-my dear papa]3459-your papa - it is very wrong , [Margaret]44-margaret , indeed - what would [Mr. Basil]46-basil say if [he]58-papa heard [you]3163-my dear ? "[43-mrs. sherwin]

[I]0-i determined to go in at once , and tell [Margaret]44-margaret that [I]0-i had heard [her]44-margaret - resolving , at the same time , to exert some firmness , and remonstrate with [her]44-margaret , for [her]44-margaret own good , on much of what [she]44-margaret had said , which had really surprised and displeased [me]0-i . On [my]0-i unexpected entrance , [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin started , and looked more timid than ever . [Margaret]44-margaret , however , came forward to meet [me]0-i with [her]44-margaret wonted smile , and held out [her]44-margaret hand with [her]44-margaret wonted grace . [I]0-i said nothing until [we]1520-we had got into [our]1520-we accustomed corner , and were talking together in whispers as usual . Then [I]0-i began [my]0-i remonstrance - very tenderly , and in the lowest possible tones . [She]44-margaret took precisely the right way to stop [me]0-i in full career , in spite of all [my]0-i resolution . [Her]44-margaret beautiful eyes filled with tears directly - the first [I]0-i had ever seen in them : caused , too , by what [I]0-i had said ! - and [she]44-margaret murmured a few plaintive words about the cruelty of being angry with [her]44-margaret for only wanting to please [me]0-i by being dressed as [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister was , which upset every intention [I]0-i had formed but the moment before . [I]0-i involuntarily devoted [myself]0-i to soothing [her]44-margaret for the rest of the morning . Need [I]0-i say how the matter ended ? [I]0-i never mentioned the subject more ; and [I]0-i made [her]44-margaret a present of the new dress .

Some weeks after the little home - breeze which [I]0-i have just related , had died away into a perfect calm , [I]0-i was accidentally witness of another domestic dilemma in which [Margaret]44-margaret bore a principal share . On this occasion , as [I]0-i walked up to [the house]244-the house in the morning again , [I]0-i found the front door open . A pail was on the steps - [the servant]315-the servant had evidently been washing them , had been interrupted in [her]315-the servant work , and had forgotten to close the door when [she]315-the servant left it . The nature of the interruption [I]0-i soon discovered as [I]0-i entered [the hall]1423-the hall .

" For God 's sake , [Miss]3468-miss ! "[1525-the housemaid] cried [the housemaid]1525-the housemaid 's voice , from [the dining - room]165-the dining - room , " for [God]37-god 's sake , put down the poker ! [Missus]3469-missus will be [here]3265-here directly ; and it 's [her]3469-missus cat ! "[1525-the housemaid]

" [I]44-margaret 'll kill [the vile brute]3471-the vile brute ! [I]44-margaret 'll kill the hateful cat ! [I]44-margaret do n't care whose it is ! - [[my]44-margaret poor dear]3472-my poor dear , dear , dear bird ! "[44-margaret] The voice was [Margaret]44-margaret 's . At first , its tones were tones of fury ; they were afterwards broken by hysterical sobs .

" Poor thing , "[315-the servant] continued [the servant]315-the servant , soothingly , " [I]315-the servant 'm sorry for it , and for [you]3468-miss too , [Miss]3473-miss ! But , oh ! do please to remember it was [you]3468-miss left the cage on the table , in the cat 's reach - "[315-the servant]

" Hold [your]3468-miss tongue , [[you]3468-miss wretch]3474-you wretch ! How dare [you]3468-miss hold [me]315-the servant ? - let [me]315-the servant go ! "[315-the servant]

" Oh , [you]3468-miss must n't - [you]3468-miss must n't indeed ! It 's [missus]3081-missus 's cat , recollect - poor missus 's , who 's always ill , and has n't got nothing else to amuse [her]3081-missus . "[315-the servant]

" [I]315-the servant do n't care ! The cat has killed [my]315-the servant bird , and the cat shall be killed for doing it ! - it shall ! - it shall ! ! - it shall ! ! ! [I]315-the servant 'll call in [the first boy from [the street]163-the street]3476-the first boy from the street to catch it , and hang it ! Let [me]315-the servant go ! [I]315-the servant will go ! "[315-the servant]

" [I]315-the servant 'll let the cat go first , [Miss]3478-miss , as sure as [my]315-the servant name 's [Susan]64-susan ! "[315-the servant]

The next instant , the door was suddenly opened , and puss sprang past [me]0-i , out of harm 's way , closely followed by [the servant]315-the servant , who stared breathless and aghast at seeing [me]0-i in [the hall]1423-the hall . [I]0-i went into [the dining - room]165-the dining - room immediately .

On the floor lay a bird - cage , with the poor canary dead inside it was the same canary that [I]0-i had seen [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife playing with , on the evening of the day when [I]0-i first met [her]864-my wife . The bird 's head had been nearly dragged through the bent wires of the cage , by the murderous claws of the cat . Near [the fire - place]1532-the fire - place , with the poker [she]864-my wife had just dropped on the floor by [her]864-my wife side , stood [Margaret]44-margaret . Never had [I]0-i seen [her]44-margaret look so beautiful as [she]44-margaret now appeared , in the fury of passion which possessed [her]44-margaret . [Her]44-margaret large black eyes were flashing grandly through [her]44-margaret tears - the blood was glowing crimson in [her]44-margaret cheeks - [her]44-margaret lips were parted as [she]44-margaret gasped for breath . One of [her]44-margaret hands was clenched , and rested on the mantel - piece ; the other was pressed tight over [her]44-margaret bosom , with the fingers convulsively clasping [her]44-margaret dress . Grieved as [I]0-i was at the paroxysm of passion into which [she]44-margaret had allowed [herself]44-margaret to be betrayed , [I]0-i could not repress an involuntary feeling of admiration when [my]0-i eyes first rested on [her]44-margaret . Even anger itself looked lovely in that lovely face !

[She]44-margaret never moved when [she]44-margaret saw [me]0-i . As [I]0-i approached [her]44-margaret , [she]44-margaret dropped down on [her]44-margaret knees by the cage , sobbing with frightful violence , and pouring forth a perfect torrent of ejaculations of vengeance against the cat . [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin came down ; and by [her]43-mrs. sherwin total want of tact and presence of mind , made matters worse . In brief , the scene ended by a fit of hysterics .

To speak to [Margaret]44-margaret on that day , as [I]0-i wished to speak to [her]44-margaret , was impossible . To approach the subject of [the canary]1533-the canary 's death afterwards , was useless . If [I]0-i only hinted in the gentlest way , and with the strongest sympathy for the loss of the bird , at the distress and astonishment [she]44-margaret had caused [me]0-i by the extremities to which [she]44-margaret had allowed [her]44-margaret passion to hurry [her]44-margaret , a burst of tears was sure to be [her]44-margaret only reply - just the reply , of all others , which was best calculated to silence [me]0-i . If [I]0-i had been [[her]44-margaret husband]480-her husband in fact , as well as in name ; if [I]0-i had been [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father , [[her]44-margaret brother]1536-her brother , or [[her]44-margaret friend]1537-her friend , [I]0-i should have let [her]44-margaret first emotions have their way , and then have expostulated with [her]44-margaret afterwards . But [I]0-i was [[her]44-margaret lover]1538-her lover still ; and , to [my]0-i eyes , [Margaret]44-margaret 's tears made virtues even of [Margaret]44-margaret 's faults .

Such occurrences as these , happening but at rare intervals , formed the only interruptions to the generally even and happy tenour of [our]1539-our intercourse . Weeks and weeks glided away , and not a hasty or a hard word passed between [us]1539-our . Neither , after one preliminary difference had been adjusted , did any subsequent disagreement take place between [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin and [me]0-i . This last element in the domestic tranquillity of [North Villa]11-north villa was , however , less attributable to [his]42-mr. sherwin forbearance , or to [mine]0-i , than to the private interference of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion .

For some days after [my]0-i interview with [the managing clerk]1540-the managing clerk , at [[his]42-mr. sherwin own house]1473-his own house , [I]0-i had abstained from calling [his]42-mr. sherwin offered services into requisition . [I]0-i was not conscious of any reason for this course of conduct . All that had been said , all that had happened during the night of the storm , had produced a powerful , though vague impression on [me]0-i . Strange as it may appear , [I]0-i could not determine whether [my]0-i brief but extraordinary experience of [[my]0-i new friend]1542-my new friend had attracted [me]0-i towards [him]1542-my new friend , or repelled [me]0-i from [him]1542-my new friend . [I]0-i felt an unwillingness to lay [myself]0-i under an obligation to [him]1542-my new friend , which was not the result of pride , or false delicacy , or sullenness , or suspicion - it was an inexplicable unwillingness , that sprang from the fear of encountering some heavy responsibility ; but of what nature [I]0-i could not imagine . [I]0-i delayed and held back , by instinct ; and , on [his]1542-my new friend side , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion made no further advances . [He]1542-my new friend maintained the same manner , and continued the same habits , during [his]1542-my new friend intercourse with [the family]179-the family at [North Villa]11-north villa , which [I]0-i had observed as characterising [him]1542-my new friend before [I]0-i took shelter from the storm , in [[his]1542-my new friend house]216-his house . [He]1542-my new friend never referred again to the conversation of that evening , when [we]1545-we now met .

[Margaret]44-margaret 's behaviour , when [I]0-i mentioned to [her]44-margaret [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's willingness to be useful to [us]1545-we both , rather increased than diminished the vague uncertainties which perplexed [me]0-i , on the subject of accepting or rejecting [his]1542-my new friend overtures .

[I]0-i could not induce [her]44-margaret to show the smallest interest about [him]1542-my new friend . Neither [[his]1542-my new friend house]216-his house , [his]1542-my new friend personal appearance , [his]1542-my new friend peculiar habits , or [his]1542-my new friend secrecy in relation to [his]1542-my new friend early life - nothing , in short , connected with [him]1542-my new friend - appeared to excite [her]44-margaret attention or curiosity in the slightest degree . On the evening of [his]1542-my new friend return from [the continent]339-the continent , [she]44-margaret had certainly shown some symptoms of interest in [his]1542-my new friend arrival at [North Villa]11-north villa , and some appearance of attention to [him]1542-my new friend , when [he]1542-my new friend joined [[our]1548-our party]1549-our party . Now , [she]44-margaret seemed completely and incomprehensibly changed on this point . [Her]44-margaret manner became almost petulant , if [I]0-i persisted long in making [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion a topic of conversation - it was as if [she]44-margaret resented [his]1542-my new friend sharing [my]0-i thoughts with [her]44-margaret in the slightest degree . As to the difficult question whether [we]1548-our should engage [him]1542-my new friend in [our]1548-our interests or not , that was a matter which [she]44-margaret always seemed to think too trifling to be discussed between [us]1548-our at all .

Ere long , however , circumstances decided [me]0-i as to the course [I]0-i should take with [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion .

A ball was given by [one of [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's rich commercial friends]1551-mr. sherwin 's rich commercial friends]1550-one of mr. sherwin 's rich commercial friends , to which [he]1542-my new friend announced [his]1542-my new friend intention of taking [Margaret]44-margaret . Besides the jealousy which [I]0-i felt - naturally enough , in [my]0-i peculiar situation - at the idea of [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife going out as [Miss Sherwin]44-margaret , and dancing in the character of [a young unmarried lady]1553-a young unmarried lady with [any young gentlemen who were introduced to [her]44-margaret]1554-any young gentlemen who were introduced to her , [I]0-i had also the strongest possible desire to keep [Margaret]44-margaret out of the society of [[her]44-margaret own class]1555-her own class , until [my]0-i year 's probation was over , and [I]0-i could hope to instal [her]44-margaret permanently in [the society of [[my]0-i class]1557-my class]1556-the society of my class . [I]0-i had privately mentioned to [her]44-margaret [my]0-i ideas on this subject , and found that [she]44-margaret fully agreed with [them]1558-them . [She]44-margaret was not wanting in ambition to ascend to the highest degree in the social scale ; and had already begun to look with indifference on the society which was offered to [her]44-margaret by [those in [her]44-margaret own rank]1559-those in her own rank .

To [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin [I]0-i could confide nothing of this . [I]0-i could only object , generally , to [his]42-mr. sherwin taking [Margaret]44-margaret out , when neither [she]44-margaret nor [I]0-i desired it . [He]42-mr. sherwin declared that [she]44-margaret liked parties - that [all girls]1560-all girls did - that [she]44-margaret only pretended to dislike [them]1560-all girls , to please [me]0-i - and that [he]42-mr. sherwin had made no engagement to keep [her]44-margaret moping at [home]176-home a whole year on [my]0-i account . In the case of the particular ball now under discussion , [he]42-mr. sherwin was determined to have [his]42-mr. sherwin own way ; and [he]42-mr. sherwin bluntly told [me]0-i as much .

Irritated by [his]42-mr. sherwin obstinacy and gross want of consideration for [my]0-i defenceless position , [I]0-i forgot all doubts and scruples ; and privately applied to [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion to exert the influence which [he]42-mr. sherwin had promised to use , if [I]0-i wished it , in [my]0-i behalf .

The result was as immediate as it was conclusive . The very next evening , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin came to [us]1562-us with a note which [he]42-mr. sherwin had just written , and informed [me]0-i that it was an excuse for [Margaret]44-margaret 's non - appearance at the ball . [He]42-mr. sherwin never mentioned [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's name , but sulkily and shortly said , that [he]42-mr. sherwin had reconsidered the matter , and had altered [his]42-mr. sherwin first decision for reasons of [his]42-mr. sherwin own .

Having once taken a first step in the new direction , [I]0-i soon followed it up , without hesitation , by taking many others . Whenever [I]0-i wished to call oftener than once a - day at [North Villa]11-north villa , [I]0-i had but to tell [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , and the next morning [I]0-i found the permission immediately accorded to [me]0-i by [the ruling power]1563-the ruling power . The same secret machinery enabled [me]0-i to regulate [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's incomings and outgoings , just as [I]0-i chose , when [Margaret]44-margaret and [I]0-i were together in the evening . [I]0-i could feel almost certain , now , of never having any one with [us]1564-us , but [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin , unless [I]0-i desired it - which , as may be easily imagined , was seldom enough .

[[My]0-i new ally]1565-my new ally 's ready interference for [my]0-i advantage was exerted quietly , easily , and as a matter of course . [I]0-i never knew how , or when , [he]42-mr. sherwin influenced [[his]42-mr. sherwin employer]1384-his employer , and [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin on [his]42-mr. sherwin part , never breathed a word of that influence to [me]0-i . [He]42-mr. sherwin accorded any extra privilege [I]0-i might demand , as if [he]42-mr. sherwin acted entirely under [his]42-mr. sherwin own will , little suspecting how well [I]0-i knew what was the real motive power which directed [him]42-mr. sherwin .

[I]0-i was the more easily reconciled to employing the services of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , by the great delicacy with which [he]42-mr. sherwin performed [them]1567-them . [He]42-mr. sherwin did not allow [me]0-i to think - [he]42-mr. sherwin did not appear to think [himself]42-mr. sherwin - that [he]42-mr. sherwin was obliging [me]0-i in the smallest degree . [He]42-mr. sherwin affected no sudden intimacy with [me]0-i ; [his]42-mr. sherwin manners never altered ; [he]42-mr. sherwin still persisted in not joining [us]1568-us in the evening , but at [my]0-i express invitation ; and if [I]0-i referred in any way to the advantages [I]0-i derived from [his]42-mr. sherwin devotion to [my]0-i interests , [he]42-mr. sherwin always replied in [his]42-mr. sherwin brief undemonstrative way , that [he]42-mr. sherwin considered [himself]42-mr. sherwin [the favoured person]1569-the favoured person , in being permitted to make [his]42-mr. sherwin services of some use to [Margaret]44-margaret and [me]0-i .

[I]0-i had told [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , when [I]0-i was leaving [him]51-mr. mannion on the night of the storm , that [I]0-i would treat [his]51-mr. mannion offers as the offers of [a friend]512-a friend ; and [I]0-i had now made good [my]0-i words , much sooner and much more unreservedly than [I]0-i had ever intended , when [we]1571-we parted at [[his]51-mr. mannion own house]1473-his own house - door .

V.

The autumn was now over ; the winter - a cold , gloomy winter - had fairly come . Five months had nearly elapsed since [Clara]57-clara and [[my]0-i father]147-my father had departed for [the country]370-the country . What communication did [I]0-i hold with [them]1575-them , during that interval ?

No personal communication with either - written communication only with [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister . [Clara]57-clara 's letters to [me]0-i were frequent . [They]1575-them studiously avoided anything like a reproach for [my]0-i long absence ; and were confined almost exclusively to such details of country life as [the writer]495-the writer thought likely to interest [me]0-i . [Their]1575-them tone was as affectionate - nay , more affectionate , if possible - than usual ; but [Clara]57-clara 's gaiety and quiet humour , as [a correspondent]1578-a correspondent , were gone . [My]0-i conscience taught [me]0-i only too easily and too plainly how to account for this change - [my]0-i conscience told [me]0-i who had altered the tone of [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister 's letters , by altering all the favourite purposes and favourite pleasures of [her]296-my sister country life .

[I]0-i was selfishly enough devoted to [my]0-i own passions and [my]0-i own interests , at this period of [my]0-i life ; but [I]0-i was not so totally dead to every one of the influences which had guided [me]0-i since childhood , as to lose all thought of [Clara]57-clara and [[my]0-i father]147-my father , and [the ancient house that was associated with [my]0-i earliest and happiest recollections]1581-the ancient house that was associated with my earliest and happiest recollections . Sometimes , even in [Margaret]44-margaret 's beloved presence , a thought of [Clara]57-clara put away from [me]0-i all other thoughts . And , sometimes , in [the lonely London house]1582-the lonely london house , [I]0-i dreamed - with the strangest sleeping oblivion of [my]0-i marriage , and of all the new interests which it had crowded into [my]0-i life - of country rides with [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , and of quiet conversations in [the old gothic library]1584-the old gothic library at [the Hall]1423-the hall . Under such influences as these , [I]0-i twice resolved to make amends for [my]0-i long absence , by joining [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister in [the country]370-the country , even though it were only for a few days - and , each time , [I]0-i failed in [my]0-i resolution . On the second occasion , [I]0-i had actually mustered firmness enough to get as far as [the railway station]1589-the railway station ; and only at the last moment faltered and hung back . The struggle that it cost [me]0-i to part for any length of time from [Margaret]44-margaret , [I]0-i had overcome ; but the apprehension , as vivid as it was vague , that something - [I]0-i knew not what - might happen to [her]44-margaret in [my]0-i absence , turned [my]0-i steps backward at starting . [I]0-i felt heartily ashamed of [my]0-i own weakness ; but [I]0-i yielded to it nevertheless .

At last , a letter arrived from [Clara]57-clara , containing a summons to [the country]370-the country , which [I]0-i could not disobey .

" [I]57-clara have never asked [you]0-i , "[57-clara] [she]57-clara wrote , " to come and see [us]3479-us for [my]57-clara sake ; for [I]57-clara would not interfere with any of [your]0-i interests or any of [your]0-i plans ; but [I]57-clara now ask [you]0-i to come here for [your]0-i own sake - just for one week , and no more , unless [you]0-i like to remain longer . [You]0-i remember [papa]58-papa telling [you]0-i , in [[your]0-i room in [London]10-london]3480-your room in london , that [he]58-papa believed [you]0-i kept some secret from [him]58-papa . [I]57-clara am afraid this is preying on [his]58-papa mind : [your]0-i long absence is making [him]58-papa uneasy about [you]0-i . [He]58-papa does not say so ; but [he]58-papa never sends any message , when [I]57-clara write ; and if [I]57-clara speak about [you]0-i , [he]58-papa always changes the subject directly . Pray come here , and show [yourself]0-i for a few days - no questions will be asked , [you]0-i may be sure . It will do so much good ; and will prevent - what [I]57-clara hope and pray may never happen - a serious estrangement between [papa]3052-papa and [you]0-i . Recollect , [Basil]46-basil , in a month or six weeks [we]3482-we shall come back to [town]340-town ; and then the opportunity will be gone . "[57-clara]

As [I]0-i read these lines , [I]0-i determined to start for [the country]370-the country at once , while the effect of them was still fresh on [my]0-i mind . [Margaret]44-margaret , when [I]0-i took leave of [her]44-margaret , only said that [she]44-margaret should like to be going with [me]0-i - " it would be such a sight for [her]44-margaret , to see [a grand country house like]3484-a grand country house like [ours]3485-ours ! "[44-margaret] [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin laughed as coarsely as usual , at the difficulties [I]0-i made about only leaving [[his]42-mr. sherwin daughter]233-his daughter for a week . [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin very earnestly , and very inaccountably as [I]0-i then thought , recommended [me]0-i not to be away any longer than [I]0-i had proposed . [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion privately assured [me]0-i , that [I]0-i might depend on [him]42-mr. sherwin in [my]0-i absence from [North Villa]11-north villa , exactly as [I]0-i had always depended on [him]42-mr. sherwin , during [my]0-i presence [there]161-there . It was strange that [his]42-mr. sherwin parting words should be the only words which soothed and satisfied [me]0-i on taking leave of [London]10-london .

The winter afternoon was growing dim with the evening darkness , as [I]0-i drove up to [the Hall]1423-the hall . Snow on the ground , in [the country]370-the country , has always a cheerful look to [me]0-i . [I]0-i could have wished to see it on the day of [my]0-i arrival at [home]176-home ; but there had been a thaw for the last week - mud and water were all about [me]0-i - a drizzling rain was falling - a raw , damp wind was blowing - a fog was rising , as the evening stole on - and the ancient leafless elms in [the park avenue]1597-the park avenue groaned and creaked above [my]0-i head drearily , as [I]0-i approached [the house]244-the house .

[[My]0-i father]147-my father received [me]0-i with more ceremony than [I]0-i liked . [I]0-i had known , from [a boy]292-a boy , what it meant when [he]147-my father chose to be only polite to [[his]147-my father own son]1601-his own son . What construction [he]147-my father had put on [my]0-i long absence and [my]0-i persistence in keeping [my]0-i secret from [him]147-my father , [I]0-i could not tell ; but it was evident that [I]0-i had lost [my]0-i usual place in [his]147-my father estimation , and lost it past regaining merely by a week 's visit . The estrangement between [us]1602-us , which [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister had feared , had begun already .

[I]0-i had been chilled by the desolate aspect of nature , as [I]0-i approached [the Hall]1423-the hall ; [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's reception of [me]0-i , when [I]0-i entered [the house]244-the house , increased the comfortless and melancholy impressions produced on [my]0-i mind ; it required all the affectionate warmth of [Clara]57-clara 's welcome , all the pleasure of hearing [her]57-clara whisper [her]57-clara thanks , as [she]57-clara kissed [me]0-i , for [my]0-i readiness in following [her]57-clara advice , to restore [my]0-i equanimity . But even then , when the first hurry and excitement of meeting had passed away , in spite of [her]57-clara kind words and looks , there was something in [her]57-clara face which depressed [me]0-i . [She]57-clara seemed thinner , and [her]57-clara constitutional paleness was more marked than usual . Cares and anxieties had evidently oppressed [her]57-clara - was [I]0-i the cause of [them]1607-them ?

The dinner that evening proceeded very heavily and gloomily . [[My]0-i father]147-my father only talked on general and commonplace topics , as if [a mere acquaintance]1609-a mere acquaintance had been present . When [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister left [us]1611-us , [he]147-my father too quitted [the room]263-the room , to see [some one who had arrived on business]1613-some one who had arrived on business . [I]0-i had no heart for the company of the wine bottles , so [I]0-i followed [Clara]57-clara .

At first , [we]1611-us only spoke of [her]57-clara occupations since [she]57-clara had been in [the country]370-the country ; [I]0-i was unwilling , and [she]57-clara forbore , to touch on [my]0-i long stay in [London]10-london , or on [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's evident displeasure at [my]0-i protracted absence . There was a little restraint between [us]1611-us , which [neither]1616-neither had the courage to break through . Before long , however , an accident , trifling enough in itself , obliged [me]0-i to be more candid ; and enabled [her]57-clara to speak unreservedly on the subject nearest to [her]57-clara heart .

[I]0-i was seated opposite to [Clara]57-clara , at the fire - place , and was playing with a favourite dog which had followed [me]0-i into [the room]263-the room . While [I]0-i was stooping towards the animal , a locket containing some of [Margaret]44-margaret 's hair , fell out of its place in [my]0-i waistcoat , and swung towards [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister by the string which attached it round [my]0-i neck . [I]0-i instantly hid it again ; but not before [Clara]57-clara , with [a woman]325-a woman 's quickness , had detected the trinket as something new , and drawn the right inference , as to the use to which [I]0-i devoted it .

An expression of surprise and pleasure passed over [her]57-clara face ; [she]57-clara rose , and putting [her]57-clara hands on [my]0-i shoulders , as if to keep [me]0-i still in [the place [I]0-i occupied]1620-the place i occupied , looked at [me]0-i intently .

" [Basil]46-basil ! "[57-clara] [she]57-clara exclaimed , " if that is all the secret [you]46-basil have been keeping from [us]3486-us , how glad [I]57-clara am ! When [I]57-clara see a new locket drop out of [[my]57-clara brother]154-my brother 's waistcoat - "[57-clara] [she]57-clara continued , observing that [I]0-i was too confused to speak - " and when [I]57-clara find [him]154-my brother colouring very deeply , and hiding it again in a great hurry , [I]57-clara should be [no true woman]3488-no true woman if [I]57-clara did not make [my]57-clara own discoveries , and begin to talk about them directly . "[57-clara]

[I]0-i made an effort - a very poor one - to laugh the thing off . [Her]57-clara expression grew serious and thoughtful , while [she]57-clara still fixed [her]57-clara eyes on [me]0-i . [She]57-clara took [my]0-i hand gently , and whispered in [my]0-i ear : " Are [you]0-i going to be married , [Basil]46-basil ? Shall [I]57-clara love [[my]57-clara new sister]3489-my new sister almost as much as [I]57-clara love [you]0-i ? "[57-clara]

At that moment [the servant]315-the servant came in with tea . The interruption gave [me]0-i a minute for consideration . Should [I]0-i tell [her]57-clara all ? [Impulse]65-impulse answered , yes - reflection , no . If [I]0-i disclosed [my]0-i real situation , [I]0-i knew that [I]0-i must introduce [Clara]57-clara to [Margaret]44-margaret . This would necessitate taking [her]57-clara privately to [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's house]3406-mr. sherwin 's house , and exposing to [her]57-clara the humiliating terms of dependence and prohibition on which [I]0-i lived with [[my]0-i own wife]1623-my own wife . A strange medley of feelings , in which pride was uppermost , forbade [me]0-i to do that . Then again , to involve [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister in [my]0-i secret , would be to involve [her]57-clara with [me]0-i in any consequences which might be produced by its disclosure to [[my]0-i father]147-my father . The mere idea of making [her]57-clara a partaker in responsibilities which [I]0-i alone ought to bear , was not to be entertained for a moment . As soon as [we]1626-we were left together again , [I]0-i said to [her]57-clara :

" Will [you]57-clara not think the worse of [me]0-i , [Clara]57-clara , if [I]0-i leave [you]57-clara to draw [your]57-clara own conclusions from what [you]57-clara have seen ? only asking [you]57-clara to keep strict silence on the subject to every one . [I]0-i ca n't speak yet , love , as [I]0-i wish to speak : [you]57-clara will know why , some day , and say that [my]0-i reserve was right . In the meantime , can [you]57-clara be satisfied with the assurance , that when the time comes for making [my]0-i secret known , [you]57-clara shall be the first to know it - the first [I]0-i put trust in ? "[0-i]

" As [you]57-clara have not starved [my]57-clara curiosity altogether , "[57-clara] said [Clara]57-clara , smiling , " but have given it a little hope to feed on for the present , [I]57-clara think , [woman]3490-woman though [I]57-clara am , [I]57-clara can promise all [you]57-clara wish . Seriously , [Basil]46-basil , "[57-clara] [she]57-clara continued , " that telltale locket of [yours]46-basil has so pleasantly brightened some very gloomy thoughts of [mine]57-clara about [you]46-basil , that [I]57-clara can now live happily on expectation , without once mentioning [your]46-basil secret again , till [you]57-clara give [me]57-clara leave to do so . "[57-clara]

Here [[my]0-i father]147-my father entered [the room]263-the room , and [we]1629-we said no more . [His]147-my father manner towards [me]0-i had not altered since dinner ; and it remained the same during the week of [my]0-i stay at [the Hall]1423-the hall . One morning , when [we]1629-we were alone , [I]0-i took courage , and determined to try [the dangerous ground]1631-the dangerous ground a little , with a view towards [my]0-i guidance for the future ; but [I]0-i had no sooner begun by some reference to [my]0-i stay in [London]10-london , and some apology for it , than [he]147-my father stopped [me]0-i at once .

" [I]147-my father told [you]0-i , "[147-my father] [he]147-my father said , gravely and coldly , ' some months ago , that [I]0-i had too much faith in [your]0-i honour to intrude on affairs which [you]0-i choose to keep private . Until [you]0-i have perfect confidence in [me]0-i , and can speak with complete candour , [I]0-i will hear nothing . [You]0-i have not that confidence now - [you]0-i speak hesitatingly - [your]0-i eyes do not meet [mine]0-i fairly and boldly . [I]0-i tell [you]0-i again , [I]0-i will hear nothing which begins with such common - place excuses as [you]0-i have just addressed to [me]0-i . Excuses lead to prevarications , and prevarications to - what [I]0-i will not insult [you]0-i by imagining possible in [your]0-i case . [You]0-i are of age , and must know [your]0-i own responsibilities and [mine]0-i . Choose at once , between saying nothing , and saying all . "[0-i]

[He]0-i waited a moment after [he]0-i had spoken , and then quitted [the room]263-the room . If [he]0-i could only have known how [I]0-i suffered , at that instant , under the base necessities of concealment , [I]0-i might have confessed everything ; and [he]0-i must have pitied , though [he]0-i might not have forgiven [me]0-i .

This was [my]0-i first and last attempt at venturing towards the revelation of [my]0-i secret to [[my]0-i father]147-my father , by hints and half - admissions . As to boldly confessing it , [I]0-i persuaded [myself]0-i into a sophistical conviction that such a course could do no good , but might do much harm . When the wedded happiness [I]0-i had already waited for , and was to wait for still , through so many months , came at last , was it not best to enjoy [my]0-i married life in convenient secrecy , as long as [I]0-i could ? - best , to abstain from disclosing [my]0-i secret to [[my]0-i father]147-my father , until necessity absolutely obliged , or circumstances absolutely invited [me]0-i to do so ? [My]0-i inclinations conveniently decided the question in the affirmative ; and a decision of any kind , right or wrong , was enough to tranquillise [me]0-i at that time .

So far as [[my]0-i father]147-my father was concerned , [my]0-i journey to [the country]370-the country did no good . [I]0-i might have returned to [London]10-london the day after [my]0-i arrival at [the Hall]1423-the hall , without altering [his]147-my father opinion of [me]0-i - but [I]0-i stayed the whole week nevertheless , for [Clara]57-clara 's sake .

In spite of the pleasure afforded by [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister 's society , [my]0-i visit was a painful one . The selfish longing to be back with [Margaret]44-margaret , which [I]0-i could not wholly repress ; [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's coldness ; and the winter gloom and rain which confined [us]1640-us almost incessantly within doors , all tended in their different degrees to prevent [my]0-i living at ease in [the Hall]1423-the hall . But , besides these causes of embarrassment , [I]0-i had the additional mortification of feeling , for the first time , as [a stranger in [[my]0-i own home]1643-my own home]1642-a stranger in my own home .

Nothing in [the house]244-the house looked to [me]0-i what [it]244-the house used to look in former years . [The rooms]750-the rooms , [the old servants]1646-the old servants , the walks and views , the domestic animals , all appeared to have altered , or to have lost something , since [I]0-i had seen [them]1647-them last . [Particular rooms that [I]0-i had once been fond of occupying]1648-particular rooms that i had once been fond of occupying , were favourites no longer : particular habits that [I]0-i had hitherto always practised in [the country]370-the country , [I]0-i could only succeed in resuming by an effort which vexed and fretted [me]0-i . It was as if [my]0-i life had run into a new channel since [my]0-i last autumn and winter at [the Hall]1423-the hall , and now refused to flow back at [my]0-i bidding into [its]244-the house old course . [Home]176-home seemed [home]176-home no longer , except in name .

As soon as the week was over , [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [I]0-i parted exactly as [we]1654-we had met . When [I]0-i took leave of [Clara]57-clara , [she]57-clara refrained from making any allusion to the shortness of [my]0-i stay ; and merely said that [we]1654-we should soon meet again in [London]10-london . [She]57-clara evidently saw that [my]0-i visit had weighed a little on [my]0-i spirits , and was determined to give to [our]1654-we short farewell as happy and hopeful a character as possible . [We]1654-we now thoroughly understood [each other]102-each other ; and that was some consolation on leaving [her]57-clara .

Immediately on [my]0-i return to [London]10-london [I]0-i repaired to [North Villa]11-north villa .

Nothing , [I]0-i was told , had happened in [my]0-i absence , but [I]0-i remarked some change in [Margaret]44-margaret . [She]44-margaret looked pale and nervous , and was more silent than [I]0-i had ever known [her]44-margaret to be before , when [we]1654-we met . [She]44-margaret accounted for this , in answer to [my]0-i inquiries , by saying that confinement to [the house]244-the house , in consequence of the raw , wintry weather , had a little affected [her]44-margaret ; and then changed the subject . In other directions , household aspects had not deviated from [their]1657-their accustomed monotony . As usual , [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin was at [her]43-mrs. sherwin post in [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room ; and [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband was reading the evening paper , over [his]480-her husband renowned old port , in [the dining - room]165-the dining - room . After the first five minutes of [my]0-i arrival , [I]0-i adapted [myself]0-i again to [my]0-i old way of life at [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's]1474-mr. sherwin 's , as easily as if [I]0-i had never interrupted it for a single day . Henceforth , wherever [[my]0-i young wife]1411-my young wife was , there , and there only , would it be [home]176-home for [me]0-i !

Late in the evening , [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion arrived with some business letters for [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's inspection . [I]0-i sent for [him]51-mr. mannion into [the hall]1423-the hall to see [me]0-i , as [I]0-i was going away . [His]51-mr. mannion hand was never a warm one ; but as [I]0-i now took it , on greeting [him]51-mr. mannion , it was so deadly cold that it literally chilled [mine]0-i for the moment . [He]51-mr. mannion only congratulated [me]0-i , in the usual terms , on [my]0-i safe return ; and said that nothing had taken place in [my]0-i absence - but in [his]51-mr. mannion utterance of those few words , [I]0-i discovered , for the first time , a change in [his]51-mr. mannion voice : [his]51-mr. mannion tones were lower , and [his]51-mr. mannion articulation quicker than usual . This , joined to the extraordinary coldness of [his]51-mr. mannion hand , made [me]0-i inquire whether [he]51-mr. mannion was unwell . Yes , [he]51-mr. mannion too had been ill while [I]0-i was away - harassed with hard work , [he]51-mr. mannion said . Then apologising for leaving [me]0-i abruptly , on account of the letters [he]51-mr. mannion had brought with [him]51-mr. mannion , [he]51-mr. mannion returned to [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , in [the dining - room]165-the dining - room , with a greater appearance of hurry in [his]51-mr. mannion manner than [I]0-i had ever remarked in it on any former occasion .

[I]0-i had left [Margaret]44-margaret and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion both well - [I]0-i returned , and found [them]1666-them both ill . Surely this was something that had taken place in [my]0-i absence , though [they]1666-them all said that nothing had happened . But trifling illnesses seemed to be little regarded at [North Villa]11-north villa - perhaps , because serious illness was perpetually present there , in the person of [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin .

VI .

About six weeks after [I]0-i had left [the Hall]1423-the hall , [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [Clara]57-clara returned to [London]10-london for the season .

It is not [my]0-i intention to delay over [my]0-i life either at [home]176-home or at [North Villa]11-north villa , during the spring and summer . This would be merely to repeat much of what has been already related . It is better to proceed at once to the closing period of [my]0-i probation ; to a period which it taxes [my]0-i resolution severely to write of at all . A few weeks more of toil at [my]0-i narrative , and the penance of this poor task - work will be over .

Imagine then , that the final day of [my]0-i long year of expectation has arrived ; and that on the morrow , [Margaret]44-margaret , for whose sake [I]0-i have sacrificed and suffered so much , is at last really to be [mine]0-i .

On the eve of the great change in [my]0-i life that was now to take place , the relative positions in which [I]0-i , and [the different persons with whom [I]0-i was associated]1670-the different persons with whom i was associated , stood towards [each other]102-each other , may be sketched thus : -

[[My]0-i father]147-my father 's coldness of manner had not altered since [his]147-my father return to [London]10-london . On [my]0-i side , [I]0-i carefully abstained from uttering a word before [him]147-my father , which bore the smallest reference to [my]0-i real situation . Although when [we]1673-we met , [we]1673-we outwardly preserved the usual relations of [parent]1674-parent and [child]3426-child , the estrangement between [us]1673-we had now become complete .

[Clara]57-clara did not fail to perceive this , and grieved over it in secret . Other and happier feelings , however , became awakened within [her]57-clara , when [I]0-i privately hinted that the time for disclosing [my]0-i secret to [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister was not far off . [She]57-clara grew almost as much agitated as [I]0-i was , though by very different expectations - [she]57-clara could think of nothing else but the explanation and the surprise in store for [her]57-clara . Sometimes , [I]0-i almost feared to keep [her]57-clara any longer in suspense ; and half regretted having said anything on the subject of the new and absorbing interest of [my]0-i life , before the period when [I]0-i could easily have said all .

[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin and [I]0-i had not latterly met on the most cordial terms . [He]42-mr. sherwin was dissatisfied with [me]0-i for not having boldly approached the subject of [my]0-i marriage in [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's presence ; and considered [my]0-i reasons for still keeping it secret , as dictated by morbid apprehension , and as showing a total want of proper firmness . On the other hand , [he]42-mr. sherwin was obliged to set against this omission on [my]0-i part , the readiness [I]0-i had shown in meeting [his]42-mr. sherwin wishes on all remaining points . [My]0-i life was insured in [Margaret]44-margaret 's favour ; and [I]0-i had arranged to be called to the bar immediately , so as to qualify [myself]0-i in good time for every possible place within place - hunting range . [My]0-i assiduity in making these preparations for securing [Margaret]44-margaret 's prospects and [mine]0-i against any evil chances that might happen , failed in producing the favourable effect on [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , which [they]1678-they must assuredly have produced on [a less selfish man]1679-a less selfish man . But [they]1678-they obliged [him]42-mr. sherwin , at least , to stop short at occasional grumblings about [my]0-i reserve with [[my]0-i father]147-my father , and to maintain towards [me]0-i a sort of sulky politeness , which was , after all , less offensive than the usual infliction of [his]42-mr. sherwin cordiality , with its unfailing accompaniment of dull stories and duller jokes .

During the spring and summer , [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin appeared to grow feebler and feebler , from continued ill - health . Occasionally , [her]43-mrs. sherwin words and actions - especially in [her]43-mrs. sherwin intercourse with [me]0-i - suggested fears that [her]43-mrs. sherwin mind was beginning to give way , as well as [her]43-mrs. sherwin body . For instance , on one occasion , when [Margaret]44-margaret had left [the room]263-the room for a minute or two , [she]44-margaret suddenly hurried up to [me]0-i , whispering with eager looks and anxious tones : - " Watch over [[your]0-i wife]3287-your wife - mind [you]0-i watch over [her]3287-your wife , and keep [all bad people]3492-all bad people from [her]3287-your wife ! [I]44-margaret 've tried to do it - mind [you]0-i do it , too ! "[44-margaret] [I]0-i asked immediately for an explanation of this extraordinary injunction ; but [she]44-margaret only answered by muttering something about [a mother]1682-a mother 's anxieties , and then returned hastily to [her]44-margaret place . It was impossible to induce [her]44-margaret to be more explicit , try how [I]0-i might .

[Margaret]44-margaret once or twice occasioned [me]0-i much perplexity and distress , by certain inconsistencies and variations in [her]44-margaret manner , which began to appear shortly after [my]0-i return to [North Villa]11-north villa from [the country]370-the country . At one time , [she]44-margaret would become , on a sudden , strangely sullen and silent - at another , irritable and capricious . Then , again , [she]44-margaret would abruptly change to the most affectionate warmth of speech and demeanour , anxiously anticipating every wish [I]0-i could form , eagerly showing [her]44-margaret gratitude for the slightest attentions [I]0-i paid [her]44-margaret . These unaccountable alterations of manner vexed and irritated [me]0-i indescribably . [I]0-i loved [Margaret]44-margaret too well to be able to look philosophically on the imperfections of [her]44-margaret character ; [I]0-i knew of no cause given by [me]0-i for the frequent changes in [her]44-margaret conduct , and , if they only proceeded from coquetry , then coquetry , as [I]0-i once told [her]44-margaret , was the last female accomplishment that could charm [me]0-i in [any woman whom [I]0-i really loved]1684-any woman whom i really loved . However , these causes of annoyance and regret - [her]44-margaret caprices , and [my]0-i remonstrances - all passed happily away , as the term of [my]0-i engagement with [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin approached its end , [Margaret]44-margaret 's better and lovelier manner returned . Occasionally , [she]44-margaret might betray some symptoms of confusion , some evidences of unusual thoughtfulness - but [I]0-i remembered how near was the day of the emancipation of [our]1685-our love , and looked on [her]44-margaret embarrassment as a fresh charm , a new ornament to the beauty of [[my]0-i maiden wife]1686-my maiden wife .

[Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion continued - as far as attention to [my]0-i interests went - to be [the same ready and reliable friend]1687-the same ready and reliable friend as ever ; but [he]51-mr. mannion was , in some other respects , [an altered man]1688-an altered man . The illness of which [he]51-mr. mannion had complained months back , when [I]0-i returned to [London]10-london , seemed to have increased . [His]51-mr. mannion face was still the same impenetrable face which had so powerfully impressed [me]0-i when [I]0-i first saw [him]51-mr. mannion , but [his]51-mr. mannion manner , hitherto so quiet and self - possessed , had now grown abrupt and variable . Sometimes , when [he]51-mr. mannion joined [us]1685-our in [the drawing - room at [North Villa]11-north villa]1467-the drawing - room at north villa , [he]51-mr. mannion would suddenly stop before [we]1685-our had exchanged more than three or four words , murmur something , in a voice unlike [his]51-mr. mannion usual voice , about an attack of spasm and giddiness , and leave [the room]263-the room .
