These fits of illness had something in their nature of the same secrecy which distinguished everything else connected with [him]51-mr. mannion : they produced no external signs of distortion , no unusual paleness in [his]51-mr. mannion face - [you]1691-you could not guess what pain [he]51-mr. mannion was suffering , or where [he]51-mr. mannion was suffering it . Latterly , [I]0-i abstained from ever asking [him]51-mr. mannion to join [us]1685-our ; for the effect on [Margaret]44-margaret of [his]51-mr. mannion sudden attacks of illness was , naturally , such as to discompose [her]44-margaret seriously for the remainder of the evening . Whenever [I]0-i saw [him]51-mr. mannion accidentally , at later periods of the year , the influence of the genial summer season appeared to produce no alteration for the better in [him]51-mr. mannion . [I]0-i remarked that [his]51-mr. mannion cold hand , which had chilled [me]0-i when [I]0-i took it on the raw winter night of [my]0-i return from [the country]370-the country , was as cold as ever , on the warm summer days which preceded the close of [my]0-i engagement at [North Villa]11-north villa .

Such was the posture of affairs at [home]176-home , and at [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's , when [I]0-i went to see [Margaret]44-margaret for the last time in [my]0-i old character , on the last night which yet remained to separate [us]1685-our from [each other]102-each other .

[I]0-i had been all day preparing for [our]1685-our reception , on the morrow , in [a cottage which [I]0-i had taken for a month , in [a retired part of [the country]370-the country]1696-a retired part of the country , at [some distance from [London]10-london]1698-some distance from london]1695-a cottage which i had taken for a month , in a retired part of the country , at some distance from london . One month 's unalloyed happiness with [Margaret]44-margaret , away from [the world]158-the world and all worldly considerations , was [the Eden upon earth towards which [my]0-i dearest hope and anticipations had pointed for a whole year past]1700-the eden upon earth towards which my dearest hope and anticipations had pointed for a whole year past - and now , now at last , those aspirations were to be realized ! All [my]0-i arrangements at [the cottage]1701-the cottage were completed in time to allow [me]0-i to return [home]176-home , just before [our]1685-our usual late dinner hour . During the meal , [I]0-i provided for [my]0-i month 's absence from [London]10-london , by informing [[my]0-i father]147-my father that [I]0-i proposed visiting [one of [[my]0-i country friends]1705-my country friends]1704-one of my country friends . [He]147-my father heard [me]0-i as coldly and indifferently as usual ; and , as [I]0-i anticipated , did not even ask to what [[friend]1706-friend 's house [I]0-i was going]1707-friend 's house i was going . After dinner , [I]0-i privately informed [Clara]57-clara that on the morrow , before starting , [I]0-i would , in accordance with [my]0-i promise , make [her]57-clara the depositary of [my]0-i long - treasured secret - which , as yet , was not to be divulged to [any one besides]1708-any one besides . This done , [I]0-i hurried away , between nine and ten o'clock , for a last half - hour 's visit to [North Villa]11-north villa ; hardly able to realise [my]0-i own situation , or to comprehend the fulness and exaltation of [my]0-i own joy .

A disappointment was in store for [me]0-i . [Margaret]44-margaret was not in [the house]244-the house ; [she]44-margaret had gone out to an evening party , given by [a maiden aunt of [hers]44-margaret]1710-a maiden aunt of hers , who was known to be very rich , and was , accordingly , [a person to be courted and humoured by [the family]179-the family]1711-a person to be courted and humoured by the family .

[I]0-i was angry as well as disappointed at what had taken place . To send [Margaret]44-margaret out , on this evening of all others , showed a want of consideration towards both of [us]1713-us , which revolted [me]0-i . [Mr.]1714-mr. and [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin were in [the room]263-the room when [I]0-i entered ; and to [him]1714-mr. [I]0-i spoke [my]0-i opinion on the subject , in no very conciliatory terms . [He]1714-mr. was suffering from a bad attack of headache , and a worse attack of ill - temper , and answered as irritably as [he]1714-mr. dared .

" [[My]1714-mr. good Sir]3493-my good sir ! "[1714-mr.] [he]1714-mr. said , in sharp , querulous tones , " do , for once , allow [me]1714-mr. to know what 's best . [You]0-i 'll have it all [your]0-i way to - morrow - just let [me]1714-mr. have [mine]1714-mr. , for the last time , to - night . [I]1714-mr. 'm sure [you]0-i 've been humoured often enough about keeping [Margaret]44-margaret away from parties - and [we]3494-we should have humoured [you]0-i this time , too ; but a second letter came from [the old lady]3495-the old lady , saying [she]3495-the old lady should be affronted if [Margaret]44-margaret was n't [one of [[her]3495-the old lady guests]3497-her guests]3496-one of her guests . [I]1714-mr. could n't go and talk [her]3495-the old lady over , because of this infernal headache of [mine]1714-mr. - Hang it ! it 's [your]0-i interest that [Margaret]44-margaret should keep in with [[her]44-margaret aunt]3498-her aunt ; [she]44-margaret 'll have all [the old girl]3499-the old girl 's money , if [she]44-margaret only plays [her]44-margaret cards decently well . That 's why [I]1714-mr. sent [her]44-margaret to the party - [her]44-margaret going will be worth some thousands to both of [you]0-i one of these days . [She]44-margaret 'll be back by half - past twelve , or before . [Mannion]51-mr. mannion was asked ; and though [he]51-mr. mannion 's all out of sorts , [he]51-mr. mannion 's gone to take care of [her]44-margaret , and bring [her]44-margaret back . [I]1714-mr. 'll warrant [she]44-margaret comes [home]176-home in good time , when [he]51-mr. mannion 's with [her]44-margaret . So [you]0-i see there 's nothing to make a fuss about , after all . "[1714-mr.]

It was certainly a relief to hear that [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion was taking care of [Margaret]44-margaret . [He]51-mr. mannion was , in [my]0-i opinion , much fitter for such a trust than [[her]44-margaret own father]1716-her own father . Of all the good services [he]51-mr. mannion had done for [me]0-i , [I]0-i thought this the best - but it would have been even better still , if [he]51-mr. mannion had prevented [Margaret]44-margaret from going to the party .

" [I]42-mr. sherwin must say again , "[42-mr. sherwin] resumed [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin , still more irritably , finding [I]0-i did not at once answer [him]42-mr. sherwin , " there 's nothing that [any reasonable being]3501-any reasonable being need make a fuss about . "[0-i]

" [I]42-mr. sherwin am sorry for [your]0-i illness , [Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin ; and [I]42-mr. sherwin do n't doubt [your]0-i good intentions , or the advantage of [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's protection for [Margaret]44-margaret ; but [I]42-mr. sherwin feel disappointed , nevertheless , that [she]44-margaret should have gone out to - night . "[42-mr. sherwin]

" [I]0-i said [she]44-margaret ought n't to go at all , whatever [[her]44-margaret aunt]3498-her aunt wrote - [I]0-i said that . "[0-i]

This bold speech actually proceeded from [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin ! [I]0-i had never before heard [her]43-mrs. sherwin utter an opinion in [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband 's presence - such an outburst from [her]43-mrs. sherwin , was perfectly inexplicable . [She]43-mrs. sherwin pronounced the words with desperate rapidity , and unwonted power of tone , fixing [her]43-mrs. sherwin eyes all the while on [me]0-i with a very strange expression .

" Damn it , [Mrs. S.]53-mrs. s. ! "[480-her husband] roared [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband in a fury , " will [you]0-i hold [your]0-i tongue ? "[480-her husband]

Here [he]1719-his stopped ; and vented the rest of [his]1719-his ill - humour by ringing the bell violently for " [his]1719-his arrow - root , "[1719-his] and abusing [the servant]315-the servant when [she]315-the servant brought it .

[I]0-i hesitated about accepting [his]1719-his proposal . While [I]0-i was in doubt , [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin took the opportunity , when [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband 's eye was off [her]43-mrs. sherwin , of nodding [her]43-mrs. sherwin head at [me]0-i significantly . [She]43-mrs. sherwin evidently wished [me]0-i to join [Margaret]44-margaret at the party - but why ? What did [her]43-mrs. sherwin behaviour mean ?

It was useless to inquire . Long bodily suffering and weakness had but too palpably produced a corresponding feebleness in [her]43-mrs. sherwin intellect . What should [I]0-i do ? [I]0-i was resolved to see [Margaret]44-margaret that night ; but to wait for [her]44-margaret between two and three hours , in company with [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father and [mother]1225-mother at [North Villa]11-north villa , was an infliction not to be endured . [I]0-i determined to go to the party . [No one]743-no one there would know anything about [me]0-i . [They]1725-they would be [all people who lived in a different world from [mine]0-i]1726-all people who lived in a different world from mine ; and whose manners and habits [I]0-i might find some amusement in studying . At any rate , [I]0-i should spend an hour or two with [Margaret]44-margaret , and could make it [my]0-i own charge to see [her]44-margaret safely [home]176-home . Without further hesitation , therefore [I]0-i took up the envelope with the address on it , and bade [Mr.]1728-mr. and [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin good - night .

It struck ten as [I]0-i left [North Villa]11-north villa . The moonlight which was just beginning to shine brilliantly on [my]0-i arrival [there]161-there , now appeared but at rare intervals ; for the clouds were spreading thicker and thicker over the whole surface of the sky , as the night advanced .

VII .

The address to which [I]0-i was now proceeding , led [me]0-i some distance away from [[Mr. Sherwin]42-mr. sherwin 's place of abode]1730-mr. sherwin 's place of abode , in the direction of [the populous neighbourhood which lies on [the western side of [the Edgeware Road]1733-the edgeware road]1732-the western side of the edgeware road]1731-the populous neighbourhood which lies on the western side of the edgeware road . [The house of [Margaret]44-margaret 's aunt]1734-the house of margaret 's aunt was plainly enough indicated to [me]0-i , as soon as [I]0-i entered [the street]163-the street where [it]1734-the house of margaret 's aunt stood , by the glare of light from the windows , the sound of dance music , and [the nondescript group of [cabmen]1737-cabmen and [linkmen]1738-linkmen , with [their]1736-the nondescript group of cabmen and linkmen , with their little train of idlers in attendance little train of idlers in attendance]1736-the nondescript group of cabmen and linkmen , with their little train of idlers in attendance , assembled outside the door . It was evidently a very large party . [I]0-i hesitated about going in .

[My]0-i sensations were not those which fit [a man]3101-a man for exchanging conventional civilities with [perfect strangers]1740-perfect strangers ; [I]0-i felt that [I]0-i showed outwardly the fever of joy and expectation within [me]0-i . Could [I]0-i preserve [my]0-i assumed character of [a mere friend of [the family]179-the family]1741-a mere friend of the family , in [Margaret]44-margaret 's presence ? - and on this night too , of all others ? It was far more probable that [my]0-i behaviour , if [I]0-i went to the party , would betray everything to [everybody assembled]1743-everybody assembled . [I]0-i determined to walk about in [the neighbourhood of [the house]244-the house]1744-the neighbourhood of the house , until twelve o'clock ; and then to go into [the hall]1423-the hall , and send up [my]0-i card to [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion , with a message on it , intimating that [I]0-i was waiting below to accompany [him]51-mr. mannion to [North Villa]11-north villa with [Margaret]44-margaret .

[I]0-i crossed [the street]163-the street , and looked up again at [the house]244-the house from the pavement opposite . Then lingered a little , listening to the music as it reached [me]0-i through the windows , and imagining to [myself]0-i [[Margaret]44-margaret 's occupation]1749-margaret 's occupation at that moment . After this , [I]0-i turned away ; and set forth eastward on [my]0-i walk , careless in which direction [I]0-i traced [my]0-i steps .

[I]0-i felt little impatience , and no sense of fatigue ; for in less than two hours more [I]0-i knew that [I]0-i should see [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife again . Until then , the present had no existence for [me]0-i - [I]0-i lived in the past and future . [I]0-i wandered indifferently along [lonely bye - streets]1751-lonely bye - streets , and [crowded thoroughfares]1752-crowded thoroughfares . Of all the sights which attend a night - walk in [a great city]1753-a great city , not one attracted [my]0-i notice . Uninformed and unobservant , neither saddened nor startled , [I]0-i passed through [the glittering highways of [London]10-london]1754-the glittering highways of london . All sounds were silent to [me]0-i save the love - music of [my]0-i own thoughts ; all sights had vanished before the bright form that moved through [my]0-i bridal dream . Where was [[my]0-i world]1755-my world , at that moment ? Narrowed to [the cottage in [the country]370-the country which was to receive [us]1758-us on the morrow]1756-the cottage in the country which was to receive us on the morrow . Where were the beings in [the world]158-the world ? All merged in one - [Margaret]44-margaret .

Sometimes , [my]0-i thoughts glided back , dreamily and voluptuously , to the day when [I]0-i first met [her]44-margaret . Sometimes , [I]0-i recalled the summer evenings when [we]1758-us sat and read together out of the same book ; and , once more , it was as if [I]0-i breathed with the breath , and hoped with the hopes , and longed with the old longings of those days . But oftenest it was with the morrow that [my]0-i mind was occupied . The first dream of [all young men]1760-all young men - the dream of living rapturously with [the woman [they]1760-all young men love , in a secret retirement kept sacred from [friends]440-friends and from [strangers alike]1763-strangers alike]1761-the woman they love , in a secret retirement kept sacred from friends and from strangers alike , was now [my]0-i dream ; to be realised in a few hours , to be realised with [my]0-i waking on the morning which was already at hand !

For the last quarter of an hour of [my]0-i walk , [I]0-i must have been unconsciously retracing [my]0-i steps towards [the house of [[Margaret]44-margaret 's aunt]3509-margaret 's aunt]1734-the house of margaret 's aunt . [I]0-i came in sight of [it]1734-the house of margaret 's aunt again , just as the sound of the neighbouring church clocks , striking eleven , roused [me]0-i from [my]0-i abstraction . [More cabs]1766-more cabs were in [the street]163-the street ; [more people]1768-more people were gathered about the door , by this time . Was all this bustle , the bustle of arrival or of departure ? Was the party about to break up , at an hour when parties usually begin ? [I]0-i determined to go nearer to [the house]244-the house , and ascertain whether the music had ceased , or not .

[I]0-i had approached close enough to hear the notes of the harp and pianoforte still sounding as gaily as ever , when the house - door was suddenly flung open for the departure of [a lady]1770-a lady and [gentleman]1771-gentleman . The light from [the hall]1423-the hall - lamps fell on [their]1773-their faces ; and showed [me]0-i [Margaret]44-margaret and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion .

Going [home]176-home already ! An hour and a half before it was time to return ! Why ?

There could be but one reason . [Margaret]44-margaret was thinking of [me]0-i , and of what [I]0-i should feel if [I]0-i called at [North Villa]11-north villa , and had to wait for [her]44-margaret till past midnight . [I]0-i ran forward to speak to [them]1773-their , as [they]1773-their descended the steps ; but exactly at the same moment , [my]0-i voice was overpowered , and [my]0-i further progress barred , by a scuffle on the pavement among [the people who stood between [us]1776-us]1775-the people who stood between us . [One man]1777-one man said that [his]1777-one man pocket had been picked ; [others]98-others roared to [him]1777-one man that [they]98-others had caught [the thief]1779-the thief . There was a fight - [the police]1780-the police came up - [I]0-i was surrounded on all sides by [a shouting , struggling mob that seemed to have gathered in an instant]1781-a shouting , struggling mob that seemed to have gathered in an instant .

Before [I]0-i could force [myself]0-i out of [the crowd]1782-the crowd , and escape into [the road]1783-the road , [Margaret]44-margaret and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion had hurried into [a cab]637-a cab . [I]0-i just saw [the vehicle driving off]1785-the vehicle driving off rapidly , as [I]0-i got free . [An empty cab]1786-an empty cab was standing near [me]0-i - [I]0-i jumped into [it]1786-an empty cab directly - and told [the man]696-the man to overtake [them]1788-them . After having waited [my]0-i time so patiently , to let a mere accident stop [me]0-i from going [home]176-home with [them]1788-them , as [I]0-i had resolved , was not to be thought of for a moment . [I]0-i was hot and angry , after [my]0-i contest with [the crowd]1782-the crowd ; and could have flogged on the miserable cab - horse with [my]0-i own hand , rather than have failed in [my]0-i purpose .

[We]1791-we were just getting closer behind [them]1788-them : [I]0-i had just put [my]0-i head out of the window to call to [them]1788-them , and to bid [the man who was driving [me]0-i]1792-the man who was driving me , call , too - when [[their]1788-them cab]1793-their cab abruptly turned down [a bye - street]1794-a bye - street , in a direction exactly opposite to the direction which led to [North Villa]11-north villa .

What did this mean ? Why were [they]1788-them not going straight [home]176-home ?

[The cabman]1796-the cabman asked [me]0-i whether [he]1796-the cabman should not hail [them]1788-them before [they]1788-them got farther away from [us]1791-we ; frankly confessing , as [he]1796-the cabman put the question , that [his]1796-the cabman horse was nothing like equal to the pace of the horse ahead . [Mechanically]66-mechanically , without assignable purpose or motive , [I]0-i declined [his]1796-the cabman offer , and told [him]1796-the cabman simply to follow at any distance [he]1796-the cabman could . While the words passed [my]0-i lips , a strange sensation stole over [me]0-i : [I]0-i seemed to be speaking as the mere mouthpiece of some other voice . From feeling hot , and moving about restlessly the moment before , [I]0-i felt unaccountably cold , and sat still now . What caused this ?

[My]0-i cab stopped . [I]0-i looked out , and saw that the horse had fallen . " [We]1798-them 've lots of time , [Sir]3046-sir , "[1797-the driver] said [the driver]1797-the driver , as [he]1797-the driver coolly stepped off the box , " [they]1798-them are just pulling up further down [the road]1783-the road . "[1797-the driver] [I]0-i gave [him]1796-the cabman some money , and got out immediately - determined to overtake [them]1798-them on foot .

It was [a very lonely place]1799-a very lonely place - [a colony of half - finished streets]1800-a colony of half - finished streets , and half - inhabited houses , which had grown up in [the neighbourhood of [a great railway station]1802-a great railway station]1801-the neighbourhood of a great railway station . [I]0-i heard the fierce scream of the whistle , and the heaving , heavy throb of the engine starting on its journey , as [I]0-i advanced along [the gloomy Square in which [I]0-i now found [myself]0-i]1803-the gloomy square in which i now found myself . [The cab [I]0-i had been following]1804-the cab i had been following stood at a turning which led into [a long street]1805-a long street , occupied towards the farther end , by [shops closed for the night]1806-shops closed for the night , and at the end nearest [me]0-i , apparently by [private houses]1807-private houses only . [Margaret]44-margaret and [Mr. Mannion]51-mr. mannion hastily left [the cab]1808-the cab , and without looking either to the right or the left , hurried down [the street]163-the street . [They]1798-them stopped at [the ninth house]1810-the ninth house . [I]0-i followed just in time to hear the door closed on [them]1798-them , and to count the number of doors intervening between that door and [the Square]717-the square .

The awful thrill of a suspicion which [I]0-i hardly knew yet for what it really was , began to creep over [me]0-i - to creep like a dead - cold touch crawling through and through [me]0-i to the heart . [I]0-i looked up at [the house]244-the house . [It]244-the house was [an hotel]1813-an hotel - [a neglected , deserted , dreary - looking building]1814-a neglected , deserted , dreary - looking building . Still acting mechanically ; still with no definite impulse that [I]0-i could recognise , even if [I]0-i felt it , except the instinctive resolution to follow [them]1798-them into [the house]244-the house , as [I]0-i had already followed [them]1798-them through [the street]163-the street - [I]0-i walked up to the door , and rang the bell .

It was answered by [a waiter]1817-a waiter - [a mere lad]1818-a mere lad . As the light in [the passage]1048-the passage fell on [my]0-i face , [he]1817-a waiter paused in the act of addressing [me]0-i , and drew back a few steps . Without stopping for any explanations , [I]0-i closed the door behind [me]0-i , and said to [him]1817-a waiter at once :

" [A lady]1770-a lady and [gentleman]1771-gentleman came into [this hotel]3514-this hotel a little while ago . "[0-i]

" What may [your]1817-a waiter business be ? "[1817-a waiter] - [He]1817-a waiter hesitated , and added in an altered tone , " [I]1817-a waiter mean , what may [you]0-i want with [them]1798-them , [Sir]3046-sir ? "[1817-a waiter]

" [I]1817-a waiter want [you]3046-sir to take [me]1817-a waiter where [I]1817-a waiter can hear [their]1798-them voices , and [I]1817-a waiter want nothing more . Here 's a sovereign for [you]3046-sir , if [you]3046-sir do what [I]1817-a waiter ask . "[1817-a waiter]

[His]1817-a waiter eyes fastened covetously on the gold , as [I]0-i held it before [them]1820-them . [He]1817-a waiter retired a few steps on tiptoe , and listened at the end of [the passage]1048-the passage . [I]0-i heard nothing but the thick , rapid beating of [my]0-i own heart . [He]1817-a waiter came back , muttering to [himself]1817-a waiter : " [Master]491-master 's safe at [supper down stairs]3517-supper down stairs - [I]1817-a waiter 'll risk it ! [You]0-i 'll promise to go away directly , "[1817-a waiter] [he]1817-a waiter added , whispering to [me]0-i , " and not disturb [the house]244-the house ? [We]3519-we are [quiet people]3520-quiet people here , and ca n't have anything like a disturbance . Just say at once , will [you]0-i promise to step soft , and not speak a word ? "[1817-a waiter]

" [I]1817-a waiter promise . "[1817-a waiter]

" This way then , [Sir]3046-sir - and mind [you]0-i do n't forget to step soft . "[1817-a waiter]

A strange coldness and stillness , an icy insensibility , a dream - sensation of being impelled by some hidden , irresistible agency , possessed [me]0-i , as [I]0-i followed [him]1817-a waiter [upstairs]3063-upstairs . [He]1817-a waiter showed [me]0-i softly into [an empty room]1823-an empty room ; pointed to one of the walls , whispering , " It 's only boards papered over - "[1817-a waiter] and then waited , keeping [his]1817-a waiter eyes anxiously and steadily fixed upon all [my]0-i movements .

[I]0-i listened ; and through the thin partition , [I]0-i heard voices - [her]1824-her voice , and [his]1817-a waiter voice . [I]0-i heard and [I]0-i knew - knew [my]0-i degradation in all its infamy , knew [my]0-i wrongs in all [their]1825-their nameless horror . [He]1817-a waiter was exulting in the patience and secrecy which had brought success to the foul plot , foully hidden for months on months ; foully hidden until the very day before [I]0-i was to have claimed as [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife , [a wretch as guilty as [himself]1817-a waiter]1827-a wretch as guilty as himself !

[I]0-i could neither move nor breathe . The blood surged and heaved upward to [my]0-i brain ; [my]0-i heart strained and writhed in anguish ; the life within [me]0-i raged and tore to get free . Whole years of the direst mental and bodily agony were concentrated in that one moment of helpless , motionless torment . [I]0-i never lost the consciousness of suffering . [I]0-i heard [the waiter]1828-the waiter say , under [his]1828-the waiter breath , " [[My]1828-the waiter God]3522-my god ! [he]1828-the waiter 's dying . "[1828-the waiter] [I]0-i felt [him]1828-the waiter loosen [my]0-i cravat - [I]0-i knew that [he]1828-the waiter dashed cold water over [me]0-i ; dragged [me]0-i out of [the room]263-the room ; and , opening a window on [the landing]1830-the landing , held [me]0-i firmly where the night - air blew upon [my]0-i face . [I]0-i knew all this ; and knew when the paroxysm passed , and nothing remained of it , but a shivering helplessness in every limb .

[Erelong]67-erelong , the power of thinking began to return to [me]0-i by degrees .

Misery , and shame , and horror , and a vain yearning to hide [myself]0-i from [all human eyes]1831-all human eyes , and weep out [my]0-i life in secret , overcame [me]0-i . Then , these subsided ; and ONE THOUGHT slowly arose in [their]1832-their stead - arose , and cast down before it every obstacle of conscience , every principle of education , every care for the future , every remembrance of the past , every weakening influence of present misery , every repressing tie of [family]860-family and [home]176-home , every anxiety for good fame in this life , and every idea of the next that was to come . Before the fell poison of that Thought , all other thoughts - good or evil - died . As it spoke secretly within [me]0-i , [I]0-i felt [my]0-i bodily strength coming back ; a quick vigour leapt hotly through [my]0-i frame . [I]0-i turned , and looked round towards [the room [we]1836-we had just left]1126-the room we had just left - [my]0-i mind was looking at [the room beyond [it]1126-the room we had just left]1837-the room beyond it , [the room [they]1832-their were in]1838-the room they were in .

[The waiter]1828-the waiter was still standing by [my]0-i side , watching [me]0-i intently . [He]1828-the waiter suddenly started back ; and , with pale face and staring eyes , pointed down [the stairs]1840-the stairs .

" [You]0-i go , "[1828-the waiter] [he]1828-the waiter whispered , " go directly ! [You]0-i 're well now - [I]1828-the waiter 'm afraid to have [you]0-i [here]3265-here any longer . [I]1828-the waiter saw [your]0-i look , [your]0-i horrid look at [that room]3524-that room ! [You]0-i 've heard what [you]0-i wanted for [your]0-i money - go at once ; or , if [I]1828-the waiter lose [my]1828-the waiter place for it , [I]1828-the waiter 'll call out Murder , and raise [the house]244-the house . And mind this : as true as [God]37-god 's in [heaven]3526-heaven , [I]1828-the waiter 'll warn [them]3527-them both before [they]3527-them go outside [our]3527-them door ! "[1828-the waiter]

Hearing , but not heeding [him]1841-him , [I]0-i left [the house]244-the house . No voice that ever spoke , could have called [me]0-i back from the course on which [I]0-i was now bound . [The waiter]1828-the waiter watched [me]0-i vigilantly from the door , as [I]0-i went out . Seeing this , [I]0-i made a circuit , before [I]0-i returned to the spot where , as [I]0-i had suspected , [the cab]1808-the cab [they]1845-they had ridden in was still waiting for [them]1845-they .

[The driver]1797-the driver was asleep inside . [I]0-i awoke [him]1797-the driver ; told [him]1797-the driver [I]0-i had been sent to say that [he]1797-the driver was not wanted again that night : and secured [his]1797-the driver ready departure , by at once paying [him]1797-the driver on [his]1797-the driver own terms . [He]1797-the driver drove off ; and the first obstacle on [the fatal path which [I]0-i had resolved to tread unopposed]1847-the fatal path which i had resolved to tread unopposed , was now removed .

As [the cab]1808-the cab disappeared from [my]0-i sight , [I]0-i looked up at the sky . It was growing very dark . The ragged black clouds , fantastically parted from each other in island shapes over the whole surface of the heavens , were fast drawing together into [one huge , formless , lowering mass]1849-one huge , formless , lowering mass , and had already hidden the moon for , good . [I]0-i went back to [the street]163-the street , and stationed [myself]0-i in the pitch darkness of [a passage which led down [a mews]1852-a mews , situated exactly opposite to [the hotel]1853-the hotel]1851-a passage which led down a mews , situated exactly opposite to the hotel .

In the silence and obscurity , in the sudden pause of action while [I]0-i now waited and watched , [my]0-i Thought rose to [my]0-i lips , and [my]0-i speech mechanically formed it into words . [I]0-i whispered softly to [myself]0-i : [I]0-i will kill [him]1797-the driver when [he]1797-the driver comes out . [My]0-i mind never swerved for an instant from this thought - never swerved towards [myself]0-i ; never swerved towards [her]1797-the driver . Grief was numbed at [my]0-i heart ; and the consciousness of [my]0-i own misery was numbed with grief . Death chills all before it - and [Death]68-death and [my]0-i Thought were one .

Once , while [I]0-i stood on the watch , a sharp agony of suspense tried [me]0-i fiercely .

Just as [I]0-i had calculated that the time was come which would force [them]1854-them to depart , in order to return to [North Villa]11-north villa by the appointed hour , [I]0-i heard the slow , heavy , regular tramp of a footstep advancing along [the street]163-the street . It was [the policeman of [the district]1857-the district]1856-the policeman of the district going [his]1856-the policeman of the district round . As [he]1856-the policeman of the district approached the entrance to [the mews]1858-the mews [he]1856-the policeman of the district paused , yawned , stretched [his]1856-the policeman of the district arms , and began to whistle a tune . If [Mannion]51-mr. mannion should come out while [he]51-mr. mannion was [there]161-there ! [My]0-i blood seemed to stagnate on its course , while [I]0-i thought that this might well happen . Suddenly , [the man]696-the man ceased whistling , looked steadily up and down [the street]163-the street , and tried the door of [a house near [him]696-the man]1862-a house near him - advanced a few steps - then paused again , and tried another door - then muttered to [himself]696-the man , in drowsy tones - " [I]696-the man 've seen all safe [here]3265-here already : it 's [the other street [I]696-the man forgot]3529-the other street i forgot just now . "[696-the man] [He]696-the man turned , and retraced [his]696-the man way . [I]0-i fixed [my]0-i aching eyes vigilantly on [the hotel]1853-the hotel , while [I]0-i heard the sound of [his]696-the man footsteps grow fainter and fainter in the distance . It ceased altogether ; and still there was no change - still [the man whose life [I]0-i was waiting for]1864-the man whose life i was waiting for , never appeared .

Ten minutes after this , so far as [I]0-i can guess , the door opened ; and [I]0-i heard [Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's voice , and the voice of [the lad who had let [me]0-i in]1865-the lad who had let me in . " Look about [you]51-mr. mannion before [you]51-mr. mannion go out , "[1828-the waiter] said [the waiter]1828-the waiter , speaking in [the passage]1048-the passage ; " [the street]163-the street 's not safe for [you]51-mr. mannion . "[1828-the waiter] Disbelieving , or affecting to disbelieve , what [he]696-the man heard , [Mannion]51-mr. mannion interrupted [the waiter]1828-the waiter angrily ; and endeavoured to reassure [[his]51-mr. mannion companion]1869-his companion in guilt , by asserting that the warning was nothing but an attempt to extort money by way of reward . [The man]696-the man retorted sulkily , that [he]696-the man cared nothing for [the gentleman]1118-the gentleman 's money , or [the gentleman]1118-the gentleman either . Immediately afterwards an inner door in [the house]244-the house banged violently ; and [I]0-i knew that [Mannion]51-mr. mannion had been left to [his]51-mr. mannion fate .

There was a momentary silence ; and then [I]0-i heard [him]51-mr. mannion tell [[his]51-mr. mannion accomplice]1874-his accomplice that [he]51-mr. mannion would go alone to look for [the cab]1808-the cab , and that [she]1874-his accomplice had better close the door and wait quietly in [the passage]1048-the passage till [he]51-mr. mannion came back . This was done . [He]51-mr. mannion walked out into [the street]163-the street . It was after twelve o'clock . No sound of a strange footfall was audible - [no soul]1878-no soul was at hand to witness , and prevent , the coming struggle . [His]51-mr. mannion life was [mine]0-i . [His]51-mr. mannion death followed [him]51-mr. mannion as fast as [my]0-i feet followed , while [I]0-i was now walking on [his]51-mr. mannion track .

[He]51-mr. mannion looked up and down , from the entrance to [the street]163-the street , for [the cab]1808-the cab . Then , seeing that it was gone , [he]51-mr. mannion hastily turned back . At that instant [I]0-i met [him]51-mr. mannion face to face . Before a word could be spoken , even before a look could be exchanged , [my]0-i hands were on [his]51-mr. mannion throat .

[He]51-mr. mannion was [a taller and heavier man than [I]0-i was]1881-a taller and heavier man than i was ; and struggled with [me]0-i , knowing that [he]51-mr. mannion was struggling for [his]51-mr. mannion life . [He]51-mr. mannion never shook [my]0-i grasp on [him]51-mr. mannion for a moment ; but [he]51-mr. mannion dragged [me]0-i out into [the road]1783-the road - dragged [me]0-i away eight or ten yards from [the street]163-the street . The heavy gasps of approaching suffocation beat thick on [my]0-i forehead from [his]51-mr. mannion open mouth : [he]51-mr. mannion swerved to and fro furiously , from side to side ; and struck at [me]0-i , swinging [his]51-mr. mannion clenched fists high above [his]51-mr. mannion head . [I]0-i stood firm , and held [him]51-mr. mannion away at arm 's length . As [I]0-i dug [my]0-i feet into the ground to steady [myself]0-i , [I]0-i heard the crunching of stones - [the road]1783-the road had been newly mended with granite . Instantly , a savage purpose goaded into fury the deadly resolution by which [I]0-i was possessed . [I]0-i shifted [my]0-i hold to the back of [his]51-mr. mannion neck , and the collar of [his]51-mr. mannion coat , and hurled [him]51-mr. mannion , with the whole impetus of the raging strength that was let loose in [me]0-i , face downwards , on to the stones .

In the mad triumph of that moment , [I]0-i had already stooped towards [him]51-mr. mannion , as [he]51-mr. mannion lay insensible beneath [me]0-i , to lift [him]51-mr. mannion again , and beat out of [him]51-mr. mannion , on the granite , not life only , but the semblance of humanity as well ; when , in the blank stillness that followed the struggle , [I]0-i heard the door of [the hotel]1853-the hotel in [the street]163-the street open once more . [I]0-i left [him]51-mr. mannion directly , and ran back from [the square]717-the square - [I]0-i knew not with what motive , or what idea - to the spot .

On the steps of [the house]244-the house , on the threshold of [that accursed place]1889-that accursed place , stood [the woman whom [[God]37-god 's minister]1891-god 's minister had given to [me]0-i in the sight of [God]37-god , as [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife .

One long pang of shame and despair shot through [my]0-i heart as [I]0-i looked at [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife , and tortured out of its trance the spirit within [me]0-i . Thousands on thousands of thoughts seemed to be whirling in the wildest confusion through and through [my]0-i brain - thoughts , whose track was a track of fire - thoughts that struck [me]0-i with a hellish torment of dumbness , at the very time when [I]0-i would have purchased with [my]0-i life the power of a moment 's speech . Voiceless and tearless , [I]0-i went up to [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife , and took [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife by the arm , and drew [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife away from [the house]244-the house . There was some vague purpose in [me]0-i , as [I]0-i did this , of never quitting [my]0-i hold of [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife , never letting [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife stir from [me]0-i by so much as an inch , until [I]0-i had spoken certain words to [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife . What words they were , and when [I]0-i should utter them , [I]0-i could not tell .

The cry for mercy was on [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife lips , but the instant [our]1894-our eyes met , it died away in long , low , hysterical moanings . [Her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife cheeks were ghastly , [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife features were rigid , [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife eyes glared like [an idiot]1895-an idiot 's ; guilt and terror had made [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife hideous to look upon already .

[I]0-i drew [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife onward a few paces towards [the Square]717-the square . Then [I]0-i stopped , remembering the body that lay face downwards on [the road]1783-the road . The savage strength of a few moments before , had left [me]0-i from the time when [I]0-i first saw [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife . [I]0-i now reeled where [I]0-i stood , from sheer physical weakness . The sound of [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife pantings and shudderings , of [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife abject inarticulate murmurings for mercy , struck [me]0-i with a supernatural terror . [My]0-i fingers trembled round [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife arm , the perspiration dripped down [my]0-i face , like rain ; [I]0-i caught at the railings by [my]0-i side , to keep [myself]0-i from falling . As [I]0-i did so , [she]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife snatched [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife arm from [my]0-i grasp , as easily as if [I]0-i had been [a child]226-a child ; and , with a cry for help , fled towards the further end of [the street]163-the street .

Still , the strange instinct of never losing hold of [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife , influenced [me]0-i . [I]0-i followed , staggering like [a drunken man]1900-a drunken man . In a moment , [she]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife was out of [my]0-i reach ; in another , out of [my]0-i sight . [I]0-i went on , nevertheless ; on , and on , and on , [I]0-i knew not whither . [I]0-i lost all ideas of time and distance . Sometimes [I]0-i went round and round [the same streets]1901-the same streets , over and over again . Sometimes [I]0-i hurried in one direction , straight forward . Wherever [I]0-i went , it seemed to [me]0-i that [she]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife was still just before ; that [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife track and [my]0-i track were one ; that [I]0-i had just lost [my]0-i hold of [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife , and that [she]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife was just starting on [her]1890-the woman whom god 's minister had given to me in the sight of god , as my wife flight .

[I]0-i remember passing [two men]1902-two men in this way , in [some great thoroughfare]1903-some great thoroughfare . [They]1902-two men both stopped , turned , and walked a few steps after [me]0-i . [One]1904-one laughed at [me]0-i , as [a drunkard]1905-a drunkard . [The other]678-the other , in serious tones , told [him]1904-one to be silent ; for [I]0-i was not drunk , but mad - [he]1904-one had seen [my]0-i face as [I]0-i passed under a gas - lamp , and [he]1904-one knew that [I]0-i was mad .

" MAD ! "[1904-one] - that word , as [I]0-i heard it , rang after [me]0-i like a voice of judgment . " MAD ! "[1904-one] - a fear had come over [me]0-i , which , in all its frightful complication , was expressed by that one word - a fear which , to [the man who suffers it , is worse even than the fear of death]1907-the man who suffers it , is worse even than the fear of death ; which no human language ever has conveyed , or ever will convey , in all its horrible reality , to [others]98-others . [I]0-i had pressed onward , hitherto , because [I]0-i saw a vision that led [me]0-i after it - a beckoning shadow , ahead , darker even than the night darkness . [I]0-i still pressed on , now ; but only because [I]0-i was afraid to stop .

[I]0-i know not how far [I]0-i had gone , when [my]0-i strength utterly failed [me]0-i , and [I]0-i sank down helpless , in a lonely place where [the houses]1909-the houses were few and scattered , and trees and [fields]1086-fields were dimly discernible in the obscurity beyond . [I]0-i hid [my]0-i face in [my]0-i hands , and tried to assure [myself]0-i that [I]0-i was still in possession of [my]0-i senses . [I]0-i strove hard to separate [my]0-i thoughts ; to distinguish between [my]0-i recollections ; to extricate from the confusion within [me]0-i any one idea , no matter what - and [I]0-i could not do it . In that awful struggle for the mastery over [my]0-i own mind , all that had passed , all the horror of that horrible night , became as nothing to [me]0-i . [I]0-i raised [myself]0-i , and looked up again , and tried to steady [my]0-i reason by the simplest means - even by endeavouring to count all [the houses within sight]1911-the houses within sight . The darkness bewildered [me]0-i . Darkness ? - Was it dark ? or was day breaking yonder , far away in the murky eastern sky ? Did [I]0-i know what [I]0-i saw ? Did [I]0-i see the same thing for a few moments together ? What was this under [me]0-i ? Grass ? yes ! cold , soft , dewy grass . [I]0-i bent down [my]0-i forehead upon it , and tried , for the last time , to steady [my]0-i faculties by praying ; tried if [I]0-i could utter the prayer which [I]0-i had known and repeated every day from childhood - [the Lord]162-the lord 's Prayer . The Divine Words came not at [my]0-i call - no ! not one of them , from the beginning to the end ! [I]0-i started up on [my]0-i knees . A blaze of lurid sunshine flashed before [my]0-i eyes ; a hell - blaze of brightness , with fiends by millions , raining down out of it on [my]0-i head ; then a rayless darkness - the darkness of [the blind]1913-the blind - then [God]37-god 's mercy at last - the mercy of utter oblivion .

When [I]0-i recovered [my]0-i consciousness , [I]0-i was lying on the couch in [[my]0-i own study]1914-my own study . [[My]0-i father]147-my father was supporting [me]0-i on the pillow ; [the doctor]3241-the doctor had [his]3241-the doctor fingers on [my]0-i pulse ; and [a policeman]1917-a policeman was telling [them]1918-them where [he]1917-a policeman had found [me]0-i , and how [he]1917-a policeman had brought [me]0-i [home]176-home .

PART III .

[I.]0-i

WHEN [the blind]1913-the blind are operated on for the restoration of sight , the same succouring hand which has opened to [them]1913-the blind the visible world , immediately shuts out the bright prospect again , for a time . A bandage is passed over the eyes , lest in the first tenderness of the recovered sense , it should be fatally affected by the sudden transition from darkness to light . But between the awful blank of total privation of vision , and the temporary blank of vision merely veiled , there lies the widest difference . In the moment of [their]1913-the blind restoration , [the blind]1913-the blind have had one glimpse of light , flashing on [them]1913-the blind in an overpowering gleam of brightness , which the thickest , closest veiling can not extinguish . The new darkness is not like the void darkness of old ; it is filled with changing visions of brilliant colours and ever - varying forms , rising , falling , whirling hither and thither with every second . Even when the handkerchief is passed over [them]1913-the blind , the once sightless eyes , though bandaged fast , are yet not blinded as they were before .

It was so with [my]0-i mental vision . After the utter oblivion and darkness of a deep swoon , consciousness flashed like light on [my]0-i mind , when [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in [[my]0-i father]147-my father 's presence , and in [[my]0-i own home]1643-my own home . But , almost at the very moment when [I]0-i first awakened to the bewildering influence of that sight , a new darkness fell upon [my]0-i faculties - a darkness , this time , which was not utter oblivion ; a peopled darkness , like that which the bandage casts over the opened eyes of [the blind]1913-the blind .

[I]0-i had sensations , [I]0-i had thoughts , [I]0-i had visions , now - but they all acted in the frightful self - concentration of delirium . The lapse of time , the march of events , the alternation of day and night , [the persons who moved about [me]0-i]1925-the persons who moved about me , the words [they]1913-the blind spoke , the offices of kindness [they]1913-the blind did for [me]0-i - all these were annihilated from the period when [I]0-i closed [my]0-i eyes again , after having opened them for an instant on [[my]0-i father]147-my father , in [[my]0-i own study]1914-my own study .

[My]0-i first sensation how soon it came after [I]0-i had been brought [home]176-home , [I]0-i know not was of a terrible heat ; a steady , blazing heat , which seemed to have shrivelled and burnt up the whole of [the little world around [me]0-i]1929-the little world around me , and to have left [me]0-i alone to suffer , but never to consume in it . After this , came a quick , restless , unintermittent toiling of obscure thought , ever in [the same darkened sphere]1930-the same darkened sphere , ever on the same impenetrable subject , ever failing to reach some distant and visionary result . It was as if something were imprisoned in [my]0-i mind , and moving always to and fro in it - moving , but never getting free .

Soon , these thoughts began to take a form that [I]0-i could recognise .

In the clinging heat and fierce seething fever , to which neither waking nor sleeping brought a breath of freshness or a dream of change , [I]0-i began to act [my]0-i part over again , in the events that had passed , but in a strangely altered character . Now , instead of placing implicit trust in [others]98-others , as [I]0-i had done ; instead of failing to discover a significance and a warning in each circumstance as it arose , [I]0-i was suspicious from the first - suspicious of [Margaret]44-margaret , of [[her]44-margaret father]1224-her father , of [[her]44-margaret mother]319-her mother , of [Mannion]51-mr. mannion , of [the very servants in [the house]244-the house]1934-the very servants in the house . In the hideous phantasmagoria of [my]0-i own calamity on which [I]0-i now looked , [my]0-i position was reversed . Every event of the doomed year of [my]0-i probation was revived . But the doom itself , the night - scene of horror through which [I]0-i had passed , had utterly vanished from [my]0-i memory . This lost recollection , it was the one unending toil of [my]0-i wandering mind to recover , and [I]0-i never got it back . [None who have not suffered as [I]0-i suffered then]1936-none who have not suffered as i suffered then , can imagine with what a burning rage of determination [I]0-i followed past events in [my]0-i delirium , one by one , for days and nights together , - followed , to get to the end which [I]0-i knew was beyond , but which [I]0-i never could see , not even by glimpses , for a moment at a time .

However [my]0-i visions might alter in their course of succession , they always began with the night when [Mannion]51-mr. mannion returned from [the continent]339-the continent to [North Villa]11-north villa . [I]0-i stood again in [the drawing - room]1022-the drawing - room ; [I]0-i saw [him]51-mr. mannion enter ; [I]0-i marked the slight confusion of [Margaret]44-margaret ; and instantly doubted [her]44-margaret . [I]0-i noticed [his]51-mr. mannion unwillingness to meet [her]44-margaret eye or [mine]0-i ; [I]0-i looked on the sinister stillness of [his]51-mr. mannion face ; and suspected [him]51-mr. mannion . From that moment , love vanished , and hatred came in its place . [I]0-i began to watch ; to garner up slight circumstances which confirmed [my]0-i suspicions ; to wait craftily for the day when [I]0-i should discover , judge , and punish [them]1939-them both - the day of disclosure and retribution that never came .

Sometimes , [I]0-i was again with [Mannion]51-mr. mannion , in [[his]51-mr. mannion house]216-his house , on the night of the storm . [I]0-i detected in every word [he]51-mr. mannion spoke an artful lure to trap [me]0-i into trusting [him]51-mr. mannion as [[my]0-i second father]1941-my second father , more than as [[my]0-i friend]3044-my friend . [I]0-i heard in the tempest sounds which mysteriously interrupted , or mingled with , [my]0-i answers , voices supernaturally warning [me]0-i of [[my]0-i enemy]1943-my enemy , each time that [I]0-i spoke to [him]51-mr. mannion . [I]0-i saw once more the hideous smile of triumph on [his]51-mr. mannion face , as [I]0-i took leave of [him]51-mr. mannion on [the doorstep]1944-the doorstep : and saw it , this time , not as an illusion produced by a flash of lightning , but as a frightful reality which the lightning disclosed .

Sometimes , [I]0-i was again in [the garden at [North Villa]11-north villa]1945-the garden at north villa accidentally overhearing the conversation between [Margaret]44-margaret and [[her]44-margaret mother]319-her mother - overhearing what deceit [she]44-margaret was willing to commit , for the sake of getting a new dress - then going into [the room]263-the room , and seeing [her]44-margaret assume [her]44-margaret usual manner on meeting [me]0-i , as if no such words as [I]0-i had listened to but the moment before , had ever proceeded from [her]44-margaret lips . Or , [I]0-i saw [her]44-margaret on that other morning , when , to revenge the death of [her]44-margaret bird , [she]44-margaret would have killed with [her]44-margaret own hand [the one pet companion that [[her]44-margaret sick mother]1949-her sick mother possessed]1948-the one pet companion that her sick mother possessed . Now , no generous , trusting love blinded [me]0-i to the real meaning of such events as these . Now , instead of regarding them as little weaknesses of beauty , and little errors of youth , [I]0-i saw them as timely warnings , which bade [me]0-i remember when the day of [my]0-i vengeance came , that in the contriving of the iniquity on which [they]1950-they were both bent , [the woman]695-the woman had been as vile as [the man]696-the man .

Sometimes , [I]0-i was once more on [my]0-i way to [North Villa]11-north villa , after [my]0-i week 's absence at [[our]1953-our country house]1954-our country house . [I]0-i saw again the change in [Margaret]44-margaret since [I]0-i had left [her]44-margaret - the paleness , the restlessness , the appearance of agitation . [I]0-i took the hand of [Mannion]51-mr. mannion , and started as [I]0-i felt its deadly coldness , and remarked the strange alteration in [his]51-mr. mannion manner . When [they]1950-they accounted for these changes by telling [me]0-i that [both]1955-both had been ill , in different ways , since [my]0-i departure , [I]0-i detected the miserable lie at once ; [I]0-i knew that an evil advantage had been taken of [my]0-i absence ; that the plot against [me]0-i was fast advancing towards consummation : and that , at the sight of [[their]1950-they victim]1956-their victim , even [the two wretches who were compassing [my]0-i dishonour]1957-the two wretches who were compassing my dishonour could not repress all outward manifestation of [their]1957-the two wretches who were compassing my dishonour guilt .

Sometimes , the figure of [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin appeared to [me]0-i , wan and weary , and mournful with a ghostly mournfulness . Again [I]0-i watched [her]43-mrs. sherwin , and listened to [her]43-mrs. sherwin ; but now with eager curiosity , with breathless attention . Once more , [I]0-i saw [her]43-mrs. sherwin shudder when [Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's cold eyes turned on [her]43-mrs. sherwin face - [I]0-i marked the anxious , imploring look that [she]43-mrs. sherwin cast on [Margaret]44-margaret and on [me]0-i - [I]0-i heard [her]43-mrs. sherwin confused , unwilling answer , when [I]0-i inquired the cause of [her]43-mrs. sherwin dislike of [the man in whom [[her]43-mrs. sherwin husband]480-her husband placed the most implicit trust]1958-the man in whom her husband placed the most implicit trust - [I]0-i listened to [her]43-mrs. sherwin abrupt , inexplicable injunction to " watch continually over [[my]43-mrs. sherwin wife]864-my wife , and keep [bad people]3532-bad people from [her]43-mrs. sherwin . "[43-mrs. sherwin] All these different circumstances occurred again as vividly as in the reality ; but [I]0-i did not now account for them , as [I]0-i had once accounted for [them]1960-them , by convincing [myself]0-i that [Mrs. Sherwin]43-mrs. sherwin 's mind was wandering , and that [her]43-mrs. sherwin bodily sufferings had affected [her]43-mrs. sherwin intellect . [I]0-i saw immediately , that [she]43-mrs. sherwin suspected [Mannion]51-mr. mannion , and dared not openly confess [her]43-mrs. sherwin suspicions ; [I]0-i saw , that in the stillness , and abandonment , and self - concentration of [her]43-mrs. sherwin neglected life , [she]43-mrs. sherwin had been watching more vigilantly than [others]98-others had watched ; [I]0-i detected in every one of [her]43-mrs. sherwin despised gestures , and looks , and halting words , the same concealed warning ever lying beneath the surface ; [I]0-i knew [they]1962-their had not succeeded in deceiving [her]43-mrs. sherwin ; [I]0-i was determined [they]1962-their should not succeed in deceiving [me]0-i .

It was oftenest at this point , that [my]0-i restless memory recoiled before the impenetrable darkness which forbade it to see further - to see on to the last evening , to the fatal night . It was oftenest at this point , that [I]0-i toiled and struggled back , over and over again , to seek once more the lost events of the End , through the events of the Beginning . How often [my]0-i wandering thoughts thus incessantly and desperately traced and retraced [their]1962-their way over [their]1962-their own fever track , [I]0-i can not tell : but there came a time when [they]1962-their suddenly ceased to torment [me]0-i ; when the heavy burden that was on [my]0-i mind fell off ; when a sudden strength and fury possessed [me]0-i , and [I]0-i plunged down through a vast darkness into a world whose daylight was all radiant flame . Giant phantoms mustered by millions , flashing white as lightning in the ruddy air . [They]1962-their rushed on [me]0-i with hurricane speed ; [their]1962-their wings fanned [me]0-i with fiery breezes ; and the echo of [their]1962-their thunder - music was like the groaning and rending of an earthquake , as [they]1962-their tore [me]0-i away with [them]1962-their on [their]1962-their whirlwind course .

Away ! to [a City of Palaces]1963-a city of palaces , to [measureless halls]1964-measureless halls , and arches , and domes , soaring one above another , till [their]1962-their flashing ruby summits are lost in the burning void , high overhead . On ! through and through these mountain - piles , into [countless , limitless corridors]1965-countless , limitless corridors , reared on pillars lurid and rosy as molten lava . Far down [the corridors]1966-the corridors rise visions of flying phantoms , ever at the same distance before [us]1967-us - [their]1962-their raving voices clanging like the hammers of a thousand forges . Still on and on ; faster and faster , for days , years , centuries together , till there comes , stealing slowly forward to meet [us]1967-us , a shadow - a vast , stealthy , gliding shadow - the first darkness that has ever been shed over that world of blazing light ! It comes nearer - nearer and nearer softly , till it touches the front ranks of [[our]1967-us phantom troop]1968-our phantom troop . Then in an instant , [our]1967-us rushing progress is checked : the thunder - music of [our]1967-us wild march stops ; the raving voices of the spectres ahead , cease ; a horror of blank stillness is all about [us]1967-us - and as the shadow creeps onward and onward , until [we]1967-us are enveloped in it from front to rear , [we]1967-us shiver with icy cold under the fiery air and amid the lurid lava pillars which hem [us]1967-us in on either side .

A silence , like no silence ever known on [earth]1969-earth ; a darkening of the shadow , blacker than the blackest night in the thickest wood - a pause - then , a sound as of the heavy air being cleft asunder ; and then , an apparition of two figures coming on out of the shadow - two monsters stretching forth [their]1962-their gnarled yellow talons to grasp at [us]1967-us ; leaving on [their]1962-their track a green decay , oozing and shining with a sickly light . Beyond and around [me]0-i , as [I]0-i stood in the midst of [them]1962-their , [the phantom troop]1970-the phantom troop dropped into formless masses , while [the monsters]1971-the monsters advanced . [They]1962-their came close to [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i alone , of all the myriads around , changed not at [their]1962-their approach . [Each]1972-each laid a talon on [my]0-i shoulder - each raised a veil which was one hideous net - work of twining worms . [I]0-i saw through the ghastly corruption of [their]1962-their faces the look that told [me]0-i who [they]1962-their were - the monstrous iniquities incarnate in monstrous forms ; [the fiend - souls made visible in fiend - shapes]1973-the fiend - souls made visible in fiend - shapes - [Margaret]44-margaret and [Mannion]51-mr. mannion !

A moment more ! and [I]0-i was alone with [those two]1974-those two . [Not a wreck of the phantom - multitude]1975-not a wreck of the phantom - multitude remained ; [the towering city]1976-the towering city , [the gleaming corridors]1977-the gleaming corridors , the fire - bright radiance had vanished . [We]1978-us stood on [a wilderness]1979-a wilderness - [a still , black lake of dead waters]1980-a still , black lake of dead waters was before [us]1978-us ; a white , faint , misty light shone on [us]1978-us . Outspread over the noisome ground lay [the ruins of [a house]1982-a house , rooted up and overthrown to [its]1982-a house foundations]1981-the ruins of a house , rooted up and overthrown to its foundations . [The demon figures]1983-the demon figures , still watching on either side of [me]0-i , drew [me]0-i slowly forward to the fallen stones , and pointed to two dead bodies lying among [them]1983-the demon figures .

[[My]0-i father]147-my father ! - [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister ! - both cold and still , and whiter than the white light that showed them to [me]0-i . The demons at [my]0-i side stretched out [their]1983-the demon figures crooked talons , and forbade [me]0-i to kneel before [[my]0-i father]147-my father , or to kiss [Clara]57-clara 's wan face , before [I]0-i went to torment . [They]1983-the demon figures struck [me]0-i motionless where [I]0-i stood - and unveiled [their]1983-the demon figures hideous faces once more , jeering at [me]0-i in triumph . Anon , [the lake of black waters]1987-the lake of black waters heaved up and overflowed , and noiselessly sucked [us]1988-we away into [its]1987-the lake of black waters central depths - depths that were endless ; depths of rayless darkness , in which [we]1988-we slowly eddied round and round , deeper and deeper down at every turn . [I]0-i felt the bodies of [[my]0-i father]147-my father and [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister touching [me]0-i in cold contact : [I]0-i stretched out [my]0-i arms to clasp [them]1983-the demon figures and sink with [them]1983-the demon figures ; and [the demon pair]1991-the demon pair glided between [us]1988-we , and separated [me]0-i from [them]1991-the demon pair . This vain striving to join [myself]0-i to [[my]0-i dead kindred]1992-my dead kindred when [we]1988-we touched [each other]102-each other in the slow , endless whirlpool , ever continued and was ever frustrated in the same way . Still [we]1988-we sank apart , down [the black gulphs of [the lake]1995-the lake]1994-the black gulphs of the lake ; still there was no light , no sound , no change , no pause of repose - and this was eternity : the eternity of [Hell]19-hell !

Such was one dream - vision out of many that [I]0-i saw . It must have been at this time that [men]518-men were set to watch [me]0-i day and night as [I]0-i afterwards heard , in order that [I]0-i might be held down in [my]0-i bed , when a paroxysm of convulsive strength made [me]0-i dangerous to [myself]0-i and to all about [me]0-i . The period too when [the doctors]1997-the doctors announced that the fever had seized on [my]0-i brain , and was getting the better of [their]1997-the doctors skill , must have been this period .

But though [they]1997-the doctors gave up [my]0-i life as lost , [I]0-i was not to die . There came a time , at last , when the gnawing fever lost its hold ; and [I]0-i awoke faintly one morning to a new existence - to a life frail and helpless as the life of [a new - born babe]1998-a new - born babe .

[I]0-i was too weak to move , to speak , to open [my]0-i eyes , to exert in the smallest degree any one faculty , bodily or mental , that [I]0-i possessed . The first sense of which [I]0-i regained the use , was the sense of hearing ; and the first sound that [I]0-i recognised , was of a light footstep which mysteriously approached , paused , and then retired again gently outside [my]0-i door . The hearing of this sound was [my]0-i first pleasure , the waiting for its repetition [my]0-i first source of happy expectation , since [I]0-i had been ill . Once more the footsteps approached - paused a moment - then seemed to retire as before - then returned slowly . A sigh , very faint and trembling ; a whisper of which [I]0-i could not yet distinguish the import , caught [my]0-i ear - and after that , there was silence . Still [I]0-i waited oh , how happily and calmly ! to hear the whisper soon repeated , and to hear it better when it next came . Ere long , for the third time , the footsteps advanced , and the whispering accents sounded again . [I]0-i could now hear that [they]1997-the doctors pronounced [my]0-i name - once , twice , three times - very softly and imploringly , as if to beg the answer which [I]0-i was still too weak to give . But [I]0-i knew the voice : [I]0-i knew it was [Clara]57-clara 's . Long after it had ceased , the whisper lingered gently on [my]0-i ear , like a lullaby that alternately soothed [me]0-i to slumber , and welcomed [me]0-i to wakefulness . It seemed to be thrilling through [my]0-i frame with a tender , reviving influence - the same influence which the sunshine had , weeks afterwards , when [I]0-i enjoyed it for the first time out of doors .

The next sound that came to [me]0-i was audible in [[my]0-i room]136-my room ; audible sometimes , close at [my]0-i pillow . It was the simplest sound imaginable - nothing but the soft rustling of [a woman]325-a woman 's dress . And yet , [I]0-i heard in it innumerable harmonies , sweet changes , and pauses minute beyond all definition . [I]0-i could only open [my]0-i eyes for a minute at a time , and even then , could not fix them steadily on anything ; but [I]0-i knew that the rustling dress was [Clara]57-clara 's ; and fresh sensations seemed to throng upon [me]0-i , as [I]0-i listened to the sound which told [me]0-i that [she]57-clara was in [the room]263-the room . [I]0-i felt the soft summer air on [my]0-i face ; [I]0-i enjoyed the sweet scent of flowers , wafted on that air ; and once , when [my]0-i door was left open for a moment , the twittering of birds in the aviary down stairs , rang with exquisite clearness and sweetness on [my]0-i ear . It was thus that [my]0-i faculties strengthened , hour by hour , always in the same gradual way , from the time when [I]0-i first heard the footstep and the whisper outside [[my]0-i chamber]2002-my chamber - door .

One evening [I]0-i awoke from a cool , dreamless sleep ; and , seeing [Clara]57-clara sitting by [my]0-i bedside , faintly uttered [her]57-clara name , and moved [my]0-i wasted hand to take [hers]57-clara . As [I]0-i saw the calm , familiar face bending over [me]0-i ; the anxious eyes looking tenderly and lovingly into [mine]0-i - as the last melancholy glory of sunset hovered on [my]0-i bed , and the air , sinking already into its twilight repose , came softly and more softly into [the room]263-the room - as [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister took [me]0-i in [her]296-my sister arms , and raising [me]0-i on [my]0-i weary pillow , bade [me]0-i for [her]296-my sister sake lie hushed and patient a little longer - the memory of the ruin and the shame that had overwhelmed [me]0-i ; the memory of [my]0-i love that had become an infamy ; and of [my]0-i brief year 's hope miserably fulfilled by a life of despair , swelled darkly over [my]0-i heart . The red , retiring rays of sunset just lingered at that moment on [my]0-i face . [Clara]57-clara knelt down by [my]0-i pillow , and held up [her]57-clara handkerchief to shade [my]0-i eyes - " [God]37-god has given [you]0-i back to [us]3533-us , [Basil]46-basil , "[57-clara] [she]57-clara whispered , " to make [us]3533-us happier than ever . "[57-clara] As [she]57-clara spoke , the springs of the grief so long pent up within [me]0-i were loosened ; hot tears dropped heavily and quickly from [my]0-i eyes ; and [I]0-i wept for the first time since the night of horror which had stretched [me]0-i where [I]0-i now lay - wept in [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister 's arms , at that quiet evening hour , for the lost honour , the lost hope , the lost happiness that had gone from [me]0-i for ever in [my]0-i youth !

II .

Darkly and wearily the days of [my]0-i recovery went on . After that first outburst of sorrow on the evening when [I]0-i recognised [[my]0-i sister]296-my sister , and murmured [her]296-my sister name as [she]296-my sister sat by [my]0-i side , there sank over all [my]0-i faculties a dull , heavy trance of mental pain .

[I]0-i dare not describe what remembrances of [the guilty woman who had deceived and ruined [me]0-i]2007-the guilty woman who had deceived and ruined me , now gnawed unceasingly and poisonously at [my]0-i heart . [My]0-i bodily strength feebly revived ; but [my]0-i mental energies never showed a sign of recovering with them . [[My]0-i father]147-my father 's considerate forbearance , [Clara]57-clara 's sorrowful reserve in touching on the subject of [my]0-i long illness , or of the wild words which had escaped [me]0-i in [my]0-i delirium , mutely and gently warned [me]0-i that the time was come when [I]0-i owed the tardy atonement of confession to [the family]179-the family that [I]0-i had disgraced ; and still , [I]0-i had no courage to speak , no resolution to endure . The great misery of the past , shut out from [me]0-i the present and the future alike - every active power of [my]0-i mind seemed to be destroyed hopelessly and for ever .

There were moments - most often at the early morning hours , while the heaviness of the night 's sleep still hung over [me]0-i in [my]0-i wakefulness - when [I]0-i could hardly realise the calamity which had overwhelmed [me]0-i ; when it seemed that [I]0-i must have dreamt , during the night , of scenes of crime and woe and heavy trial which had never actually taken place . What was the secret of the terrible influence which - let [her]2010-her even be the vilest of the vile - [Mannion]51-mr. mannion must have possessed over [Margaret Sherwin]44-margaret , to induce [her]44-margaret to sacrifice [me]0-i to [him]2011-him ? Even the crime itself was not more hideous and more incredible than the mystery in which its evil motives , and the manner of its evil ripening , were still impenetrably veiled .

[Mannion]51-mr. mannion ! It was a strange result of the mental malady under which [I]0-i suffered , that , though the thought of [Mannion]51-mr. mannion was now inextricably connected with every thought of [Margaret]44-margaret , [I]0-i never once asked [myself]0-i , or had an idea of asking [myself]0-i , for days together , after [my]0-i convalescence , what had been the issue of [our]2012-our struggle , for [him]2011-him . In the despair of first awakening to a perfect sense of the calamity which had been hurled on [me]0-i from the hand of [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife - in the misery of first clearly connecting together , after the wanderings of delirium , [the Margaret to whom with [my]0-i hand [I]0-i had given all [my]0-i heart]2014-the margaret to whom with my hand i had given all my heart , with [the Margaret who had trampled on the gift and ruined the giver]2015-the margaret who had trampled on the gift and ruined the giver - all minor thoughts and minor feelings , all motives of revengeful curiosity or of personal apprehension were suppressed . And yet , the time was soon to arrive when that lost thought of inquiry into [Mannion]51-mr. mannion 's fate , was to become [the one master]2016-the one master - thought that possessed [me]0-i - the thought that gave back its vigilance to [my]0-i intellect , and its manhood to [my]0-i heart .

One evening [I]0-i was sitting alone in [[my]0-i room]136-my room . [[My]0-i father]147-my father had taken [Clara]57-clara out for a little air and exercise , and [the servant]315-the servant had gone away at [my]0-i own desire . It was in this quiet and solitude , when the darkness was fast approaching , when the view from [my]0-i window was at its loneliest , when [my]0-i mind was growing listless and confused as the weary day wore out - it was exactly at this time that the thought suddenly and mysteriously flashed across [me]0-i : Had [Mannion]51-mr. mannion been taken up from the stones on which [I]0-i had hurled [him]51-mr. mannion , [a living man]2020-a living man or [a dead]2021-a dead ?

[I]0-i instinctively started to [my]0-i feet with something of the vigour of [my]0-i former health ; repeating the question to [myself]0-i ; and feeling , as [I]0-i unconsciously murmured aloud the few words which expressed it , that [my]0-i life had purposes and duties , trials and achievements , which were yet to be fulfilled . How could [I]0-i instantly solve the momentous doubt which had now , for the first time , crossed [my]0-i mind ?

One moment [I]0-i paused in eager consideration - the next , [I]0-i descended to [the library]1061-the library . A daily newspaper was kept [there]161-there , filed for reference . [I]0-i might possibly decide the fatal question in a few moments by consulting it . In [my]0-i burning anxiety and impatience [I]0-i could hardly handle the leaves or see the letters , as [I]0-i tried to turn back to the right date - the day oh anguish of remembrance ! on which [I]0-i was to have claimed [Margaret Sherwin]44-margaret as [[my]0-i wife]864-my wife !

At last , [I]0-i found the number [I]0-i desired ; but the closely - printed columns swam before [me]0-i as [I]0-i looked at them . A glass of water stood on a table near [me]0-i - [I]0-i dipped [my]0-i handkerchief in it , and cooled [my]0-i throbbing eyes . The destiny of [my]0-i future life might be decided by the discovery [I]0-i was now about to make !

[I]0-i locked the door to guard against all intrusion , and then returned to [my]0-i task - returned to [my]0-i momentous search - slowly tracing [my]0-i way through the paper , paragraph by paragraph , column by column .

On the last page , and close to the end , [I]0-i read these lines :

" MYSTERIOUS OCCURRENCE .[0-i]

" About one o'clock this morning , [a gentleman]3111-a gentleman was discovered lying on [his]3111-a gentleman face in the middle of [the road]1783-the road , in [Westwood Square]20-westwood square , by [the policeman on duty]3536-the policeman on duty . [The unfortunate man]3537-the unfortunate man was to all appearance dead . [He]3111-a gentleman had fallen on a part of [the road]1783-the road which had been recently macadamised ; and [his]3111-a gentleman face , [we]3539-we are informed , is frightfully mutilated by contact with the granite . [The policeman]3540-the policeman conveyed [him]3111-a gentleman to [the neighbouring hospital]3541-the neighbouring hospital , where it was discovered that [he]3111-a gentleman was still alive , and the promptest attentions were immediately paid [him]3111-a gentleman . [We]3539-we understand that [the surgeon in attendance]3542-the surgeon in attendance considers it absolutely impossible that [he]3111-a gentleman could have been injured as [he]3111-a gentleman was , except by having been violently thrown down on [his]3111-a gentleman face , either by [a vehicle driven]3543-a vehicle driven at a furious rate , or by a savage attack from [some person]3544-some person or [persons unknown]3545-persons unknown . In the latter case , robbery could not have been the motive ; for [the unfortunate man]3537-the unfortunate man 's watch , purse , and ring were all found about [him]3111-a gentleman . No cards of address or letters of any kind were discovered in [his]3111-a gentleman pockets , and [his]3111-a gentleman linen and handkerchief were only marked with the letter M. [He]3111-a gentleman was dressed in evening costume - entirely in black . After what has been already said about the injuries to [his]3111-a gentleman face , any recognisable personal description of [him]3111-a gentleman is , for the present , unfortunately out of the question . [We]3539-we wait with much anxiety to gain some further insight into this mysterious affair , when [the sufferer]3547-the sufferer is restored to consciousness . The last particulars which [[our]3539-we reporter]3548-our reporter was able to collect at [the hospital]3549-the hospital were , that [the surgeon]3550-the surgeon expected to save [[his]3550-the surgeon patient]3551-his patient 's life , and the sight of one of [his]3111-a gentleman eyes . The sight of the other is understood to be entirely destroyed . "[0-i]

With sensations of horror which [I]0-i could not then , and can not now analyse , [I]0-i turned to the next day 's paper ; but found in it no further reference to the object of [my]0-i search . In the number for the day after , however , the subject was resumed in these words :

" The mystery of the accident in [Westwood Square]20-westwood square thickens . [The sufferer]3547-the sufferer is restored to consciousness ; [he]3547-the sufferer is perfectly competent to hear and understand what is said to [him]3547-the sufferer , and is able to articulate , but not very plainly , and only for a moment or so , at a time . [The authorities at [the hospital]3549-the hospital]3553-the authorities at the hospital anticipated , as [we]3539-we did , that , on [the patient]3555-the patient 's regaining [his]3555-the patient senses , some information of the manner in which the terrible accident from which [he]3555-the patient is suffering was caused , would be obtained from [him]3555-the patient . But , to the astonishment of [every one]1283-every one , [he]3555-the patient positively refuses to answer any questions as to the circumstances under which [his]3555-the patient frightful injuries were inflicted . With the same unaccountable secrecy , [he]3555-the patient declines to tell [his]3555-the patient name , [his]3555-the patient place of abode , or the names of [any friends to whom notice of [his]3555-the patient situation might be communicated]3557-any friends to whom notice of his situation might be communicated . It is quite in vain to press [him]3555-the patient for any reason for this extraordinary course of conduct - [he]3555-the patient appears to be [a man of very unusual firmness of character]3558-a man of very unusual firmness of character ; and [his]3555-the patient refusal to explain [himself]3555-the patient in any way , is evidently no mere caprice of the moment . All this leads to the conjecture that the injuries [he]3555-the patient has sustained were inflicted on [him]3555-the patient from some motive of private vengeance ; and that [certain persons]3559-certain persons are concerned in this disgraceful affair , whom [he]3555-the patient is unwilling to expose to public odium , for some secret reason which it is impossible to guess at . [We]3560-we understand that [he]3555-the patient bears the severe pain consequent upon [his]3555-the patient situation , in such a manner as to astonish [every person about [him]3555-the patient]3561-every person about him - no agony draws from [him]3555-the patient a word or a sigh . [He]3555-the patient displayed no emotion even when [the surgeons]3562-the surgeons informed [him]3555-the patient that the sight of one of [his]3555-the patient eyes was hopelessly destroyed ; and merely asked to be supplied with writing materials as soon as [he]3555-the patient could see to use them , when [he]3555-the patient was told that the sight of the other would be saved .
